questions.category: Chapter 41: Assessment of the Musculoskeletal System
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for an older client who has kyphosis and a widened gait. For which health problems is the client at risk?
options: Osteoporosis
Contracture
Osteopenia
Falls
questions.rationale: Kyphosis is caused by bone loss and causes the client to bend forward which changes the center of gravity leading to problems with balance. Older adults who have balance issues are at risk for falls.

questions.category: Chapter 41: Assessment of the Musculoskeletal System
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching assistant personnel (AP) about care of an older ambulatory adult who has osteopenia. Which statement by the AP indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: "I will tell the client to change positions frequently to prevent pressure injury."
"I will remind the client to take frequent walks to strengthen bones."
"I will assist the client with activities of daily living as needed."
"I will apply warm compresses to the joints to relieve pain."
questions.rationale: The ambulatory client who has osteopenia has experienced bone loss. Therefore, taking walks as a weight-bearing exercise helps to prevent further bone loss. The client does not have joint pain and does not need assistance or position changes because the client is ambulatory and probably independent.

questions.category: Chapter 41: Assessment of the Musculoskeletal System
questions.stem: A client had an arthroscopy 1 hour ago on the left knee. The nurse finds the left lower leg to be pale and cool, with a 1+ pedal pulse. What action would the nurse perform first?
options: Assess the neurovascular status of the right leg.
Document the findings in the patient's chart.
Elevate the left leg on at least two pillows.
Notify the primary health care provider immediately.
questions.rationale: The nurse would compare findings of the two legs as these findings may be normal for the client. If a difference is observed, the nurse would then notify the primary health care provider. Documentation would occur after the nurse has all the data. Elevating the left leg will not improve perfusion if there is a problem.

questions.category: Chapter 41: Assessment of the Musculoskeletal System
questions.stem: A hospitalized client's strength of the upper extremities is rated at a 4. What does the nurse understand about this client's ability to perform activities of daily living (ADLs)?
options: The client is able to perform ADLs but not lift some items.
The client is unable to perform ADLs alone.
No difficulties are expected with ADLs.
The client would need almost total assistance with ADLs.
questions.rationale: This rating indicates good muscle strength with full range of motion.

questions.category: Chapter 41: Assessment of the Musculoskeletal System
questions.stem: An older client is distressed at body changes related to kyphosis. What response by the nurse is appropriate?
options: Ask the client to explain more about these feelings.
Explain that these changes are irreversible.
Offer to help select clothes to hide the deformity.
Tell the client that safety is more important than looks.
questions.rationale: Assessment is the first step of the nursing process, and the nurse would begin by getting as much information about the client's feelings as possible. Explaining that the changes are irreversible discounts the client's feelings. Depending on the extent of the deformity, clothing will not hide it. While safety is more objectively important than looks, the client is worried about looks and the nurse needs to address this issue.

questions.category: Chapter 41: Assessment of the Musculoskeletal System
questions.stem: The nurse is taking a history from an older client who reports having frequent falls. Which dietary habit could be contributing to the client's problem?
options: Consumes high-protein foods.
Eats few concentrated sweets.
Limits fatty or greasy foods.
Avoids dairy products.
questions.rationale: Falls can occur when older adults have inadequate calcium and Vitamin D because they are at risk for osteopenia and osteoporosis. Dairy products have a high concentration of both calcium and Vitamin D and this client avoids those foods. High-protein foods are recommended to help prevent osteopenia and sweets and fatty/greasy foods have no impact on bone health.

questions.category: Chapter 41: Assessment of the Musculoskeletal System
questions.stem: The client's electronic health record indicates genu varum. What does the nurse understand this term to mean?
options: Bow-legged
Fluid accumulation
Knock-kneed
Spinal curvature
questions.rationale: Genu varum is a bow-legged deformity. A fluid accumulation is an effusion. Genu valgum is knock-kneed. A spinal curvature could be kyphosis or lordosis.

questions.category: Chapter 41: Assessment of the Musculoskeletal System
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a client who had a left humeral biopsy about home care. Which statement by the client indicates understanding of the nurse's teaching?
options: "I will take my opioids only when I have severe pain."
"I will keep my left arm elevated for 24 hours."
"I will watch for tenderness and warmth around the biopsy site."
"I will report any discomfort to my primary health care provider immediately."
questions.rationale: Bone biopsy is an ambulatory procedure which can cause some discomfort but not severe pain. The client can use the affected arm soon after the procedure but should watch for tenderness and warmth which could indicate infection.

questions.category: Chapter 41: Assessment of the Musculoskeletal System
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching assistive personnel (AP) about the risk for osteoporosis associated with race or ethnicity. Which population typically has a decreased incidence of osteoporosis when compared to Euro-Americans?
options: Irish Americans
African Americans
American Indians
Asian Americans
questions.rationale: African Americans usually have more bone mass when compared to Euro-Americans which makes them at a decreased risk for osteoporosis.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: A client has a bone density score of –2.8. What intervention would the nurse anticipate based on this assessment?
options: Asking the client to complete a food diary
Planning to teach about bisphosphonates
Scheduling another scan in 2 years
Scheduling another scan in 6 months
questions.rationale: A T-score from a bone density scan at or lower than –2.5 indicates osteoporosis. The nurse would plan to teach about medications used to treat this disease, such as the bisphosphonates. A food diary is helpful to determine if the client gets adequate calcium and vitamin D, but at this point, dietary changes will not prevent the disease. Simply scheduling another scan will not help treat the disease either.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse teaches assistive personnel (AP) about care of an older adult diagnosed with osteoporosis. What teaching would the nurse include?
options: "Teach the client to eat high-calcium foods in the diet."
"Assist the client with activities of daily living."
"Osteoporosis places the client is at risk for fractures."
"The client should stay in bed to prevent falling."
questions.rationale: Anyone who has osteoporosis is at risk for fragility fractures even if he or she does not experience trauma like a fall. The client needs to keep active rather than stay in bed where more bone could be lost. High-calcium foods may not be helpful because bone loss is already severe. There is no indication that the client needs assistance with ADLs.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: A client has been advised to perform weight-bearing exercises to help slow bone loss, but has not followed this advice. What response by the nurse is appropriate at this time?
options: Ask the client about fear of falling.
Instruct the client to increase calcium.
Suggest other exercises the client can do.
Tell the client to try weight lifting.
questions.rationale: Fear of falling can limit participation in activity. The nurse would first assess if the client has this fear and then offer suggestions for dealing with it. The client may or may not need extra calcium, other exercises, or weight lifting.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for several Patients with osteoporosis. For which client would bisphosphonates not be a good option?
options: Client with diabetes who has a serum creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL (61 mcmol/L).
Client who recently fell and has vertebral compression fractures.
Hypertensive client who takes calcium channel blockers.
Client with a spinal cord injury who cannot tolerate sitting up.
questions.rationale: Patients on bisphosphonates must be able to sit upright for 30 to 60 minutes after taking them. The client who cannot tolerate sitting up is not a good candidate for this class of drug. Poor renal function also makes Patients poor candidates for this drug, but the client with a creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL (61 mcmol/L) is within normal range. Diabetes and hypertension are not related unless the client also has renal disease. The client who recently fell and sustained fractures is a good candidate for this drug if the fractures are related to osteoporosis.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: A client has been prescribed denosumab. What health teaching about this drug is most appropriate for the nurse to include?
options: "Drink at least 8 ounces (240 mL) of water with it."
"Make appointments to come get your injection."
"Sit upright for 30 to 60 minutes after taking it."
"Take the drug on an empty stomach."
questions.rationale: Denosumab is given by subcutaneous injection twice a year. The client does not need to drink 8 ounces (240 mL) of water with this medication as it is not taken orally. The client does not need to remain upright for 30 to 60 minutes after taking this medication, nor does the client need to take the drug on an empty stomach.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is performing an assessment of a client with possible plantar fasciitis in the right foot. What assessment finding would the nurse expect in the right foot?
options: Multiple toe deformities
Numbness and paresthesias
Severe pain in the arch of the foot
Redness and severe swelling
questions.rationale: The most common assessment finding is the client's report of severe pain in the arch of the foot, especially when walking. The other findings are not typical in Patients with this health problem.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a young client who has been diagnosed with osteopenia. Which risk factor in the client's history most likely contributed to the bone loss?
options: Osteoarthritis
Hypothyroidism
Addison disease
Rheumatoid arthritis
questions.rationale: Rheumatoid arthritis often occurs in young female adults and can lead to osteoporosis as a common complication. Cushing disease (rather than Addison disease) and hyperthyroidism (rather than hypothyroidism) are also risk factors. Osteoarthritis is a joint disease.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: An older client with diabetes is admitted with a heavily draining leg wound. The client's white blood cell count is 38,000/mm³ (38 × 10⁹/L) but the client is afebrile. Which nursing action is most appropriate at this time?
options: Administer acetaminophen as needed.
Educate the client on amputation.
Place the client on Contact Precautions.
Refer the client to the wound care nurse.
questions.rationale: In the presence of a heavily draining wound, the nurse would place the client on Contact Precautions. If the client has discomfort, acetaminophen can be used, but this client has not reported pain and is afebrile. The client may or may not need an amputation in the future. The wound care nurse may be consulted but not as the most appropriate action.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: A nurse is caring for four Patients. After the hand-off report, which client would the nurse see first?
options: Client with osteoporosis and a white blood cell count of 27,000/mm³ (27 × 10⁹/L)
Client with osteoporosis and a bone fracture who requests pain medication
Post-microvascular bone transfer client whose distal leg is cool and pale
Client with suspected bone tumor who just returned from having a spinal CT
questions.rationale: This client is the priority because the assessment findings indicate a critical lack of perfusion. A high white blood cell count is an expected finding for the client with osteoporosis. The client requesting pain medication should be seen second. The client who just returned from a CT scan is stable and needs no specific postprocedure care.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: A client has a metastatic bone tumor in the left leg. What action by the nurse is appropriate?
options: Administer pain medication as prescribed.
Elevate the extremity and apply moist heat.
Teach the client about amputation care.
Place the client on protective precautions.
questions.rationale: Pain medication should be given to control metastatic bone pain. Elevation and heat may or may not be helpful. Protective precautions are not needed for this client.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: A client with bone cancer is hospitalized for a limb salvage procedure. How can the nurse best address the client's psychosocial needs?
options: Assess the client's coping skills and support systems.
Explain that the surgery leads to a longer life expectancy.
Refer the client to the social worker or hospital chaplain.
Reinforce physical therapy to aid with ambulating normally.
questions.rationale: The first step in the nursing process is assessment. The nurse would assess coping skills and possible support systems that will be helpful in this client's treatment. Explaining that a limb salvage procedure will extend life does not address the client's psychosocial needs. Referrals may be necessary, but the nurse should assess first. Reinforcing physical therapy is also helpful but again does not address the psychosocial needs of the client.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: A client had a bunionectomy with osteotomy. The client asks why healing may take up to 3 months. What explanation by the nurse is best?
options: "The bones in your feet are hard to operate on."
"The surrounding bones and tissue are damaged."
"Your feet have less blood flow, so healing is slower."
"Your feet bear weight so they never really heal."
questions.rationale: The feet are the most distal to the heart and receive less blood flow than other organs and tissues, prolonging the healing time after surgery. The other explanations are not correct.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: A nurse assesses Patients in an osteoporosis clinic. Which client would the nurse assess first?
options: Client taking calcium with vitamin D who reports flank pain 2 weeks ago.
Client taking ibandronate who cannot remember when the last dose was.
Client taking raloxifene who reports unilateral calf swelling.
Client taking risedronate who reports occasional dyspepsia.
questions.rationale: The client on raloxifene needs to be assessed first because of the potential for deep vein thrombosis, which is an adverse effect of raloxifene. The client with flank pain may have had a kidney stone but is not acutely ill now. The client who cannot remember taking the last dose of ibandronate can be seen last. The client on risedronate may need to change medications.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: What information does the nurse teach a women's group about osteoporosis?
options: "Primary osteoporosis occurs in postmenopausal women due to lack of estrogen."
"Men actually have higher rates of the disease but are underdiagnosed."
"There is no way to prevent or slow osteoporosis after menopause."
"Women and men have an equal chance of getting osteoporosis."
questions.rationale: Women are more at risk of developing primary osteoporosis after menopause due to the lack of estrogen. Men have a slower loss of bone after the age of 75. Many treatments are now available for women to slow osteoporosis after menopause.

questions.category: Chapter 42: Concepts of Care for Patients with Musculoskeletal Conditions
questions.stem: A client with osteoporosis is going home where the client lives alone. What action by the nurse is best?
options: Refer the client to Meals on Wheels.
Arrange a home safety evaluation.
Ensure that the client has a walker at home.
Help the client look into assisted living.
questions.rationale: This client has several risk factors that place him or her at a high risk for falling. The nurse should consult social work or home health care to conduct a home safety evaluation. The other options may or may not be needed based upon the client's condition at discharge.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a client who has severe osteoarthritis. What primary joint problems will the nurse expect the client to report?
options: Crepitus
Effusions
Pain
Deformities
questions.rationale: The primary assessment finding typically reported by Patients who have osteoarthritis is joint pain, although crepitus, effusions (fluid), and mild deformities may occur.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A nurse is teaching a client newly diagnosed with osteoarthritis (OA) about drugs used to treat the disease. For which drug does the nurse plan health teaching?
options: Acetaminophen
Cyclobenzaprine hydrochloride
Hyaluronate
Ibuprofen
questions.rationale: All of these drugs may be appropriate to treat OA. However, the first-line drug is acetaminophen. Cyclobenzaprine is a muscle relaxant given to treat muscle spasms. Hyaluronate is a synthetic joint fluid implant. Ibuprofen is a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: The nurse assesses a client with diabetes and osteoarthritis (OA) during a checkup. The nurse notes the client's blood glucose readings have been elevated. What question by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: "Are you following the prescribed diabetic diet?"
"Have you been taking glucosamine supplements?"
"How much exercise do you really get each week?"
"You're still taking your diabetic medication, right?"
questions.rationale: All of the topics are appropriate for a client whose blood glucose readings have been higher than usual. However, since this client also has OA, and glucosamine can increase blood glucose levels, the nurse would ask about its use. The other questions all have an element of nontherapeutic communication in them. Asking how much exercise the client "really" gets is accusatory. Asking if the diet is being followed is accusatory. Asking if the client takes his or her medications "right?" is patronizing.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: The nurse interviews an older client with moderate osteoarthritis and her husband. What psychosocial assessment question would the nurse include?
options: "Do you feel like hurting yourself or others?"
"Are you planning to retire due to your disease?"
"Do you ask your husband for assistance?"
"Do you experience discomfort during sex?"
questions.rationale: Although some Patients can become depressed and anxious as a result of having OA, suicidal ideation is not common. The nurse should not assume that an older adult will want to retire or that the client will need help from her husband. Many Patients avoid sexual intercourse because of joint pain and stiffness.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: The nurse assesses a client after a total hip arthroplasty. The client's surgical leg is visibly shorter than the other one and the client reports extreme pain. While a co-worker calls the surgeon, what action by the nurse is appropriate?
options: Assess neurovascular status in both legs.
Elevate the surgical leg and apply ice.
Prepare to administer pain medication.
Try to place the surgical leg in abduction.
questions.rationale: This client has signs and symptoms of hip dislocation, a potential complication of this surgery. Hip dislocation can cause neurovascular compromise. The nurse would assess neurovascular status while comparing both legs. The nurse would not try to move the extremity to elevate or abduct it. Pain medication may be administered if possible, but first the nurse would thoroughly assess the client.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a client who is prescribed acetaminophen for control of osteoarthritic joint pain. What statement by the client indicates a need for further teaching?
options: "I won't take more than 5000 mg of this drug each day."
"I'll follow up to get my lab tests done to check my liver."
"I'll check drugs that I take for acetaminophen in them."
"I can use topical patches and creams to help relieve pain."
questions.rationale: All of the choices are correct about acetaminophen except that the maximum daily dosage is 4000 mg. For older adults, 3000 mg are recommended due to slower drug metabolism by the liver.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: After a total knee arthroplasty, a client is on the postoperative nursing unit with a continuous femoral nerve blockade. On assessment, the nurse notes the skin of both legs is pale pink, warm, and dry, but the client is unable to dorsiflex or plantarflex the surgical foot. What action would the nurse take next?
options: Document the findings and monitor as prescribed.
Increase the frequency of monitoring the client.
Notify the surgeon or anesthesia provider immediately.
Palpate the client's bladder or perform a bladder scan.
questions.rationale: With the femoral nerve block, the client would still be able to dorsiflex and plantarflex the affected surgical foot. Since this client has an abnormal finding, the nurse would notify either the surgeon or the anesthesia provider immediately. Documentation is the last priority. Increasing the frequency of assessment may be appropriate, but first the nurse must notify the appropriate provider. Palpating the bladder is not related.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A client is prescribed celecoxib for joint pain. What statement by the client indicates a need for further teaching?
options: "I'll report any signs of bleeding or bruising to my primary health care provider."
"I'll take this drug only as prescribed by my primary health care provider."
"I'll be sure to take this drug three times a day only on an empty stomach."
"I'll monitor the amount of urine that I excrete every day and report any changes."
questions.rationale: All of the choices are correct for this NSAID except that celecoxib can cause GI distress unless taken with meals or food. The drug should not be taken on an empty stomach and is rarely taken more than twice a day.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a client who is planning to have a total hip arthroplasty. What statement by the client indicates a need for further teaching?
options: "I will get an IV antibiotic right before surgery to prevent infection."
"I may request a regional nerve block as part of the surgical anesthesia."
"I will receive IV heparin before surgery to decrease the risk of clots."
"I will receive tranexamic acid to help reduce blood loss during surgery."
questions.rationale: All of the choices are correct except that IV heparin is not given before or after surgery. A different anticoagulant is given after surgery to prevent postoperative venous thromboembolism, such as deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolus.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A client asks the nurse about having a total knee arthroplasty to relieve joint pain. Which factor would place the client at the highest risk for impaired postoperative healing?
options: Controlled hypertension
Obesity
Osteoarthritis
Mild osteopenia
questions.rationale: Obesity places a client at high risk for many postoperative complications including slower wound and bone healing. The other factors usually do not affect healing after surgery.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A nurse assesses a group of Patients who have rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Which client would the nurse see first?
options: Client who reports jaw pain when eating
Client with a red, hot, swollen right wrist
Client who has a puffy-looking area behind the knee
Client with a worse joint deformity since the last visit
questions.rationale: All of the options are possible manifestations of RA. However, the presence of one joint that is much redder, hotter, or more swollen that the other joints may indicate infection or an exacerbation of the RA disease process. The nurse needs to see this client first.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: The nurse assesses a client with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and Sjögren syndrome. What assessment would be most important for this client?
options: Abdominal assessment
Oxygen saturation
Breath sounds
Visual acuity
questions.rationale: Sjögren syndrome may be seen in Patients with RA and manifests with dryness of the eyes, mouth, and vagina in females. Visual disturbances can occur. The other assessments are not related to Sjögren syndrome.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A client who has rheumatoid arthritis is prescribed etanercept. What health teaching by the nurse about this drug is appropriate?
options: Giving subcutaneous injections
Having a chest x-ray once a year
Taking the medication with food
Using heat on the injection site
questions.rationale: Etanercept is given as a subcutaneous injection twice a week. The nurse would teach the client how to self-administer the medication. The other options are not appropriate for etanercept.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A client with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) has an acutely swollen, red, and painful joint. What nonpharmacologic intervention does the nurse recommend?
options: Heating pad
Ice packs
Splint
Paraffin dip
questions.rationale: Ice is best for acute inflammation. Heat often helps with joint stiffness. Splinting helps preserve joint function. A paraffin dip is used to provide warmth to the joint which is more appropriate for chronic pain and stiffness.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A client is scheduled to have a total hip arthroplasty. What preoperative teaching by the nurse is most important?
options: Teach the need to discontinue all medications for 5 days before surgery.
Teach the patient about foods high in protein, Vitamin C, and iron.
Explain to the client the possible need for blood transfusions postoperatively.
Remind the client to have all dental procedures completed at least 2 weeks prior to surgery.
questions.rationale: The nurse would include teaching about dental procedures to avoid infection after new joint has been inserted. Planned procedures would be completed at least 2 weeks before surgery and the client will need to tell any future primary health care providers about having a total joint arthroplasty. Only home medications prescribed that increase the risk for bleeding or clotting need to be discontinued 5 to 10 days before surgery. Patients need to be aware that any postoperative anemia may need to be treated with a blood transfusion, but it is not the most important. Diets high in protein, Vitamin C, and iron help with tissue repair, but are not the most important.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A client is getting out of bed into the chair for the first time after an uncemented total hip arthroplasty. What action by the nurse is appropriate?
options: Have adequate help to transfer the patient.
Provide socks so the patient can slide easier.
Tell the patient full weight bearing is allowed.
Use a footstool to elevate the patient's leg.
questions.rationale: The client with an uncemented hip will be on toe-touch only after surgery. The nurse would ensure there is adequate help to transfer the patient while preventing falls. Slippery socks may cause a fall. Elevating the leg is not going to assist with the client's transfer.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A client has long-term rheumatoid arthritis that especially affects the hands. The client wants to finish quilting a baby blanket before the birth of her grandchild. What response by the nurse is appropriate?
options: "Let's ask your provider about increasing your pain pills."
"Hold ice bags against your hands before quilting."
"Try a paraffin wax dip 20 minutes before you quilt."
"You need to stop quilting before it destroys your fingers."
questions.rationale: Paraffin wax dips are beneficial for decreasing pain in arthritic hands and lead to increased mobility. Increasing pain pills may not help with movement. Ice has limited use unless the client has a "hot" or exacerbated joint. The client wants to finish the project, so the nurse would not negate its importance by telling the client it is destroying her joints.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: A client has a left knee arthrocentesis to remove excess joint fluid. What postprocedure health teaching will the nurse include?
options: "Take your opioid medication as prescribed by the primary health care provider."
"Do not bear weight on your left leg for at least a week after you get home."
"Monitor the site for bleeding or clear fluid leakage when you are home."
"Tell your employer that you can't come back to work for 2 to 3 weeks."
questions.rationale: An arthrocentesis is performed as an ambulatory procedure and may require a mild analgesic such as acetaminophen for discomfort. Opioids are not used. The client may bear weight and return to work, but needs to monitor for bleeding or leakage of synovial fluid at the injection site.

questions.category: Chapter 43: Concepts of Care for Patients With Arthritis and Total Joint Arthroplasty
questions.stem: The primary health care provider prescribes methotrexate (MTX) for a client with a new diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis. The nurse provides health teaching about the drug. What statement by the nurse is appropriate to include about methotrexate?
options: "It will take at least 1 to 2 weeks for the drug to help relieve your symptoms."
"The drug is very expensive but there are pharmacy plans to help pay for it."
"The drug can increase your risk for infection, so you should avoid crowds."
"It's OK for you to drink about 2 to 3 glasses of wine each week while taking the drug."
questions.rationale: MTX takes up to 4 to 6 weeks to begin to help relieve RA symptoms and is very inexpensive. Patients should avoid alcohol due to the potential for liver toxicity. MTX suppresses the immune system which makes Patients susceptible to infection. The nurse teaches Patients to avoid crowds and anyone with a known infection.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A client who had a surgical fractured femur repair reports new-onset shortness of breath and increased respirations. What is the nurse's first action?
options: Place the client in a high-Fowler position.
Document the client's oxygen saturation level.
Start oxygen therapy at 2 L/min via nasal cannula.
Contact the primary health care provider.
questions.rationale: The client is experiencing respiratory distress which could be due to pulmonary embolus, fat embolism syndrome, or anxiety. Regardless of the cause, the nurse would place the client in a sitting position first and then perform additional assessment. Oxygen would likely be needed, especially if the client's oxygen saturation was under 95%.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A client who had a fractured ankle open reduction internal fixation (ORIF) 4 weeks ago reports burning pain and tingling in the affected foot. For which potential complication would the nurse anticipate?
options: Delayed bone healing
Complex regional pain syndrome
Peripheral neuropathy
Compartment syndrome
questions.rationale: Burning pain and tingling that occurs weeks or months after a fracture or other trauma may indicate complex regional pain syndrome. Compartment syndrome tends to occur within days of the initial injury.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: An older client who fell at home is admitted to the emergency department and reports pain in her left groin and behind her left knee. What action would the nurse anticipate?
options: Administer IV push morphine.
Prepare for application of a leg cast.
Begin oxygen at 6 L/min via mask.
Obtain a left hip x-ray.
questions.rationale: The location of the client's pain indicates a possible fractured hip and therefore an x-ray of the hip is needed. A leg cast is not appropriate and oxygen may not be needed. Medication to make the client more comfortable would likely be needed after a diagnosis is determined.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: The nurse is performing a neurovascular assessment for an older client who has an extremity fracture. How many seconds would the nurse expect for a capillary refill in it is within normal range?
options: 20 seconds
15 seconds
10 seconds
5 seconds
questions.rationale: The normal capillary refill is usually 3 seconds, but for older adults, the refill usually takes up to 5 seconds due to vascular changes associated with aging.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse assesses an older adult who was admitted 2 days ago with a fractured hip. The nurse notes that the client is confused and restless with an oxygen saturation of 88%. Which action would the nurse take first?
options: Administer oxygen via nasal cannula.
Re-position to a semi-Fowler position.
Increase the intravenous flow rate.
Assess response to pain medication.
questions.rationale: The client is at high risk for a fat embolism syndrome and pulmonary embolus. Although these complications are life-threatening emergencies, the nurse would administer oxygen first and then notify the primary health care provider. Oxygen administration can reduce the risk for cerebral damage from hypoxia. Pain medication most likely would not cause the client to be restless.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse is caring for several Patients with fractures. Which client would the nurse identify as being at the highest risk for developing deep vein thrombosis?
options: An 18-year-old male athlete with a fractured clavicle
A 36-year-old female with type 2 diabetes and fractured ribs
A 55-year-old female prescribed ibuprofen for osteoarthritis
A 74-year-old male who smokes and has a fractured pelvis
questions.rationale: Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) as a complication with bone fractures occurs more often when fractures are sustained in the lower extremities and the client has additional risk factors for thrombus formation. Other risk factors include obesity, smoking, oral contraceptives, previous thrombus events, advanced age, venous stasis, and heart disease. The other Patients do not have additional risk factors for DVT.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse teaches assistive personnel (AP) about providing hygiene for a client in traction. Which statement would the nurse include as part of the teaching about this client's care?
options: "Remove the traction when re-positioning the client."
"Assess the client's skin when performing a bed bath."
"Provide pin care by using alcohol wipes to clean the sites."
"Ensure that the weights remain freely hanging at all times."
questions.rationale: Traction weights should be freely hanging at all times. They should not be lifted manually or allowed to rest on the floor. The client should remain in traction during hygiene activities. The nurse would assess the client's skin and provide pin and wound care for a patient who is in traction; this would not be delegated to the AP.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A client is admitted to the emergency department with a fractured femur resulting from a motor vehicle crash. What the nurse's priority action?
options: Keep the client warm and comfortable.
Assess airway, breathing, and circulation.
Maintain the client in a supine position.
Immobilize the injured extremity with a splint.
questions.rationale: As part of the primary survey, the nurse would ensure that the client does not have any life-threatening problem by assessing the ABCs first. If there are not major problems, then the nurse could attend to the injured extremity.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a client who had a closed reduction of the left arm and notes a large wet area of drainage on the cast. What action is the most important?
options: Cut off the old cast.
Document the assessment.
Notify the primary health care provider.
Wrap the cast with gauze.
questions.rationale: The primary health care provider should be notified to examine the client and determine the source of the drainage. The nurse's assessment should be documented, but that is not the most important action.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse is caring for a client who is recovering from an above-the-knee amputation and reports pain in the limb that was removed. How would the nurse respond?
options: "The pain you are feeling does not actually exist."
"This type of pain is common and will eventually go away."
"Would you like to learn how to use imagery to minimize your pain?"
"How would you describe the pain that you are feeling?"
questions.rationale: The nurse would ask the client to rate the pain on a scale of 0-10 and describe how the pain feels. Although phantom limb pain is common, the nurse would not minimize the pain that the client is experiencing by stating that it does not exist or will eventually go away. Although imagery may help, the nurse must assess the client's pain before determining the best action.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse cares for a client who had a wrist cast applied 3 days ago. The client states, "The cast is loose enough to slide off." How would the nurse respond?
options: "Keep your arm above the level of your heart."
"As your muscles atrophy, the cast is expected to loosen."
"I will wrap a bandage around the cast to prevent it from slipping."
"You need a new cast now that the swelling is decreased."
questions.rationale: Often the surrounding soft tissues may be swollen considerably when the cast is initially applied. After the swelling has resolved, if the cast is loose enough to permit two or more fingers between the cast and the client's skin, the cast needs to be replaced. Elevating the arm will not solve the problem, and the client's muscles should not atrophy while in a cast for 6 weeks or less. An elastic bandage will not prevent slippage of the cast.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse assesses a client with a pelvic fracture. Which assessment finding would the nurse identify as a complication of this injury?
options: Hypertension
Diarrhea
Infection
Hematuria
questions.rationale: The pelvis is very vascular and close to major organs. Injury to the pelvis can cause integral damage that may manifest as blood in the urine (hematuria) or stool. The nurse would also assess for signs of hemorrhage and hypovolemic shock, which include hypotension and tachycardia. Diarrhea and infection are not common complications of a pelvic fracture.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse cares for a client placed in skeletal traction. The client asks, "What is the primary purpose of this type of traction?" How would the nurse respond?
options: "Skeletal traction will assist in realigning your fractured bone."
"This treatment will prevent future complications and back pain."
"Traction decreases muscle spasms that occur with a fracture."
"This type of traction minimizes damage as a result of fracture treatment."
questions.rationale: Skeletal traction pins or screws are surgically inserted into the bone to aid in bone alignment. As a last resort, traction can be used to relieve pain, decrease muscle spasm, and prevent or correct deformity and tissue damage. These are not primary purposes of skeletal traction.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a postoperative client who have a regional nerve blockade for a surgical tibial fracture repair this morning. What assessment finding would the nurse expect?
options: Client reports nausea and vomiting.
Client reports tingling in the surgical leg.
Client responds well to imagery.
Client reports little to no pain.
questions.rationale: A regional nerve blockade can last for about 24 hours so the client has little to no pain until it wears off. The blockade is localized and therefore does not cause nausea or vomiting.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse is caring for a client recovering from an above-the-knee amputation of the right leg. The client reports pain in the right foot. Which prescribed medication would the nurse most likely administer?
options: Intravenous morphine
Oral acetaminophen
Intravenous calcitonin
Oral ibuprofen
questions.rationale: The client is experiencing phantom limb pain, which usually manifests as intense burning, crushing, or cramping. IV infusions of calcitonin during the week after amputation can reduce phantom limb pain. Opioid analgesics such as morphine are not as effective for phantom limb pain as they are for residual limb pain. Oral acetaminophen and ibuprofen are not used in treating phantom limb pain.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse plans care for a client who is recovering from a below-the-knee amputation of the left leg. Which intervention would the nurse include in this client's plan of care?
options: Place pillows between the client's knees.
Encourage range-of-motion exercises.
Administer prophylactic antibiotics.
Implement strict bedrest in a supine position.
questions.rationale: Patients with a below-the-knee amputation should complete range-of-motion exercises to prevent flexion contractions and prepare for a prosthesis. A pillow may be used under the limb as support. Patients recovering from this type of amputation are at low risk for infection and should not be prescribed prophylactic antibiotics. The client should be encouraged to re-position, move, and exercise frequently, and therefore should not be restricted to bedrest.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a client how to use a cane after a right surgical fractured fibula repair. What health teaching would the nurse include?
options: "Place the cane on your left side."
"Move the cane and your left leg at the same time."
"Be sure the cane is parallel to your waist."
"Use the cane only when your right leg is painful."
questions.rationale: The cane should be placed on the unaffected side (left for this client) and moved forward with the injured leg (right for this client) to provide support. The cane should be parallel to the stylus of the wrist and used at all times when ambulating.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse is caring for a client with diabetes mellitus who has fractured her arm. Which action would the nurse take first?
options: Remove the medical alert bracelet from the fractured arm.
Immobilize the arm by splinting the fractured site.
Place the client in a supine position with a warm blanket.
Cover any open areas with a sterile dressing.
questions.rationale: A client's medical alert bracelet or any other jewelry would be removed from the fractured arm before the affected extremity swells. Immobilization, positioning, and dressing should occur after the bracelet is removed.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse cares for a client with a recently fractured tibia. Which assessment would alert the nurse to take immediate action?
options: Pain of 4 on a scale of 0-10
Numbness in the extremity
Swollen extremity at the injury site
Feeling cold while lying in bed
questions.rationale: The client with numbness and/or tingling of the extremity may be displaying the first signs of acute compartment syndrome. This is an acute problem that requires immediate intervention because of possible decreased circulation. Moderate pain and swelling is an expected assessment after a fracture. Being cold can be treated with additional blankets or by increasing the temperature of the room.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: After teaching a client with a fractured humerus, the nurse assesses the client's understanding. Which dietary choice demonstrates that the client correctly understands the nutrition needed to assist in healing the fracture?
options: Baked fish with orange juice and a vitamin D supplement
Bacon, lettuce, and tomato sandwich with a vitamin B supplement
Vegetable lasagna with a green salad and a vitamin A supplement
Roast beef with low-fat milk and a vitamin C supplement
questions.rationale: The client with a healing fracture needs supplements of vitamins B and C and a high-protein, high-calorie diet. Milk for calcium supplementation and vitamin C supplementation is appropriate. Meat would increase protein in the diet that is necessary for bone healing. Fish, a sandwich, and vegetable lasagna would provide less protein.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A client who had a traumatic above-the-knee amputation states that he fears he will never have an intimate relationship again. What is the nurse's best response?
options: "You'll be able to get a leg prosthesis soon."
"You think you won't be able to have sex again?"
"I will ask the social worker to talk with you."
"Are you married now or have a girl friend?"
questions.rationale: The nurse's response needs to allow further exploration of the client's feelings. Referring the client to another health professional might be appropriate at a later time but discounts the client's current feelings. Asking about marriage or a girlfriend assumes that the client is heterosexual.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse is caring for an older client who is recovering from a leg amputation surgery. The client states, "I don't want to live with only one leg. I should have died during the surgery." What is the nurse's best response?
options: "Your vital signs are good, and you are doing just fine right now."
"Your children are waiting outside. Do you want them to grow up without a father?"
"This is a big change for you. What support system do you have to help you cope?"
"You will be able to do some of the same things as before you became disabled."
questions.rationale: The client feels like less of a person following the amputation. The nurse would help the client to identify coping mechanisms that have worked in the past and current support systems to assist with coping. The nurse would not ignore the client's feelings by focusing on vital signs. The nurse would not try to make the client feel guilty by alluding to family members. The nurse would not refer to the patient as being "disabled" as this labels the client and may fuel poor body image.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: After teaching a client who is recovering from a vertebroplasty, the nurse assesses the patient's understanding. Which statement by the client indicates a need for additional teaching?
options: "I can drive myself home after the procedure."
"I will monitor the puncture site for signs of infection."
"I can start walking tomorrow and increase my activity slowly."
"I will remove the dressing the day after discharge."
questions.rationale: Before discharge, a client who has a vertebroplasty would be taught to avoid driving or operating machinery for the first 24 hours. The client should monitor the puncture site for signs of infection. Usual activities can resume slowly, including walking and slowly increasing activity over the next few days. The client should keep the dressing dry and remove it the next day.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Concepts of Care for Patients With Musculoskeletal Trauma
questions.stem: A nurse plans care for a client who has an external fixator on the lower leg. Which intervention would the nurse include in the plan of care to decrease the client's risk for infection?
options: Washing the frame of the fixator once a day
Releasing fixator tension for 30 minutes twice a day
Avoiding moving the extremity by holding the fixator
Scheduling for pin care to be provided every shift
questions.rationale: To decrease the risk for infection in a client with skeletal traction or external fixation, the nurse would provide routine pin care and assess for signs and symptoms of infection at the pin sites every shift.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: The nurse is interviewing a client who reports having abdominal cramping, bloating, and diarrhea after drinking milk or ingesting other dairy products. What health problem does the client most likely have?
options: Steatorrhea
Ulcerative colitis
Crohn disease
Lactose intolerance
questions.rationale: The client is demonstrating signs and symptoms of lactose intolerance because they occur after the client eats or drinks dairy products which contain lactose.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: The primary health care provider documents that a client has a bruit over the abdominal aorta. What teaching will the nurse provide for assistive personnel (AP) based on this assessment finding?
options: "Use warm compresses on the client's abdomen continuously."
"Avoid washing the client's abdomen too aggressively."
"Apply ice to the client's abdomen every 4 hours."
"Massage the client's abdomen to help reduce pain."
questions.rationale: A bruit heard over the abdominal aorta possible indicates stenosis or an aneurysm which should not be palpated or percussed. Therefore, the AP should wash the client's abdomen very gently.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: A client is having an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and has been given midazolam hydrochloride. The client's respiratory rate is 8 breaths/min. What action by the nurse is appropriate?
options: Administer naloxone.
Call the Rapid Response Team.
Provide physical stimulation.
Ventilate with a bag-valve-mask.
questions.rationale: For an EGD, Patients are given mild sedation but would still be able to follow commands. For shallow or slow respirations after the sedation is given, the nurse's most appropriate action is to provide a physical stimulation such as a sternal rub and directions to breathe deeply. Naloxone is not the antidote for midazolam HCl. The Rapid Response Team is not needed at this point. The client does not need manual ventilation.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: A client is scheduled for a colonoscopy and the nurse has provided instructions on the bowel cleansing regimen. What statement by the client indicates a need for further teaching?
options: "It's a good thing I love orange and cherry gelatin."
"My spouse will be here to drive me home."
"I'll avoid ibuprofen for several days before the test."
"I'll buy a case of clear Gatorade before the prep."
questions.rationale: The client would be advised to avoid beverages and gelatin that are red, orange, or purple in color as their residue can appear to be blood. The other statements show an understanding of the preparation for the procedure.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: A client had a colonoscopy and biopsy yesterday and calls the gastrointestinal clinic to report a spot of bright red blood on the toilet paper today. What response by the nurse is appropriate?
options: Ask the client to call back if this happens again today.
Instruct the client to go to the emergency department.
Remind the client that a small amount of bleeding is possible.
Tell the client to come to the clinic this afternoon.
questions.rationale: After a colonoscopy with biopsy, a small amount of bleeding is normal. The nurse would remind the client of this and instruct him or her to go to the emergency department for large amounts of bleeding, severe pain, or dizziness.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: An older adult has had an instance of drug toxicity and asks why this happens, since the client has been on this medication for years at the same dose. What response by the nurse is best?
options: "Changes in your liver cause drugs to be metabolized differently."
"Perhaps you don't need as high a dose of the drug as before."
"Stomach muscles atrophy with age and you digest more slowly."
"Your body probably can't tolerate as much medication anymore."
questions.rationale: Decreased liver enzyme activity depresses drug metabolism, which leads to accumulation of drugs—possibly to toxic levels. The other options do not accurately explain this age-related change.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: To promote comfort and the passage of flatus after a colonoscopy, in what position does the nurse place the client?
options: Left lateral
Prone
Right lateral
Supine
questions.rationale: After colonoscopy, Patients have less discomfort and quicker passage of flatus when placed in the left lateral position.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: A nurse is assessing a client reporting right upper quadrant (RUQ) abdominal pain. What technique would the nurse use to assess this client's abdomen?
options: Auscultate after palpating.
Avoid any type of palpation.
Lightly palpate the RUQ first.
Lightly palpate the RUQ last.
questions.rationale: If pain is present in a certain area of the abdomen, that area would be palpated last to keep the client from tensing which could possibly affect the rest of the examination. Auscultation of the abdomen occurs prior to palpation.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: The nurse knows that a client with prolonged prothrombin time (PT) values (not related to medication) probably has dysfunction in which organ?
options: Kidneys
Liver
Spleen
Stomach
questions.rationale: Severe acute or chronic liver damage leads to a prolonged PT secondary to impaired synthesis of clotting proteins. The other organs are not related to this issue.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: A client is recovering from an esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) and requests something to drink. What action by the nurse is appropriate?
options: Allow the client cool liquids only.
Assess the client's gag reflex.
Remind the client to remain NPO.
Tell the client to wait 4 hours.
questions.rationale: The local anesthetic used during this procedure depresses the client's gag reflex. After the procedure, the nurse would ensure that the gag reflex is intact before offering food or fluids. The client does not need to be restricted to cool beverages only and is not required to wait 4 hours before oral intake is allowed. Telling the client to remain NPO does not inform the client of when he or she can have fluids, nor does it reflect the client's readiness for them.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Assessment of the Gastrointestinal System
questions.stem: The assistive personnel note that a client had a dark stool. What stool test would the nurse obtain for this client?
options: Culture and sensitivity
Parasites and ova
Occult blood test
Total fat content
questions.rationale: Dark stools are typical in Patients who have lower GI bleeding. Therefore, an fecal occult blood test would be the most appropriate test as a follow-up.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Concepts of Care for Patients With Oral Cavity and Esophageal Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a client diagnosed with stomatitis about special mouth care. Which statement by the client indicates a need for further teaching?
options: I need to take out my dentures until my mouth heals.
I'll try to eat soft foods that aren't spicy and acidic.
I will use a more firm toothbrush to keep my mouth clean.
I'll be sure to rinse my mouth often with warm salt water.
questions.rationale: The client who has stomatitis has oral inflammation which causes discomfort. Therefore, all of these actions help to avoid irritation except for needing to use a soft toothbrush or gauze rather than a firm one. A firm toothbrush would increase irritation to the already inflamed oral tissues.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Concepts of Care for Patients With Oral Cavity and Esophageal Conditions
questions.stem: A client is admitted with a large oral tumor. What assessment by the nurse takes priority?
options: Airway
Breathing
Circulation
Nutrition
questions.rationale: Airway always takes priority. Airway must be assessed first and any problems managed if present. A large oral tumor can compromise the airway, making this the critical priority assessment.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Concepts of Care for Patients With Oral Cavity and Esophageal Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a client about the use of viscous lidocaine for oral pain. What health teaching would the nurse include?
options: Use the drug before every meal to prevent aspiration.
Increase your intake of citrus foods to help with healing.
Use the drug only at bedtime because you won't be eating.
Be sure to check food temperatures before eating.
questions.rationale: Viscous lidocaine has an anesthetic effect in the oral cavity. Therefore, to promote client safety, the nurse would want to teach the client to check food temperature before eating. The anesthetic effect means the client cannot feel heat, creating a burn risk.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Concepts of Care for Patients With Oral Cavity and Esophageal Conditions
questions.stem: A nurse participates in a community screening event for oral cancer. What client is the highest priority for referral to a primary health care provider?
options: Client who has poor oral hygiene practices.
Client who smokes and drinks daily.
Client who tans for an upcoming vacation.
Client who occasionally uses illicit drugs.
questions.rationale: Smoking and alcohol exposure create a high risk for this client. Poor oral hygiene is not related to the etiology of cancer but may cause a tumor to go unnoticed. Tanning is a risk factor, but short-term exposure does not have the same risk as daily exposure to tobacco and alcohol.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Concepts of Care for Patients With Oral Cavity and Esophageal Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse notes that the primary health care provider documented the presence of mucosal erythroplasia in a client. What does the nurse understand that this most likely means for this client?
options: Early sign of oral cancer
Fungal mouth infection
Inflammation of the gums
Obvious oral tumor
questions.rationale: Mucosal erythroplasia is the earliest sign of oral cancer. It is not a fungal infection, inflammation of the gums, or an obvious tumor. This finding represents a red, velvety patch in the oral cavity.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Concepts of Care for Patients With Oral Cavity and Esophageal Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a client diagnosed with oral cancer. What is the nurse's priority for client care?
options: Encourage fluids to liquefy the client's secretions.
Place the client on Aspiration Precautions.
Remind the client to use an incentive spirometer.
Manage the client's pain and inflammation.
questions.rationale: The client who has oral cancer often has difficulty swallowing and is at risk for aspiration and possibly aspiration pneumonia. Therefore, the most important nursing action is to place the client on precautions to prevent aspiration. The nurse would implement the other actions but they are not as vital to promote client safety.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Concepts of Care for Patients With Oral Cavity and Esophageal Conditions
questions.stem: A client has an open traditional hiatal hernia repair this morning. What is the nurse's priority for client care at this time?
options: Managing surgical pain
Ambulating the client early
Preventing respiratory complications
Managing the nasogastric tube
questions.rationale: The client who has traditional surgery (rather than minimally invasive surgery) is at risk for respiratory complications such as atelectasis and pneumonia because he or she has an incision that may prevent the client from taking deep breaths or using an incentive spirometer. Therefore, the nurse's priority is to prevent these potentially life-threatening respiratory problems.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Concepts of Care for Patients With Oral Cavity and Esophageal Conditions
questions.stem: Which of these client assessment findings is typically associated with oral cancer?
options: Dry sticky oral membranes
Increased appetite
Itchy rash in oral cavity
Painless red or raised lesion
questions.rationale: A painless red or raised lesion often indicates a diagnosis of oral cancer. The client usually has a decreased appetite and thick secretions. Itchiness is not a common finding associated with oral cancer.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a client who has been treated for acute gastritis. What statement by the client indicates a need for further teaching?
options: I need to cut down on drinking martinis every night.
I should decrease my intake of caffeinated drinks, especially coffee.
I will only take ibuprofen once in a while when I really need it.
I can continue smoking cigarettes which is better than chewing tobacco.
questions.rationale: To prevent another episode of acute gastritis, alcohol, caffeinated drinks, and NSAIDs should be avoided or kept at a minimum. Smoking and all forms of tobacco should also be avoided.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a client who has frequent gastric pain and dyspepsia. Which procedure would the nurse expect for the client to make an accurate diagnosis?
options: Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD)
Abdominal arteriogram
Nuclear medicine scan
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
questions.rationale: The gold standard for diagnosing disorders of the stomach is an EGD which allows direct visualization by the endoscopist into the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a client who has been diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease. For which complication would the nurse monitor?
options: Large bowel obstruction
Dyspepsia
Upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding
Gastric cancer
questions.rationale: Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) can cause gastric mucosal damage or perforation, which causes upper GI bleeding. Dyspepsia is a symptom of PUD, gastritis, and gastric cancer. PUD affects the stomach and/or duodenum, not the colon.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: A client who had a partial gastrectomy 3 days ago begins to experience vertigo, sweating, and tachycardia about 30 minutes after eating breakfast. What postoperative complication would the nurse suspect?
options: Pyloric obstruction
Dumping syndrome
Delayed gastric emptying
Pernicious anemia
questions.rationale: Dumping syndrome causes autonomic symptoms as food quickly leaves the stomach due to its decreased size after surgery.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: A client with peptic ulcer disease is in the emergency department and reports gastric pain that has gotten much worse over the last 24 hours. The client's blood pressure when lying down is 112/68 mm Hg and when standing is 98/52 mm Hg. What action by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: Administer a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).
Call the Rapid Response Team.
Start a large-bore IV with normal saline.
Tell the patient to remain lying down.
questions.rationale: This client has orthostatic changes to the blood pressure, indicating fluid volume loss. The nurse would start a large-bore IV with isotonic solution. PPIs are not a treatment for an ulcer. The Rapid Response Team is not needed at this point. The client should be put on safety precautions, which includes staying in bed, but this is not the most appropriate action at this time.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: During an interview, the client tells the nurse that the client has a duodenal ulcer. Which assessment finding would the nurse expect?
options: Hematemesis
Pain when eating
Melena
Weight loss
questions.rationale: All of the other assessment findings are more commonly seen in Patients who have gastric ulcers rather than duodenal ulcers.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: A client who has peptic ulcer disease is prescribed quadruple drug therapy for Helicobacter pylori infection. What health teaching related to bismuth would the nurse include?
options: Report stool changes to your primary health care provider immediately.
Do not take aspirin or aspirin products of any kind while on bismuth.
Take bismuth about 30 minutes before each meal and at bedtime.
Be aware that bismuth can cause frequent vomiting and diarrhea.
questions.rationale: Bismuth is a salicylate drug and causes stool discoloration but not vomiting and diarrhea. It does not have to be taken at a specific time relative to meals. Patients taking bismuth should not take other salicylates, such as aspirin or aspirin-containing products.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse caring for Patients with gastrointestinal disorders would recall that omeprazole is a drug in which classification?
options: Gastric acid inhibitor
Histamine receptor blocker
Mucosal barrier fortifier
Proton pump inhibitor
questions.rationale: Omeprazole is a proton pump inhibitor.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a client experiencing upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding. What is the priority action for the client's care?
options: Maintain airway, breathing, and circulation.
Monitor vital signs, including orthostatic blood pressures.
Draw blood for hemoglobin and hematocrit immediately.
Insert a nasogastric (NG) tube and connect to intermittent suction.
questions.rationale: The priority action for any client experiencing deterioration or an emergent situation is monitor and maintain airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs). Taking orthostatic blood pressures would not be appropriate, but the nurse would monitor vital signs carefully and draw blood for hemoglobin and hematocrit. An NG tube would also need to be inserted and connected to gastric suction to rest the GI tract. However, none of these actions take priority over maintaining ABCs.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: A client has a nasogastric (NG) tube as a result of an upper gastrointestinal (GI) hemorrhage. What comfort measure would the nurse remind assistive personnel (AP) to provide?
options: Lavaging the tube with ice water
Performing frequent oral care
Re-positioning the tube every 4 hours
Taking and recording vital signs
questions.rationale: Patients with NG tubes need frequent oral care both for comfort and to prevent infection. Lavaging the tube is done by the nurse. Repositioning the tube, if needed, is also done by the nurse. The can take vital signs, but this is not a comfort measure.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: A client has a recurrence of gastric cancer and is crying. What response by the nurse is most appropriate?
options: Do you have family or friends for support?
Would you tell me what you are feeling now.
Well, we knew this would probably happen.
Would you like me to refer you to hospice?
questions.rationale: The nurse assesses the client's emotional state with open-ended questions and statements and shows a willingness to listen to the client's concerns. Asking about support people is very limited in nature, and "yes-or-no" questions are not therapeutic. Stating that this was expected dismisses the client's concerns. The client may or may not be ready to hear about hospice, and this is another limited, yes-or-no question.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: A client has dumping syndrome after a partial gastrectomy. Which action by the nurse would be appropriate?
options: Arrange a dietary consult.
Increase fluid intake.
Limit the client's foods.
Make the client NPO.
questions.rationale: The client with dumping syndrome after a gastrectomy has multiple dietary needs. A referral to the registered dietitian nutritionist will be extremely helpful. Food and fluid intake is complicated and needs planning. The client should not be NPO.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse recalls that the risk factors for acute gastritis include which of the following? (Select all that apply.)
options: Alcohol
Caffeine
Corticosteroids
Fruit juice
Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs)
questions.rationale: Risk factors for acute gastritis include alcohol, caffeine, corticosteroids, and chronic NSAID use. Fruit juice is not a risk factor, although in some people it does cause distress.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a client with a long history of peptic ulcer disease. What assessment findings would the nurse anticipate if the client experiences upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding? (Select all that apply.)
options: Decreased heart rate
Decreased blood pressure
Bounding radial pulse
Dizziness
Hematemesis
Decreased urinary output
questions.rationale: The client who has upper GI bleeding would likely have vomiting that contains blood (hematemesis), and would have signs and symptoms of dehydration such as a decreased blood pressure, dizziness, and/or decreased urinary output. The heart rate increases rather than decreases and the pulse is weak rather than bounding in Patients who are dehydrated.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: Which of the following is (are) (a) risk factor(s) for gastric cancer? (Select all that apply.)
options: Achlorhydria
Chronic atrophic gastritis
H. pylori infection
Iron deficiency anemia
Pernicious anemia
questions.rationale: Achlorhydria, chronic atrophic gastritis, H. pylori infection, and pernicious anemia are all risk factors for developing gastric cancer. Iron deficiency anemia is not a risk factor.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: A client has dumping syndrome. What menu selections indicate the client understands the correct diet to manage this condition? (Select all that apply.)
options: Apricots
Coffee cake
Milk shake
Potato soup
Steamed broccoli
questions.rationale: Canned apricots and potato soup are appropriate selections as they are part of a high-protein, high-fat, and low- to moderate-carbohydrate diet. Coffee cake and other sweets must be avoided. Milk products and sweet drinks such as shakes must be avoided. Gas-forming foods such as broccoli must also be avoided.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse assesses a client who has possible gastritis. Which assessment finding(s) indicate(s) that the client has chronic gastritis? (Select all that apply.)
options: Anorexia
Dyspepsia
Intolerance of fatty foods
Pernicious anemia
Nausea and vomiting
questions.rationale: Intolerance of fatty or spicy foods and pernicious anemia are signs of chronic gastritis. Anorexia and nausea/vomiting can be seen in both conditions. Dyspepsia is seen in acute gastritis.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: What action(s) by the nurse is (are) appropriate to promote nutrition in a client who had a partial gastrectomy? (Select all that apply.)
options: Administer vitamin B12 injections.
Ask the primary health care provider about folic acid replacement.
Educate the client on enteral feedings.
Obtain consent for total parenteral nutrition.
Provide iron supplements for the client.
questions.rationale: After a partial or total gastrectomy, Patients are at high risk for anemia due to vitamin B12 deficiency, folic acid deficiency, or iron deficiency. The nurse would provide supplements for all these nutrients. The client does not need enteral feeding or total parenteral nutrition.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Concepts of Care for Patients With Stomach Conditions
questions.stem: A nurse is preparing to administer pantoprazole intravenously to prevent stress ulcers during surgery. What action(s) by the nurse is (are) most appropriate? (Select all that apply.)
options: Administer the drug through a separate IV line.
Infuse pantoprazole using an IV pump.
Keep the drug in its original brown container.
Take vital signs frequently during infusion.
Use an in-line IV filter when infusing.
questions.rationale: When infusing pantoprazole, use a separate IV line, a pump, and an in-line filter. A brown wrapper and frequent vital signs are not needed.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Concepts of Care for Patients With Noninflammatory Intestinal Conditions
questions.stem: After teaching a client with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), a nurse assesses the client's understanding. Which menu selection indicates that the client correctly understands the dietary teaching?
options: Ham sandwich on white bread, cup of applesauce, carbonated beverage
Broiled chicken with brown rice, steamed broccoli, glass of apple juice
Grilled cheese sandwich, small banana, cup of hot tea with lemon
Baked tilapia, fresh green beans, cup of coffee with low-fat milk
questions.rationale: Patients with IBS are advised to eat a high-fiber diet. Chicken with brown rice, broccoli, and apple juice has the highest fiber content. Patients should avoid alcohol, caffeine, and other gastric irritants.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Concepts of Care for Patients With Noninflammatory Intestinal Conditions
questions.stem: A nurse assesses a client who is prescribed alosetron. Which assessment question would the nurse ask this client before starting the drug?
options: Have you been experiencing any constipation?
Are you eating a diet high in fiber and fluids?
Do you have a history of high blood pressure?
What vitamins and supplements are you taking?
questions.rationale: Ischemic colitis is a life-threatening complication of alosetron. The nurse would assess the client for constipation because it places the client at risk for this complication. The other questions do not identify the risk for complications related to alosetron.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Concepts of Care for Patients With Noninflammatory Intestinal Conditions
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a client who is diagnosed with a complete small bowel obstruction. For what priority problem is this client most likely at risk?
options: Abdominal distention
Nausea
Electrolyte imbalance
Obstipation
questions.rationale: The client who has a small bowel obstruction is at the highest risk for fluid and electrolyte imbalances, especially dehydration and hypokalemia due to profuse vomiting.
