This drug does not control cravings, and it is taken once daily orally or as a monthly injection.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: When the nurse practices the “Six Rights” of medication administration, what does it ensure?
options: Adequate information is provided to the patient.
Cost-effective use of medications.
Informed consent for drug administration is obtained.
Safe administration of medications.
questions.rationale: The “Six Rights” ensure that the nurse has considered all of the details of safe medication administration. The “Six Rights” include verifying: (1) the right patient; (2) the right drug; (3) the right dose; (4) the right route; (5) the right time, and (6) the right documentation.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: In order to ensure that a medication is given to the right patient, the nurse must perform which action?
options: Ask the patient to spell their last name.
Match the patient with a photo ID.
Swipe a bar code on the patient's ID bracelet.
Verify the patient using two identifiers.
questions.rationale: The Joint Commission requires two forms of identification before medication administration. Patients are asked to state their name and date of birth. Some, but not all, institutions use photos and bar codes to aid in identification.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: A health care provider calls a nursing unit to leave a telephone order for an as needed (PRN) antipyretic medication for a child. The provider tells the nurse to “give PO acetaminophen for a fever greater than 101 F per protocol.” What will the nurse do next?
options: Ask the provider to verify how many mg per kg per dose and how frequently to give the medication.
Look up the protocol in the unit manual and write the drug order for the provider to sign.
Provide the child's weight to the hospital pharmacist to write the order based on the protocol.
Transcribe the verbal order to the order sheet as “give PO acetaminophen for a fever greater than 101 F per protocol.”
questions.rationale: The components of a drug order include drug name, dose, route, frequency, and any instructions for dosing. A nurse receiving a telephone order should “read back” the order from the provider that includes this information. The provider, and not the nurse or the pharmacist, is responsible for writing the order with all components.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The pediatric nurse reviews a hand-written medication order, which reads, “09/16/2021, acetaminophen 160 mg (5 mL) PO q4h for fever.” What will the nurse do next?
options: Administer the drug when indicated.
Ask the provider to confirm if the dose is correct for the patient's age.
Clarify the nursing assessments necessary for giving a dose.
Contact the provider to request patient allergy information.
questions.rationale: This order contains all components except the level of temperature necessary to justify a dose of an antipyretic. The patient's age and allergy information are part of the medical record data base.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a 20-kg child who is ordered to receive amoxicillin 400 mg per os (PO) TID for 10 days. The nurse reviews the drug information and notes that the correct dose of amoxicillin is 40 to 50 mg/kg/day in two to three divided doses. Which action by the nurse is correct?
options: Adjust the drug dose based on drug manufacturer dosing information.
Administer the medication as ordered.
Ask the pharmacist to double check that the dose is correct.
Contact the provider and ask whether the drug should be given twice daily (BID) instead of TID.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com The correct dosing range for this drug for this child per the drug information is 800 to 1000 mg per day. If 400 mg were administered TID, it would result in 1200 mg per day being administered. It would be appropriate to verify the order with the prescriber to ensure the appropriate dose is administered.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a medication from a unit-dose system. The nurse verifies that the medication, dose, and time are correct and that the expiration date was the day prior. Which action is correct?
options: Administer the medication and observe for adequate drug effects.
Notify the pharmacist and the provider of a medication error.
Return the medication to the pharmacy to be replaced.
Verify the right patient and administer the medication.
questions.rationale: If a drug expiration date has passed, it should be returned to the pharmacy or discarded, never used. A medication error would occur only if the medication was given.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a tablet to an elementary school-aged child. The child's parent reports always crushing the tablet and mixing it with pudding when giving it at home. What is the nurse's next action?
options: Ask the pharmacist if the drug may be crushed.
Crush the tablet and mix it with pudding.
Insist that the tablet must be chewed as ordered.
Request a liquid form of the medication from the pharmacy.
questions.rationale: Nurses should not crush or mix medications in other substances without consultation with a pharmacist or a reliable drug reference. Even if the family has been doing this at home, the nurse must still determine safety and efficacy. If the medication cannot be crushed or mixed into another substance, the nurse may need to insist on the child taking the dose as ordered or may need to ask the provider to prescribe a different form of the medication.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who will have surgery that morning. The patient usually takes an antihypertensive medication every morning. The patient has been nothing per os (NPO) since midnight. What action will the nurse perform?
options: Ask the patient to swallow the pill without water.
Give the medication with a small sip of water. www.NursingExamBank.com
Consult the surgeon about giving the medication.
Hold the medication until after the patient's surgery.
questions.rationale: The patient's provider or surgeon should determine the importance of giving the medication along with the safety of administering it prior to anesthesia. The nurse should not give the medication with or without water without the provider's permission.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has asthma. The provider has ordered an albuterol metered- dose inhaler (MDI), 2 puffs q4 to 6h PRN wheezing. The patient's last dose was 4 hours ago. What is the nurse's next action?
options: Administer 2 puffs of albuterol with the MDI.
Auscultate the patient's lung sounds.
Give the albuterol if the patient reports wheezing.
Give the medication and evaluate its effectiveness.
questions.rationale: The albuterol is to be given PRN if the patient is wheezing. The nurse should assess breath sounds and give the medication if the patient is wheezing. Even if the patient reports wheezing, the nurse should conduct and document an assessment.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The nurse assumes care of a patient who had surgery that morning. The provider has ordered hydrocodone (Lortab) every 4 hours for mild to moderate pain and morphine sulfate for moderate to severe pain. The nurse reviews the patient's record and notes the patient has received two doses of hydrocodone 4 hours apart for a pain level of 7 to 8 on a scale of 1 to 10 and has reported a decrease in pain to a level of 6 to 7 after 30 minutes. It has been 4 hours since the last dose, and the patient reports a pain level of 7. What will the nurse do?
options: Administer the hydrocodone.
Administer morphine.
Ask the patient which drug to give.
Notify the provider of the patient's current pain level.
questions.rationale: The previous nurse has documented a poor response to pain medication given for mild to moderate pain. The nurse should administer the medication ordered for moderate to severe pain. Hydrocodone has not been effective and should not be given. The nurse bases the drug selection on the patient's evaluation of pain, not on which drug the patient wants. The provider has written an order with nursing evaluations specified, so there is no need for the nurse to notify the provider.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who will begin taking a thiazide diuretic to treat hypertension. The patient says, “I know this will lower my blood pressure, but how does it work?” How will the nurse best respond?
options: “It can cause orthostatic hypotension, so be careful.”
“It reduces the volume of fluid in your blood stream to lower blood pressure.”
“The actions are complicated, but it's an effective drug.”
“Your provider should explain this medication to you.”
questions.rationale: Patients have a right to understand how the drugs they are taking work and to know about side effects. The nurse should explain how the medication can cause orthostatic hypotension after addressing the patient's current question. Telling the patient that the drug actions are complicated is disrespectful. Nurses are responsible for educating patients about medications.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: A patient who is diagnosed with atrial fibrillation is to begin taking warfarin (Coumadin). The patient refuses to take the medication because “it is rat poison.” After the nurse provides teaching, the patient still refuses. What action will the nurse take?
options: Hold the dose and document the patient's refusal.
Hold the dose, notify the provider of the situation, and document these actions.
Put the medication in the patient's food.
Tell the patient that the drug is necessary for treatment.
questions.rationale: Patients have a right to refuse medications, but the provider should be notified if omitting the medication can have serious effects. According to the principle of autonomy, it is unethical to put a medication in a patient's food without their knowledge.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: Which is a violation of a nurse's right when administering medications?
options: A hospital policy for off-label drug uses.
A medication preparation area at the unit secretary's desk.
A multiple-dose drug vial requiring the nurse to calculate and measure the dose.
A new drug ordered that the nurse must look up in a drug manual.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Nurses have a right to administer drugs safely and have the right to stop, think, and be vigilant when administering medications. Another worker's desk will be noisy, with many distractions. Many drugs are used for off-label purposes; having a hospital policy helps ensure safety. Single- dose vials are more convenient and help to reduce calculation errors, but multidose vials are often used; nurses unsure of calculations should check their work with another nurse. Nurses frequently have to look up information on new drugs, and hospitals should offer reasonable access to current information.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about a new medication that will be administered using an MDI. To evaluate the patient's understanding about how to use the device, what will the nurse do?
options: Ask the patient to give a return demonstration using the inhaler.
Give the patient written instructions to review as needed.
Offer the patient an internet web address with information about the product.
Provide information about drug effects and adverse reactions.
questions.rationale: The nurse should demonstrate skills and evaluate understanding with return demonstrations. Written instructions and internet sites are helpful but do not give information about patient understanding and how well the patient can perform a task.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The community health nurse is preparing to administer a medication to a patient in the patient's home. The order reads “amoxicillin as directed BID PO.” The nurse will perform which action?
options: Administer the medication as ordered on the prescription label.
Ask the patient to take the medication as ordered.
Contact the provider to confirm the correct dose and instructions for the medication.
Review the drug information to verify the correct dose.
questions.rationale: The home nurse must have a complete order for giving medications, including the name of the medication, dose, route, and frequency, so the nurse should contact the provider to ascertain the dose. The prescription label may be outdated if the provider has changed the regimen.

questions.category: Chapter 09: Safety and Quality
questions.stem: The school nurse happens to observe a child pulling a pill out of a backpack and preparing to take it. What action will the nurse take?
options: Ask the child to describe the medication, dose, and reason for taking it.
Ask the child to keep all pills in the nurse's office.
Call the child's provider for a telephone order to give the medication. www.NursingExamBank.com
Contact the child's parent to request a properly labeled prescription.
questions.rationale: Children should bring medications properly labeled to school and should not self-administer medications without supervision.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: The nurse is assisting the parent of a 6-month-old infant to administer an oral liquid medication. The parent asks why the medication can't be given in a bottle of formula to make it taste better. How will the nurse respond?
options: “Adding a medication to the formula will cause the formula to curdle.”
“Formula and medications can form toxic compounds if mixed together.”
“The infant may not always take the entire bottle of formula.”
“This may cause the infant to refuse formula in the future.”
questions.rationale: Medications should not be mixed with a large amount of food or beverage because patients may miss the full dose if they do not consume the entire amount. If the entire bottle is not consumed, the nurse will have difficulty determining how much dose was received. If medications interact with formula in vivo, package information will indicate this.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: A patient asks the nurse if an enteric-coated tablet can be crushed and put in pudding to make it easier to swallow. How will the nurse respond to the patient?
options: “Crushing the medication can possibly lead to administration of a toxic medication dose.”
“Crushing the medication is safe and can prevent gagging on pills.”
“The tablet may be crushed if a small amount of pudding is used.”
“The tablet may be dissolved in liquid but not crushed and put in food.”
questions.rationale: Enteric-coated tablets must be swallowed whole to maintain a therapeutic drug level since they are designed to be absorbed in the small intestine. If crushed, an initial excessive release of the drug may occur, potentially causing toxicity. Enteric-coated tablets should not be dissolved in liquid.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: A patient is ordered to take an extended-release medication twice daily but has difficulty swallowing the tablet because of its size. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Contact the provider to discuss an alternate form of the medication.
Crush the tablet and put it in applesauce to help the patient swallow it.
Cut the tablet in half so the patient can take it more easily.
Dissolve the tablet in liquid.
questions.rationale: Enteric-coated and extended-release tablets must be swallowed whole to maintain a therapeutic drug level since they are designed to be absorbed in the small intestine and/or gradually over time. If crushed, an initial excessive release of the drug may occur, causing toxicity. Enteric- coated or extended-release tablets should not be dissolved in liquid. The nurse should contact the provider to discuss another form of the medication.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about using sublingual nitroglycerin at home. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “I may put the tablet in food if I don't like the taste.”
“I may take a sip of water after placing the tablet in my mouth.”
“I will place the tablet between my cheek and gum.”
“I will place the tablet under my tongue and let it absorb.”
questions.rationale: Drugs given sublingually should be placed under the tongue. No foods or fluids should be given, since the tablet must remain under the tongue until it is fully absorbed. Medications ordered to be given “buccally” should be placed between the cheek and gum.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a nursing student about giving liquid medications. Which statement by the student indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “A suspension is a mixture in which drug particles are dissolved in solution.”
“I will line up the bottom of the medication curve with the line on the syringe.”
“I will need to shake an elixir before measuring the dose.”
“I will never need to refrigerate liquids once they are reconstituted.”
questions.rationale: To measure liquid medications accurately, line up the bottom of the curve (the meniscus) of the medication with the desired line on the syringe. Suspensions are liquids in which particles are mixed but not dissolved. As a general rule, elixirs do not require shaking; shaking may suspend air into the liquid and affect accurate dosing by volume. Many liquid medications require refrigeration. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: A patient asks the nurse why the provider has ordered a transdermal form of a medication. How will the nurse respond?
options: “The patch can always be cut when dosage adjustments are needed.”
“Drug levels fluctuate less with the patch.”
“There are fewer systemic side effects with transdermal patches.”
“There is less risk of toxicity when using a patch.”
questions.rationale: Transdermal patches provide more consistent blood levels. Cutting the patch is not recommended for some types of patches. Drugs given transdermally can still produce systemic side effects and toxicity.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: When administering topical medications, which is an important nursing action?
options: Applying the medication liberally.
Cleaning skin with alcohol before applying.
Using sterile technique.
Wearing gloves.
questions.rationale: To avoid contact with the medication, nurses should wear gloves when applying topical medications. Some topical medications are applied sparingly. Skin should be clean and dry, but it is not necessary to use alcohol. It is not always necessary to use sterile technique.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: A patient who has asthma will begin taking an inhaled corticosteroid medication to be used with a spacer. The patient asks why the spacer is necessary. The nurse will explain that the spacer
options: allows a larger dose to be given safely.
is used to enhance the delivery of medications when using a metered-dose inhaler.
minimizes adverse effects of the steroid.
prevents contamination of the metered-dose inhaler.
questions.rationale: Spacers are used to enhance the delivery of medication when using a metered-dose inhaler. They do not allow higher dosing or minimize drug side effects.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a parent to administer medications using a child's gastrostomy tube. The parent asks why it is necessary to give water after each medication. The nurse explains that the water is given for which purpose?
options: To decrease gastrointestinal upset
To dilute the medication and enhance absorption
To ensure that all medication is flushed into the stomach
To improve overall hydration
questions.rationale: Flushing the tube after the medication is instilled ensures that the medication reaches the stomach and to maintain patency of the tubing. It is not always given to decrease gastrointestinal upset, to dilute the medication, or to improve hydration.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a rectal suppository antipyretic medication. Which action by the nurse is correct?
options: Allowing the suppository to soften at room temperature before inserting
Avoid explaining the administration procedures to the patient so they don't decline the medication
Having the patient remain flat or on one side for at least 30 minutes after insertion
Using an oil-based lubricant such as petrolatum gel (Vaseline) to lubricate the medication
questions.rationale: Patients should remain flat or on one side for at least 30 minutes to prevent expulsion of the suppository. Softening the suppository is not indicated. The procedure should be explained to the patient before administration of the suppository. A water-soluble lubricant should be used.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: The nurse is performing tuberculin testing on a patient. Which action by the nurse is correct?
options: Insert the needle, bevel up, at a 45-degree angle.
Massage the area gently after the injection.
Measure the diameter of the area of erythema when reading the result.
Use a 25-gauge, 1/4" needle.
questions.rationale: Intradermal injections should be given with a 25- to 27-gauge, 1/4"- to 1/2"-long needle. The needle should be inserted at a 10- to 15-degree angle. The area should not be massaged. The nurse measures the area of induration, not erythema.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer an intramuscular injection to a 14-month-old toddler. To help with site selection for this injection, what will the nurse ask the child's parent?
options: “How long has your child been walking?”
“How much does your child weigh?”
“Is your child afraid to look at needles?”
“Is your child right- or left-handed?”
questions.rationale: The ventrogluteal muscle is the preferred injection site for toddlers who have gluteal muscle development associated with firmly established walking. The muscle development, and not the child's weight, is more important. For infants less than 12 months and toddlers not walking alone, the vastus lateralis is the preferred injection site. Asking if a patient is right- or left-handed is necessary if deltoid muscles are used.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: The nurse is demonstrating the Z-track injection technique to a nursing student on a patient who is receiving iron dextran. Which statement by the student indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “This is used when administering IM injections to help minimize local skin irritation.”
“This technique allows slower, more sustained absorption.”
“You may use the deltoid site when using this method.”
“I should use a 27-gauge needle to minimize discomfort with this method.”
questions.rationale: The Z-track method is used to help minimize local skin irritation by sealing the medication in the muscle tissue. It does not affect absorption. The ventrogluteal site is preferred, and, generally, the needle is a larger bore.

questions.category: Chapter 10: Drug Administration
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to start an IV line in a preschool-age child. After applying a mixture of local anesthetics, what will the nurse do to prepare the child?
options: Describe what the IV line will feel like and how long it will be in place.
Explain the purpose of the procedure.
Give the child equipment to handle and practice on a doll.
Reassure the child that the pain will only last a few minutes.
questions.rationale: Preschool children should be allowed to play with and handle equipment and give “play” injections using a doll or stuffed animal. Describing the procedure or discussing pain will only heighten anxiety. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: A patient's serum osmolality is 305 mOsm/kg. Which term describes this patient's body fluid osmolality?
options: Iso-osmolar
Hypo-osmolar
Hyper-osmolar
Isotonic
questions.rationale: Normal osmolality is 275 to 295 mOsm/kg. This patient is therefore hyper-osmolar.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: A patient is admitted after experiencing vomiting and diarrhea for several days. The provider orders intravenous lactated Ringer's solution. The nurse understands that this fluid is given for which purpose?
options: To increase interstitial and intracellular hydration
To maintain plasma volume over time
To pull water from the interstitial space into the extracellular fluid
To replace water and electrolytes
questions.rationale: Lactated Ringer's solution is an isotonic solution and is used to replace water and electrolytes and is often used to replace gastrointestinal fluid losses. Hypotonic fluids increase interstitial and intracellular hydration. Colloidal solutions are used to maintain plasma volume over time. Hypertonic solutions pull water from the interstitial space into the extracellular fluid.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: A patient is being treated for shock after a motor vehicle accident. The provider orders Dextran 75 to be given intravenously. The nurse should expect which outcome as the result of this infusion?
options: Decreased urine output
Improved blood oxygenation
Increased interstitial fluid
Stabilization of heart rate and blood pressure
questions.rationale: Dextran 75 is a high–molecular-weight colloidal solution and is used to treat shock from hemorrhage, burns, or trauma. Colloids are plasma expanders, and use results in an improvement in heart rate (decreased) and blood pressure (increased). Plasma expanders will result in an increase in urine output. Blood oxygenation is not affected, and colloids do not increase the amount of interstitial fluid.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who weighs 75 kg. The patient has intravenous (IV) fluids infusing at a rate of 50 mL/h and has consumed 100 mL of fluids orally in the past 24 hours. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Contact the provider to ask about increasing the IV rate to 100 mL/h.
Discuss with the provider the need to increase the IV rate to 200 mL/h.
Encourage the patient to drink more water so the IV can be discontinued.
Instruct the patient to drink 250 mL of water every 8 hours.
questions.rationale: The recommended daily fluid intake for adults is 2300 to 2900 mL/day. This patient is currently receiving 1200 mL IV plus 100 mL orally for a total of 1300 mL. Increasing the IV rate to 100 mL/h would give the patient 2400 mL. If the patient continues to take oral fluids at their current rate, the amount of 2500 mL can be met. A rate of 200 mL/h would give the patient 4800 mL/day IV, which exceeds the recommended amount. Since this patient is not taking fluids well orally and is not receiving adequate IV fluids, encouraging an increased oral fluid intake is not indicated. Even if the patient drank 250 mL of water every 8 hours, the amount would not be sufficient to meet the recommended daily fluid intake for adults.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has a heart rate of 98 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 82/58 mm Hg. The patient is lethargic, is complaining of muscle weakness, and has had gastroenteritis for several days. Based on this patient's vital signs and presentation, which sodium value would the nurse expect?
options: 126 mEq/L
140 mEq/L
145 mEq/L
158 mEq/L
questions.rationale: Patients who are hyponatremic will present with tachycardia and hypotension along with lethargy and muscle weakness. The normal range for serum sodium is 135 to 145 mEq/L; a serum sodium level of 126 mEq/L would be considered hyponatremic.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has had severe vomiting. The patient's serum sodium level is 130 mEq/L. The nurse will expect the patient's provider to order which treatment?
options: Diuretic therapy
Intravenous hypertonic 5% saline
Intravenous normal saline 0.9%
Oral sodium supplements www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Patients with hyponatremia may be treated with oral sodium supplements if the patient is able or if the deficit is mild. This patient is vomiting and would not be able to take supplements easily. For a serum sodium level between 125 and 135 mEq/L, normal saline may increase sodium content in vascular fluid. Hypertonic saline is used for severe hyponatremia with a serum sodium <120 mEq/L. Diuretics would further deplete sodium and fluid volume in a patient already likely to be dehydrated from severe vomiting.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a newly admitted patient who has severe gastroenteritis. The patient's electrolytes reveal a serum sodium level of 140 mEq/L and a serum potassium level of 3.5 mEq/L. The nurse receives an order for intravenous 5% dextrose and normal saline with 20 mEq/L potassium chloride to infuse at 125 mL/h. Which action is necessary prior to administering this fluid?
options: Evaluate the patient's urine output.
Contact the provider to order arterial blood gases.
Request an order for an initial potassium bolus.
Suggest a diet low in sodium and potassium.
questions.rationale: If the patient is receiving potassium and the urine output is <25 mL/h or <600 mL/d, potassium accumulation may occur. Patients with a low urine output should not receive IV potassium. Arterial blood gases are not necessary prior to IV potassium administration. Potassium should never be given as a bolus. Patients should be put on a potassium-enriched diet when foods are tolerated.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: A patient who is being treated for dehydration is receiving 5% dextrose and 0.45% normal saline with 20 mEq/L potassium chloride at a rate of 125 mL/h. The nurse assuming care for the patient reviews the patient's serum electrolytes and notes a serum sodium level of 140 mEq/L and a serum potassium level of 3.6 mEq/L. The patient had a urine output of 250 mL during the last 12-hour shift. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Contact the patient's provider to discuss increasing the potassium chloride to 40 mEq/L.
Continue the intravenous fluids as ordered and reassess the patient frequently.
Notify the provider and discuss increasing the rate of fluids to 200 mL/h.
Stop the intravenous fluids and notify the provider of the assessment findings.
questions.rationale: The patient's potassium level is within normal limits, but the urine output is decreased, so the patient should not be receiving IV potassium. The nurse should stop the IV and report the findings to the provider. The patient does not need potassium supplementation at this time. The patient needs more fluids but not with potassium. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: A patient has a serum potassium level of 2.7 mEq/L. The patient's provider has determined that the patient will need 200 mEq of potassium to replace serum losses. How will the nurse caring for this patient expect to administer the potassium?
options: As a single-dose 200 mEq oral tablet
As an intravenous bolus over 15 to 20 minutes
In an intravenous solution at a maximum rate of 10 mEq/h
In an intravenous solution at a rate of 45 mEq/h
questions.rationale: Potassium chloride should be given intravenously when hypokalemia is severe, so this patient should receive IV potassium chloride. Potassium should never be given as a bolus and should be administered slowly. The infusion rate for potassium is generally not recommended any faster than 10 mEq/h.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: A patient is taking a loop diuretic and reports anorexia and fatigue. The nurse suspects which electrolyte imbalance in this patient?
options: Hypercalcemia
Hypocalcemia
Hyperkalemia
Hypokalemia
questions.rationale: Loop diuretics cause the body to lose potassium. Patients who take loop and thiazide diuretics should be monitored for hypokalemia.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient whose serum sodium level is 140 mEq/L and serum potassium level is 5.4 mEq/L. The nurse will contact the patient's provider to discuss an order for
options: a low-potassium diet.
intravenous sodium bicarbonate.
sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate).
salt substitutes.
questions.rationale: Mild hyperkalemia (5.4-5.6 mEq/L) may be treated with dietary restriction of potassium-rich foods. The patient's sodium level is normal, so sodium bicarbonate is not indicated. Sodium polystyrene sulfonate is used for severe hyperkalemia. Salt substitutes contain potassium and would exacerbate the hyperkalemia. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The provider has ordered sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate) to be administered to a patient. The nurse caring for this patient would expect which serum electrolyte values prior to administration of this therapy?
options: Sodium 125 mEq/L and potassium 2.5 mEq/L
Sodium 150 mEq/L and potassium 3.6 mEq/L
Sodium 135 mEq/L and potassium 6.9 mEq/L
Sodium 148 mEq/L and potassium 5.5 mEq/L
questions.rationale: Severe hyperkalemia, with a potassium level of 6.9 mEq/L, requires aggressive treatment to increase the body's excretion of potassium. Sodium polystyrene sulfonate is a potassium binder used to treat severe hyperkalemia. The normal range for serum potassium is 3.5 to 5.5 mEq/L, so use of a potassium binder would not be indicated for the serum electrolyte values presented in options A, B or D.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving oral potassium chloride supplements. The nurse notes that the patient has a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. The patient reports abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and facial paresthesia. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Contact the provider to request an order for serum electrolytes.
Encourage the patient to consume less fluids.
Report symptoms of hyperchloremia to the provider.
Request an order to increase the patient's potassium dose.
questions.rationale: Tachycardia, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, and facial paresthesia are signs of hyperkalemia, so the nurse should request an order for serum electrolytes. This patient should increase fluid intake. The patient is not exhibiting signs of hyperchloremia; the patient is showing signs of hyperkalemia, and an increased potassium dose is not indicated.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: A patient asks the nurse about taking calcium supplements to avoid hypocalcemia. The nurse will suggest that the patient follow which instruction?
options: Take a calcium and vitamin D combination supplement.
Take calcium along with phosphorus to improve absorption.
Take calcium with antacids to reduce stomach upset.
Use aspirin instead of acetaminophen when taking calcium.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Vitamin D enhances the absorption of calcium in the body. Calcium and phosphorus have an inverse relationship—an increased level of one mineral decreases the level of the other, and they would bind in the gastrointestinal tract and not be absorbed if taken at the same time. Antacids can contain magnesium, which can promote calcium loss. Aspirin can alter vitamin D levels and interfere with calcium absorption.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a newly admitted patient who will receive digoxin to treat a cardiac dysrhythmia. The patient takes hydrochlorothiazide (HydroDIURIL) and reports regular use of over-the-counter laxatives. Before administering the first dose of digoxin, the nurse will review the patient's electrolytes with careful attention to the levels of which electrolytes?
options: Calcium and magnesium
Sodium and calcium
Potassium and chloride
Potassium and magnesium
questions.rationale: Hypomagnesemia, like hypokalemia, enhances the action of digitalis and causes digitalis toxicity. Laxatives and diuretics can deplete both of these electrolytes.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is administering intravenous fluids to a patient who is dehydrated. On the second day of care, the patient's weight is increased by 2.25 pounds. The nurse would expect that the patient's fluid intake has
options: equaled urine output.
exceeded urine output by 1 L.
exceeded urine output by 2.5 L.
exceeded urine output by 3 L.
questions.rationale: A weight gain of 1 kg, or 2.2 to 2.5 lb, is equivalent to 1 L of fluid.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving isotonic intravenous (IV) fluids at an infusion rate of 125 mL/h. The nurse performs an assessment and notes a heart rate of 102 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 160/85 mm Hg, and crackles auscultated in both lungs. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Decrease the IV fluid rate and notify the provider.
Increase the IV fluid rate and notify the provider.
Request an order for a colloidal IV solution.
Request an order for a hypertonic IV solution. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: The patient shows signs of fluid volume excess, so the nurse should slow the IV fluid rate and notify the provider. Increasing the rate would compound the problem. Colloidal and hypertonic fluids would pull more fluids into the intravascular space and compound the problem.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer digoxin to a patient who is newly admitted to the intensive care unit. The nurse reviews the patient's admission electrolytes and notes a serum potassium level of 2.9 mEq/L. Which action by the nurse is correct?
options: Administer the digoxin and monitor the patient's electrocardiogram closely.
Hold the digoxin dose and notify the provider of the patient's lab values.
Request an order for an intravenous bolus of potassium.
Request an order for oral potassium supplements.
questions.rationale: Hypokalemia increases the risk for digoxin toxicity, so the nurse should hold the dose and notify the provider. Potassium should never be given as an IV bolus. Oral supplements are not used when hypokalemia is severe.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is performing an assessment on a patient brought to the emergency department for treatment for dehydration. The nurse assesses a respiratory rate of 26 breaths/minute, a heart rate of 110 beats/minute, a blood pressure of 86/50 mm Hg, and a temperature of 39.5 C. The patient becomes dizzy when transferred from the wheelchair to a bed. The nurse notes cool, clammy skin. Which diagnosis does the nurse suspect?
options: Fluid volume deficit (FVD)
Fluid volume excess (FVE)
Mild extracellular fluid (ECF) deficit
Renal failure
questions.rationale: Patients with FVD will exhibit elevated temperature, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, orthostatic hypotension, and cool, clammy skin. Patients with FVE will have bounding pulses, elevated blood pressure, dyspnea, and crackles. Mild ECF deficit causes thirst. Renal failure generally leads to FVE.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who will receive 10% calcium gluconate to treat a serum potassium level of 5.9 mEq/L. The nurse performs a drug history prior to beginning the infusion. Which drug taken by the patient would cause concern? www.NursingExamBank.com
options: Digitalis
Hydrochlorothiazide
Hydrocortisone
Vitamin D
questions.rationale: Calcium gluconate is given to treat hyperkalemia in order to decrease irritability of the myocardium. When administered to a patient taking digitalis, it can cause digitalis toxicity. The other drugs may affect potassium levels but are not a cause for concern with calcium gluconate.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: A patient is admitted with orthopnea, cough, pulmonary crackles, and peripheral edema. The patient's urine specific gravity is 1.002. The nurse will expect this patient's provider to order which treatment?
options: Diuretics
Colloidal IV fluids
Hypertonic IV fluids
Hypotonic IV fluids
questions.rationale: This patient has signs of fluid volume excess (FVE). Urine specific gravity levels less than 1.010 g/mL indicate dilute urine and excess fluid. Diuretics are prescribed to reduce fluid overload.

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who will receive intravenous calcium gluconate. Which nursing actions are appropriate when giving this solution? (Select all that apply.)
options: Administering through a central line
Review the patients medication record to see if they are receiving digitalis
Giving as a rapid intravenous bolus
Mixing in a solution containing sodium bicarbonate e. Monitoring the patient's electrocardiogram (ECG) f. Reporting a serum calcium level of >2.5 mEq/L
questions.rationale: , E, F Calcium gluconate has the same action on the heart as digitalis and combined use can place the patient at risk for digitalis toxicity. Hypercalcemia can cause ECG changes. A serum calcium level greater than 2.5 mEq/L indicates hypercalcemia and therefore should be reported. Calcium does not require infusion through a central line and should not be given as a rapid IV bolus. Calcium should not be added to a solution containing bicarbonate, because rapid precipitation occurs. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 12: Fluid Volume and Electrolytes
questions.stem: A patient is suspected of having severe hypocalcemia. While waiting for the patient's serum electrolyte results, the nurse will assess for which symptoms? (Select all that apply.)
options: Laryngeal spasms
Fatigue
Muscle weakness
Nausea and vomiting e. Hyperactive deep tendon reflexes f. Twitching of the mouth
questions.rationale: , E, F Patients who have hypocalcemia will exhibit laryngeal spasms, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes, and twitching of the mouth. The other symptoms are not characteristic of hypocalcemia.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A patient asks the nurse about whether it is necessary to take vitamin supplements. The patient is a 26-year-old female who is contemplating pregnancy. The nurse will recommend which supplement?
options: Calcium and vitamin D
Folic acid (folate)
Iron www.NursingExamBank.com
Vitamin C
questions.rationale: Folic acid deficiency during the first trimester of pregnancy can affect the development of the central nervous system (CNS) of the fetus, so women of childbearing age are encouraged to take folic acid. Other supplements are not necessary with a well-balanced diet unless a deficiency is noted.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A patient reports wanting to take vitamin A to prevent blindness. Which response by the nurse is correct?
options: “Vitamin A can be taken at any dose without serious adverse effects.”
“Vitamin A has no effects on vision.”
“Vitamin A is difficult to obtain through dietary intake alone.”
“If too much vitamin A is taken toxicity can occur.”
questions.rationale: Vitamin A is stored in the liver for up to 2 years, and toxicity can occur if hypervitaminosis A occurs. The effects of toxicity can be severe. Vitamin A is essential for the maintenance of eye function. Vitamin A can be obtained through the diet.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A young woman tells the nurse that she has a strong family history of osteoporosis and that she has been taking calcium supplements. Which vitamin will the nurse recommend as an adjunct to calcium supplementation to ensure calcium absorption?
options: Vitamin A
Vitamin D
Vitamin E
Vitamin K
questions.rationale: Vitamin D is needed for calcium absorption from the intestines and plays a major role in regulating calcium and phosphorus metabolism.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A patient who spends most of the time indoors has been taking large doses of vitamin D and is curious about signs of vitamin D toxicity. The nurse will tell this patient to report which sign that may indicate vitamin D toxicity?
options: Blurred vision
Darkening of the skin www.NursingExamBank.com
Nausea and vomiting
Palpitations
questions.rationale: Anorexia, nausea, and vomiting are early signs of vitamin D toxicity.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: Which fat-soluble vitamin can increase the risk of bleeding and would warrant close monitoring of prothrombin time in a patient also taking warfarin (Coumadin)?
options: Vitamin A
Vitamin D
Vitamin E
Vitamin K
questions.rationale: Vitamin E may prolong the prothrombin time, so patients taking warfarin should have their PT monitored closely. Vitamin K is used as an antidote in the event of oral anticoagulant overdose.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A child is brought to the emergency department after ingesting a grandparent's warfarin (Coumadin) tablets. The nurse will anticipate administering which form of vitamin K?
options: K1 (phytonadione)
K2 (menaquinone)
K3 (menadione)
K4 (menadiol)
questions.rationale: For oral anticoagulant overdose, vitamin K1 is the only vitamin K form available for therapeutic use and is most effective in preventing hemorrhage.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about water-soluble vitamins. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “Water-soluble vitamins are excreted in the urine.”
“Water-soluble vitamins are highly toxic if I take too much.”
“Water-soluble vitamins are highly protein bound.”
“Water-soluble vitamins are usually metabolized in the liver.”
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Water-soluble vitamins are not highly stored in the body as they are readily excreted in the urine. Because they are not stored, they are usually not toxic unless taken in extremely excessive amounts. They are not highly protein bound and are not generally metabolized in the liver.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has a history of chronic alcohol abuse. The patient is confused and exhibits nystagmus and blurred vision. Which vitamin will the nurse expect to administer to this patient?
options: Nicotinic acid
Pyridoxine
Riboflavin
Thiamine
questions.rationale: Alcoholics can develop Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome characterized by these symptoms related to thiamine deficiency. Thiamine must be given quickly to prevent progression of the disease which can result in irreversible brain damage.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for an elderly patient who has poor nutrition. The nurse notes cracked skin at the corners of the patient's mouth along with generalized scaly dermatitis. The nurse will contact the provider to discuss a possible deficiency of which vitamin?
options: Nicotinic acid
Pyridoxine
Riboflavin
Thiamine
questions.rationale: Riboflavin deficiency is characterized by scaly dermatitis, cracked corners of the mouth, and inflammation of the mouth and tongue.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A patient is taking nicotinic acid (Niacin) to treat hyperlipidemia. The patient reports a flushing sensation along with gastrointestinal irritation. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Contact the provider to discuss possible thromboembolism.
Discuss decreasing the patient's dose of nicotinic acid with the provider.
Reassure the patient that these effects will decrease over time.
Suggest that the patient take niacin with a full glass of cool water.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Large doses of niacin can cause gastrointestinal irritation and vasodilation, resulting in a flushing sensation. Decreasing the dose can alleviate these symptoms. They do not indicate development of thromboembolism. Taking niacin with a full glass of water does not alleviate these symptoms.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A patient reports having taken a large dose of ascorbic acid (vitamin C) and is experiencing diarrhea and gastrointestinal upset. The nurse will prepare to take which action?
options: Administer activated charcoal.
Administer sodium bicarbonate.
Perform gastric lavage.
Provide symptomatic care.
questions.rationale: The patient is experiencing uncomfortable side effects of excess vitamin C intake, but they are not life threatening, so no antidotes or treatment are indicated.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A patient reports taking large doses of vitamin C to prevent upper respiratory infections. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Monitor the patient for hyperglycemia.
Notify the provider and discuss a gradual taper of vitamin C.
Request an order for a CBC to assess the patient's hemoglobin.
Tell the patient that studies have confirmed the benefit of high dose vitamin C for this indication.
questions.rationale: Patients who take large doses of vitamin C should be tapered down gradually to avoid vitamin deficiency. Vitamin C can produce a false positive urine glucose test but does not affect blood glucose. It does not affect hemoglobin. Studies have not demonstrated the effectiveness of vitamin C in preventing or treating colds.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who has a folic acid deficiency about treatment for this disorder. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “Food sources of folic acid are better absorbed than synthetic folic acid products.”
“I should take large doses of folic acid to compensate for the deficiency.”
“Most folic acid I take is stored in the liver.”
“Symptoms of folic acid deficiency often do not appear for months.”
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Symptoms of folic acid deficiency usually are not noted until 2 to 4 months after folic acid storage is depleted. Synthetic folate is more stable and has greater bioavailability when compared with dietary folate. Large doses are not recommended. One-third of folic acid is stored in the liver with the rest stored in tissues.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A patient is diagnosed with anemia and asks the nurse why the provider has ordered vitamin B12. Which answer by the nurse is correct?
options: “Vitamin B12 is given to improve your overall energy level.”
“Vitamin B12 is necessary for the development of red blood cells.”
“Vitamin B12 prevents excess iron loss.”
“Vitamin B12 will help you absorb iron more efficiently.”
questions.rationale: Vitamin B12 is essential for DNA synthesis and aids in the conversion of folic acid to its active form and is also needed for the development of red blood cells. It does not directly improve energy level and does not affect iron loss or iron absorption.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who has iron-deficiency anemia about iron supplementation. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “I may improve iron absorption by taking this with vitamin C.”
“I should take iron tablets with an antacid to reduce gastrointestinal upset.”
“Nausea and vomiting are minor side effects and will decrease over time.”
“Taking iron with food will help to increase the amount absorbed.”
questions.rationale: Vitamin C or orange juice, which is high in vitamin C, increases the absorption of iron in the stomach. Antacids interfere with iron absorption. Nausea and vomiting should be reported since they are signs of toxicity. Food slows absorption but is sometimes recommended to reduce gastrointestinal upset.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A female patient has a history of heavy menstrual periods and has received treatment in the past for iron deficiency anemia. She would like to take ferrous sulfate prophylactically to avoid future problems. Which of the following is an appropriate patient teaching point to provide the patient?
options: Maintain an upright position for 30 minutes after taking the iron.
Take the iron with milk to improve absorption.
Iron supplements have a tendency of causing diarrhea.
Iron supplements should never be taken with food. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Patients should be advised to maintain an upright position for 30 minutes after taking oral iron preparations to prevent esophageal corrosion from reflux. Taking iron supplements with milk will decrease iron absorption and should not be recommended. Iron supplements can often contribute to constipation. While taking iron supplements with food will result in suboptimal absorption, patients can take them with food if gastrointestinal irritation prevents them from taking the supplements on an empty stomach.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A parent calls the nurse to report that a 5-year-old child has taken five children's vitamins. Which action will the nurse take first?
options: Ask whether the vitamins contain iron.
Reassure the parent that all over-the-counter vitamins are not toxic.
Recommend that the parent take the child to the emergency department (ED).
Tell the parent to watch for tarry stools and report them immediately.
questions.rationale: Iron toxicity is a serious cause of poisoning in children, and as few as 10 to 12 tablets of ferrous sulfate can be fatal within 12 to 48 hours. The nurse should first determine whether the vitamins contain iron. If so, the family should take the child to the ED.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a child who receives all nutrition parenterally. The nurse will be alert for signs of deficiency for which mineral in this child?
options: Chromium
Copper
Iron
Zinc
questions.rationale: Patients on long-term parenteral nutrition are at risk for zinc deficiency.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A patient who has type 2 diabetes mellitus asks the nurse about taking chromium supplements. The nurse will tell this patient that taking chromium
options: can increase the risk for ketoacidosis.
is not recommended for persons with diabetes.
has only been proven to improve conditions associated with chromium deficiency.
should be taken in doses greater than 200 mcg/day. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Chromium has only been shown to improve conditions associated with a documented chromium deficiency. Chromium may help with blood glucose management and can be used in people with diabetes. It does not increase the risk for ketoacidosis. The normal dose is 25 to 35 mcg/day.

questions.category: Chapter 13: Vitamin and Mineral Replacement
questions.stem: A patient who will begin taking an antibiotic reports taking several vitamin supplements every day. Which vitamin or mineral will the nurse counsel the patient about during antibiotic therapy?
options: Selenium
Vitamin A
Vitamin C
Zinc
questions.rationale: Zinc can interfere with antibiotic absorption and should be taken at least 2 hours after taking the antibiotic.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer enteral nutrition to a patient. Which assessment finding would prompt the nurse to hold the nutrition and notify the patient's provider?
options: Blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg
Decreased bowel sounds
A productive cough
A temperature of 37.8 C
questions.rationale: Enteral nutrition requires adequate small bowel function with digestion, absorption, and gastrointestinal motility. The nurse should assess for abdominal distension and a decrease or absence of bowel sounds. Patients may still receive enteral feedings if hypotension, cough, or elevated temperature are present.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer an enteral feeding to a patient who receives 300 mL of a polymeric formula over 30 minutes every 4 hours. The nurse checks the residual prior to initiating the feeding and notes a residual amount of 50 mL of formula. Which action will the nurse take next?
options: Administer the feeding as ordered.
Administer the feeding over 60 minutes.
Hold the feeding and notify the patient's provider.
Wait 1 hour and recheck the residual again.
questions.rationale: The nurse should determine gastric residual before each feeding when patients are receiving intermittent feedings. A residual greater than 150 mL may indicate the patient has an obstruction and is not digesting the feeding. This patient has a residual of 50 mL, so the nurse may proceed with the next feeding. Usually, if the residual was greater than 150 mL (the nurse should verify this value with the agency policy), the feeding should be held and the residual checked again in 1 hour. If it is still elevated on the second check the provider should be contacted. The nurse cannot change the rate of an enteral infusion without an order from the provider.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The provider calculates the enteral nutrition needs for a non-ambulatory patient and determines that the patient will need 300 mL of a polymeric formula every 4 hours. Which method of delivery will the nurse use to administer these feedings?
options: 300 mL every 4 hours given via syringe as a 10-minute bolus
300 mL every 4 hours given via enteral pump as a 45-minute infusion
75 mL per hour via enteral pump as a continuous infusion
150 mL every 2 hours via gravity infusion
questions.rationale: Intermittent enteral feedings are an inexpensive and safe method of administering enteral nutrition and may be used when patients are non-ambulatory. Three hundred to 400 mL of solution may be given and should infuse over 30 to 60 minutes. While bolus methods may be used for patients receiving 250 to 400 mL of solution, this method is not tolerated well by non- ambulatory patients and may cause nausea, vomiting, aspiration, abdominal cramping, and diarrhea. Continuous feedings are used for critically ill patients. Gravity feedings cannot be well controlled and may infuse too fast or too slow.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing a patient who will receive intermittent enteral nutrition at home with a hyperosmolar solution. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient?
options: How to perform the Valsalva maneuver
The need to consume extra fluids between feedings
The need to decrease dietary fiber www.NursingExamBank.com
The need to remain supine during infusion of the enteral solution
questions.rationale: Dehydration can occur if patients do not receive enough water during or between feedings with hyperosmolar solutions, so patients should be taught to consume extra water. The Valsalva maneuver is taught to patients who receive TPN to prevent embolus. Enteral feedings can cause diarrhea, so decreased fiber may aggravate that.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: Which of the following types of gastrointestinal tubes used for enteral feedings delivers food directly to the stomach?
options: Nasogastric
Nasoduodenal
Jejunostomy
Nasojejunal
questions.rationale: Nasogastric tubes deliver food directly to the stomach. Nasojejunal and jejunostomy tubes deliver nutrients to the jejunum. Nasoduodenal tubes deliver food directly to the duodenum.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse dilutes an antibiotic before administering it through a patient's nasogastric tube. The patient asks why this is necessary. The nurse explains that diluting the antibiotic helps to
options: improve absorption.
improve hydration.
prevent diarrhea.
prevent emboli.
questions.rationale: Liquid medication must be properly diluted when given through a feeding tube because most liquid medications are hyperosmolar and can cause abdominal distention, cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea. Diluting the liquid medication does not necessarily change absorption, improve overall hydration, or prevent embolus formation.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The nurse will carefully monitor this patient for which symptom(s)?
options: Coughing and shortness of breath
Decreased breath sounds
Diarrhea www.NursingExamBank.com
Nausea and abdominal distension
questions.rationale: TPN with IV therapy poses a risk for air embolism. Symptoms of air embolism are coughing and dyspnea. Decreased breath sounds occur with aspiration, which is a complication of nasogastric feedings. Diarrhea, nausea, and abdominal distension occur with nasogastric feedings.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to hang a new bag for a patient who is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN). During this procedure, the nurse will instruct the patient to take a deep breath and then perform which action?
options: Exhale slowly and bear down.
Exhale slowly to the count of 10.
Hold the breath and bear down.
Take several rapid, shallow breaths.
questions.rationale: The Valsalva maneuver is performed by taking a breath, holding it, and bearing down. Patients are instructed to perform this maneuver in order to help prevent the formation of air emboli during dressing, cap, and tubing changes.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: Which patient is most likely to be a candidate for total parenteral nutrition (TPN) rather than enteral nutrition?
options: A patient who is comatose after having had a stroke
A patient who has a fractured mandible following a motor vehicle accident
A patient who has cerebral palsy and severe dysphagia
A patient who is pregnant and has intractable hyperemesis gravidarum
questions.rationale: The patient who is vomiting will be unable to tolerate enteral nutrition. Enteral feedings require a functioning gastrointestinal tract. TPN is more costly and does not carry significant benefits when compared with risks, so it should only be used when enteral nutrition cannot be used.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer enteral nutrition to a patient who has had a stroke and who cannot swallow. A family member asks why the patient is not receiving intravenous nutrition. What information will the nurse provide to the family member?
options: Parenteral nutrition carries a higher risk of infection.
Parenteral nutrition does not provide sufficient calories.
Parenteral nutrition increases the risk of aspiration. www.NursingExamBank.com
Parenteral nutrition is hyperosmolar and increases the risk of dehydration.
questions.rationale: Total parenteral nutrition (TPN) carries a greater risk of sepsis than enteral nutrition. TPN can provide sufficient calories, and there is no increased risk of aspiration with TPN. TPN does not increase the risk of dehydration.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: A patient who has been receiving continuous enteral nutrition has had several large, watery stools. The nurse will contact the provider to discuss which intervention?
options: Administering antidiarrheal medications
Slowing the rate of infusion
Starting total parenteral nutrition
Thickening the nutrition solution
questions.rationale: A common cause of diarrhea during enteral feeding is rapid feed infusion. Slowing the feeding is the appropriate initial action. Antidiarrheal medications are not indicated unless slowing the infusion fails. Total parenteral nutrition is not indicated for patients with a functioning gastrointestinal tract. Thickening the solution will increase the solute load and increase the risk for diarrhea.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: A patient who has been receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) for several days accidently removes the intravenous (IV) line. While waiting for the IV therapy nurse, the nurse caring for this patient will monitor for which complication?
options: Air embolism
Dehydration
Hypoglycemia
Infection
questions.rationale: Sudden interruption of TPN therapy can lead to hypoglycemia because of the sudden drop in glucose and the patient's continued increased insulin levels. Air embolism is a complication associated with changing TPN bags. Dehydration is not a complication of a sudden interruption of TPN. Infection is an ongoing concern, but the risk does not increase with a sudden interruption of TPN.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to discontinue total parenteral nutrition (TPN) therapy for a patient who has been receiving TPN for several days. The nurse will contact the provider to discuss an order for
options: antibiotics.
intravenous insulin.
intravenous dextrose.
nasogastric feedings.
questions.rationale: Abruptly discontinuing TPN can lead to hypoglycemia. Patients should receive dextrose solution for 12 to 24 hours after TPN is discontinued to prevent this reaction. Antibiotics are used when signs of infection are observed. Intravenous insulin would compound hypoglycemia. Nasogastric feedings are indicated if the patient needs continued feeding therapy and has an intact GI tract.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient with severe burns who will begin receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The patient asks why TPN is necessary. The nurse explains that TPN is used for which reason?
options: To minimize pulmonary complications
To prevent hyperglycemia and fluid overload
To promote wound healing and maintain cell integrity
To restore fluid and electrolyte imbalance
questions.rationale: TPN is indicated for patients with severe burns. TPN enhances wound healing and provides the nutrients necessary to prevent cellular catabolism. While some pulmonary complications, such as aspiration pneumonia, do not occur with TPN, there is a risk of air embolism. Hyperglycemia and fluid overload may occur.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a non-obese, non-critically ill adult who weighs 60 kg and is scheduled to begin receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN). Prior to initiating TPN therapy, the nurse reviews the orders. What would be an appropriate energy intake for this patient?
options: 1,800 cal/day
300 cal/day
3,600 cal/day
5,000 cal/day
questions.rationale: The recommended energy intake is 25 to 35 cal/kg/day in a nonobese patient. Because this patient weighs 60 kg, a recommended energy intake would be between 1,500 to 2,100 cal/day. Adjustments to the TPN solution may be made based on patient-specific considerations. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The patient reports nausea, headache, and thirst. The nurse will contact the provider to discuss which of the following?
options: Giving acetaminophen for headache pain
Obtaining a blood glucose level
Ordering an antiemetic to prevent vomiting
Starting intravenous dextrose
questions.rationale: This patient shows signs of hyperglycemia, which is a common adverse effect of TPN. The nurse should request an order for blood glucose testing. Symptoms should not be treated without first determining the underlying cause. Dextrose is given to prevent and/or treat hypoglycemia, but the patients blood glucose should be determined first.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is being treated with total parenteral nutrition (TPN). The patient is experiencing chest pain, and the nurse observes shortness of breath and coughing along with cyanosis. The nurse understands that this patient may be experiencing which condition?
options: Air embolism
Pneumonia
Pneumothorax
Pulmonary edema
questions.rationale: Patients receiving TPN are at risk for air embolism and will report chest pain and be dyspneic with coughing and cyanosis. Patients with pneumonia will have cough and abnormal breath sounds. Patients with pneumothorax will have unilateral absent breath sounds and respiratory distress. Patients with pulmonary edema will have crackles and dyspnea.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: A patient receiving total parenteral nutrition (TPN) begins having cough and dyspnea. The nurse auscultates rales and notes neck vein engorgement and weight gain. The nurse suspects that the patient is experiencing which condition?
options: Air embolism
Fluid overload
Pneumonia
Pneumothorax
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com This patient shows signs of fluid overload, characterized by pulmonary edema with cough and dyspnea, neck vein engorgement, and weight gain.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: The nurse assumes care for a patient and is preparing to administer an enteral feeding. The nurse finds the patient supine and asleep. The nurse will perform which action prior to initiating the feeding?
options: Elevate the head of the bed 30 degrees.
Replace the enteral feeding tube.
Position the patient to the left side.
Temporarily discontinue the infusion.
questions.rationale: When administering an enteral feeding, the nurse should elevate the head of the patient's bed 30 degrees.

questions.category: Chapter 14: Nutritional Support
questions.stem: Patients with which conditions would particularly benefit from enteral feedings? (Select all that apply.)
options: Burns of face, chest, and neck
Cerebral palsy with severe dysphagia
Crohn disease
Facial fractures e. Gluten enteropathy f. Stroke
questions.rationale: , D, F Patients with an intact, normally functioning gastrointestinal tract will benefit from enteral nutrition. Patients with extensive burns will need total parenteral nutrition (TPN) to prevent negative nitrogen balance. Patients with Crohn disease and gluten enteropathy have malabsorption problems and may need TPN.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has asthma and administers a selective beta 2-adrenergic agonist (albuterol) to treat bronchospasm. The nurse knows this drug can potentially cause which side effect?
options: Increased drowsiness
Decrease blood pressure
Increased heart rate
Increased gastrointestinal (GI) motility
questions.rationale: Selective beta2 agonists preferentially act on beta2 receptors, but can potentially contribute to side effects associated with beta1 receptor activation, including increased heart rate (tachycardia). Beta2 agonists can also be associated with side effects of hypertension and tachycardia. Adrenergic agonists cause decreased GI motility and are not generally associated with drowsiness.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A patient who has asthma requires treatment with a beta blocker to manage his cardiovascular disease. The nurse understands that which drug will be the safest to give this patient?
options: Pindolol (Visken)
Metoprolol (Lopressor)
Nadolol (Corgard)
Propranolol (Inderal)
questions.rationale: Metoprolol is a cardioselective beta-adrenergic blocker that has a greater affinity for receptors that decrease heart rate and blood pressure and is less likely to cause bronchospasm. The other beta-adrenergic blockers are not selective and have a greater risk for causing bronchoconstriction.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse administers epinephrine to a patient who is experiencing an anaphylactic reaction. The nurse should expect which of the following?
options: Bradycardia
Decreased urine output
Hypotension
Nausea and vomiting
questions.rationale: Epinephrine can cause renal vasoconstriction and thereby reduce renal perfusion and decrease urinary output. Epinephrine causes tachycardia and elevates blood pressure. Nausea and vomiting are not expected to occur.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: An adult patient is brought to the emergency department for treatment of an asthma exacerbation. The patient uses inhaled albuterol as needed to control wheezing. The nurse notes expiratory wheezing, tremors, restlessness, and a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. The nurse suspects that the patient has
options: overused the albuterol.
not been using albuterol.
taken a beta-adrenergic blocker.
taken a monoamine oxidase (MAO) inhibitor.
questions.rationale: High doses of albuterol may affect beta1 receptors, causing an increase in heart rate. Patients having an asthma exacerbation may overuse their albuterol inhalers when seeking relief. Patients may have wheezing and increased heart rate during an untreated asthma exacerbation, but they will not have tremors and restlessness.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving intravenous dopamine (Intropin). The nurse notes erythema and swelling at the IV insertion site. What is the nurse's initial action?
options: Apply warm soaks to the area.
Monitor the patient closely for hypertension.
Obtain an order for an electrocardiogram.
Notify the provider of a need for phentolamine mesylate (Regitine).
questions.rationale: Extravasation of dopamine causes tissue necrosis; if extravasation occurs, the antidote phentolamine mesylate should be infiltrated into the area.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient how to use phenylephrine HCl (Neo-Synephrine) nasal spray to treat congestion from a viral upper respiratory infection. What instruction will the nurse give the patient?
options: Use this product for a maximum of 3 days.
Spray the medication into the nose while lying supine.
Use frequently since systemic side effects do not occur.
Use the medication prophylactically to prevent future nasal congestion during cold season.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Nurses should explain to patients that continuous use of nasal sprays containing adrenergic agonists may result in rebound nasal congestion; these sprays should not be used more than 3 days. To avoid systemic absorption, spray should be administered while the patient is in an upright position. Because phenylephrine overuse can result in rebound nasal congestion, it should not be used prophylactically.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who will begin taking atenolol (Tenormin) as add-on therapy for the treatment of hypertension. What information will the nurse include when teaching the patient about taking this medication?
options: The drug must be taken twice daily.
The patient should rise slowly from a chair or bed.
The medication is safe to take during pregnancy.
Use NSAIDs instead of acetaminophen for mild to moderate pain.
questions.rationale: The side effects commonly associated with beta blockers include bradycardia, hypotension, and dizziness. Patients should be instructed to use caution when rising from a sitting or lying position to avoid orthostatic hypotension. Atenolol may be taken once daily. Atenolol should be used with caution in the pregnant patient. NSAIDs can increase blood pressure and should be avoided if possible in patients with uncontrolled hypertension.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has recently begun taking atenolol (Tenormin) as add-on therapy to treat hypertension. The patient reports dizziness, nausea, vomiting, and decreased libido since beginning the medication. What will the nurse do?
options: Hold the next dose until the provider can be notified of these side effects.
Reassure the patient that these symptoms are common and not worrisome.
Recommend that the patient discuss these effects with the provider.
Suggest that the patient request a different beta-adrenergic blocker.
questions.rationale: Beta-adrenergic blockers can cause these side effects, which are often dose related. Patients experiencing these side effects should be encouraged to discuss them with their provider. Beta blockers should not be discontinued abruptly, or rebound symptoms may occur. Since symptoms may be dose related, reassuring the patient is not correct. All beta blockers have similar side effects.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A patient will begin taking an albuterol (Proventil) inhaler to treat asthma. The patient has no other chronic medical conditions. When teaching the patient about this drug, the nurse will make which recommendation?
options: Report rapid or irregular heart rate.
Drink 8 to 16 extra ounces of fluid each day.
Monitor serum glucose daily.
Take a calcium supplement.
questions.rationale: High dosages of albuterol may activate beta1 receptors, causing an increase in heart rate. It is not necessary to consume extra fluids or take a calcium supplement while using this drug. Serum glucose may be elevated slightly, but this is generally not a concern in patients without diabetes.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A patient is taking doxazosin mesylate (Cardura) 1 mg/day to treat hypertension. The nurse notes a blood pressure of 110/72 mm Hg and a heart rate of 92 beats per minute. The nurse will contact the provider to discuss which change to the drug regimen?
