options: Changing to an alternative medication class to treat hypertension
Decreasing the doxazosin dose
Increasing the doxazosin dose
Adding a diuretic
questions.rationale: Alpha-adrenergic blockers can cause orthostatic hypotension and reflex tachycardia. Changing to an alternative medication class to treat hypertension would be appropriate to avoid hypotensive events. Decreasing or increasing the drug dose is not recommended. Diuretics are added if blood pressure is not well controlled.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A patient who has Raynaud's disease will begin taking an alpha-adrenergic blocker. The patient asks the nurse how the drug works to treat symptoms. The nurse explains that alpha-adrenergic blockers treat Raynaud's disease by causing
options: decreased peripheral vascular resistance.
orthostatic hypotension.
reflex tachycardia.
vasodilation.
questions.rationale: Peripheral alpha-adrenergic blockers can be used to treat peripheral vascular disorders like Raynaud's disease because they cause vasodilation.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A patient will be discharged home on a beta blocker. Which skill is essential for the nurse to teach the patient's family?
options: How to prepare a high-potassium diet
Assessments to detect fluid retention
How to monitor heart rate and blood pressure
Early signs of changing level of consciousness
questions.rationale: Because of the action and side effects of beta blockers, heart rate and blood pressure should be monitored frequently.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: Reserpine would be best categorized as which of the following?
options: Adrenergic neuron antagonist
Alpha blocker
Beta blocker
Alpha agonist
questions.rationale: Drugs that block therelease of norepinephrine from thesympathetic terminal neurons are often called adrenergic neuron antagonists (adrenergic neuron blockers). theclinical use is to decrease blood pressure. For example, reserpine is an antihypertensive agent that closely resembles alpha- and beta-adrenergic blockers; it also reduces theserotonin and catecholamine transmitters, depletion of which may lead to severe mental depression.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A patient has been started on a treatment regimen that includes atenolol (Tenormin) and complains to thenurse of feeling weak and fatigued. Which is thebest response from thenurse?
options: “I will hold your next dose of themedication.”
“You may need an increase in your next dose of themedication.”
“This is an adverse reaction to themedication. I will stop thedrug.”
“This is a side effect of themedication. I will notify your physician.”
questions.rationale: Weakness and fatigue can be a side effect of atenolol. Beta blockers should not be stopped abruptly, thus it would be appropriate to notify thepatient that these symptoms could be due to themedication and that thephysician will be notified.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The patient has been ordered to receive pseudoephedrine (Sudafed) to treat nasal congestion. thenurse performing an admission assessment learns that thepatient has diabetes mellitus. What action is appropriate for thenurse to take?
options: Administer themedication as ordered.
Contact theprovider to discuss a lower dose.
Give themedication and monitor serum glucose closely.
Hold themedication and contact theprovider.
questions.rationale: Sympathomimetic drugs should be used with caution in patients with diabetes. thenurse should verify theorder with theprovider before administration.

questions.category: Chapter 15: Adrenergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse caring for a patient who is taking a non-specific adrenergic agonist will expect which of thefollowing side effects? (Select all that apply.)
options: Dilated pupils
Increased heart rate
Increase gastrointestinal motility
Vasodilation e. Bronchospasm
questions.rationale: , B Adrenergic agonists stimulate thesympathetic nervous system, evoking the“fight or flight” response. This response increases those functions needed to respond to stress (increased heart rate to perfuse muscles, bronchodilation to increase oxygen exchange). Adrenergic drugs shunt blood away from thegastrointestinal tract, as digestion is not critical during a fight or flight response.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a drug and learns that it is an indirect-acting cholinergic agonist. thenurse understands that this drug
options: acts on muscarinic receptors.
acts on nicotinic receptors.
inhibits cholinesterase.
inhibits cholinergic receptors. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Agents that inhibit cholinesterase, which is theenzyme that breaks down acetylcholine, indirectly enhance theactions of acetylcholine.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A nursing student asks why a direct-acting cholinergic agonist drug that is selective to muscarinic receptors is described as being non-specific. thenurse will explain that this is because
options: muscarinic receptors are present in many different tissues.
the action of cholinesterase alters thebioavailability at different sites.
these drugs can also affect nicotinic receptors.
they vary in their reversible and irreversible effects.
questions.rationale: Although drugs classified as direct-acting cholinergic agonists are primarily selective for muscarinic receptors, some are considered non-specific because muscarinic receptors are located in different sites, causing actions in various organs. They are not affected differently by cholinesterase activity and have negligible actions on nicotinic receptors.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer bethanechol (Urecholine) to a patient who is experiencing urinary retention. thenurse notes that thepatient has a blood pressure of 90/60 mm Hg. thenurse will perform which action?
options: Administer thedrug and monitor urine output.
Administer themedication and monitor vital signs frequently.
Give themedication and notify theprovider of theincreased heart rate.
Hold themedication and notify theprovider of thedecreased blood pressure.
questions.rationale: Bethanechol treatment can result in hypotension. thenurse should hold thedrug and notify theprovider of thelow blood pressure.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse administers bethanechol (Urecholine) to a patient to treat urinary retention. After 30 minutes, thepatient voids 800 mL of urine and reports having a loose stool but no cramping or gastrointestinal pain. thepatient's blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. thenurse will perform which action?
options: Notify theprovider of bethanechol adverse effects.
Record theurine output and theblood pressure and continue to monitor.
Request an order for intravenous atropine sulfate.
Suggest another dose of bethanechol to theprovider. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: The patient is exhibiting desired effects and mild side effects of bethanechol, so thenurse should record information and continue to monitor thepatient. There is no need to notify theprovider, give an antidote, or repeat thedose.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who will begin taking bethanechol (Urecholine). Which statement by thepatient indicates a need for further teaching?
options: “Excessive sweating is a normal reaction to this medication.”
“Excess salivation is a serious side effect.”
“I should get out of bed slowly while taking this drug.”
“I will not take thedrug if my heart rate is less than 60 beats per minute.”
questions.rationale: Patients taking bethanechol should be instructed to report increased salivation and diaphoresis since they can be early signs of overdosing. They should also be taught to rise slowly to avoid orthostatic hypotension and to hold thedrug if their heart rate is low.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a male patient with myasthenia gravis who will begin taking neostigmine. When performing a health history, thenurse will be concerned and further investigate thehistory of which condition in this patient?
options: Benign prostatic hypertrophy
Chronic constipation
Erectile dysfunction
Upper respiratory infection
questions.rationale: This drug is a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor and is given to increase muscle strength. Cholinesterase inhibitors are contraindicated in patients with urinary tract obstruction. theseverity of thebenign prostatic hypertrophy would need to be investigated prior to administration.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer theanticholinergic medication benztropine (Cogentin) to a patient who has Parkinson disease. thenurse understands that this drug is used primarily for which purpose?
options: To decrease drooling and excessive salivation
To improve mobility and muscle strength
To prevent urinary retention www.NursingExamBank.com
To suppress tremors and lessen muscle rigidity
questions.rationale: Anticholinergic drugs are used in Parkinson disease mainly to reduce tremors and muscle rigidity.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a postoperative patient and notes that thepatient received atropine sulfate preoperatively. Which assessment finding would prompt thenurse to notify theprovider?
options: Absent bowel sounds
Drowsiness
Dry mouth
Heart rate of 78 beats per minute
questions.rationale: These are all potential side effects of atropine. Absent bowel sounds can indicate a paralytic ileus and should be evaluated immediately. theother side effects are not imminently harmful but should be continued to be monitored.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A patient who has irritable bowel syndrome would most likely receive which type of drug to treat this condition?
options: An anticholinergic
A cholinergic esterase inhibitor
A muscarinic agent
A nicotinic agent
questions.rationale: Anticholinergic drugs are used to treat peptic ulcers and intestinal spasticity because of their actions to decrease gastric secretions and gastrointestinal spasms. theother options listed would activate theGI tract and potentially worsen thepatient's symptoms.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about theuse of an anticholinergic medication. What information will thenurse include when teaching this patient about this medication?
options: “Check your heart rate frequently to monitor for bradycardia.”
“Drink extra fluids while you are taking this medication.”
“Rise from a chair slowly to avoid dizziness when taking this drug.”
“Use gum or lozenges to decrease dry mouth caused by this drug.”
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Anticholinergic medications cause dry mouth, so patients should be advised to use gum or lozenges to counter this side effect. Anticholinergics cause increased heart rate and increased blood pressure. Anticholinergics can cause urinary retention so patients should not necessarily increase fluid intake.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: Which cholinesterase inhibitor would be prescribed for a patient who has Alzheimer disease?
options: Ambenonium chloride (Mytelase)
Benztropine (Cogentin)
Donepezil HCl (Aricept)
Neostigmine methylsulfate (Prostigmin)
questions.rationale: Donepezil is used to treat Alzheimer disease. Ambenonium and neostigmine are used to treat myasthenia gravis. Benztropine is used to treat Parkinson disease.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who is going on a cruise about theuse of transdermal scopolamine. What information will thenurse include when teaching this patient?
options: “Apply thepatch as needed for nausea and vomiting.”
“Apply thepatch to your upper arm.”
“Change thepatch every 3 days.”
“Restrict fluids while using this patch.”
questions.rationale: The transdermal scopolamine patch is designed to last for 72 hours. thepatient should be taught to change it every 3 days. It works best when worn at all times and not just for symptomatic relief. thepatch should be applied behind theear. Patients should not restrict fluids.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer benztropine (Cogentin) to a patient who has Parkinson disease. When performing an assessment, which aspect of thepatient's history would cause thenurse to hold themedication and notify theprovider?
options: Asthma
Glaucoma
Irritable bowel syndrome
Motion sickness
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Patients who have glaucoma should not take anticholinergic medications as they can increase intraocular pressure.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient in thepost-anesthesia recovery unit. thenurse notes that thepatient received atropine sulfate 2 mg 30 minutes prior to anesthesia induction. thepatient has received 1000 mL of intravenous fluids and has 700 mL of urine in theurinary catheter bag. thepatient reports having a dry mouth. thenurse notes a heart rate of 82 beats per minute. What action will thenurse perform?
options: Administer a fluid bolus.
Give thepatient ice chips.
Palpate thepatient's bladder.
Reassess thepatient in 15 minutes.
questions.rationale: Atropine can cause urinary retention. thepatient's urine output is less than thefluid intake, so thenurse should palpate thebladder to assess for distension. Dry mouth is an expected side effect and does not necessarily indicate dehydration in a patient who has been administered atropine.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A patient who has Parkinson disease is scheduled to begin treatment with benztropine (Cogentin). thepresence of which of thefollowing would trigger thenurse to contact thephysician to discuss theappropriateness of this agent?
options: Drooling
Muscle rigidity
Muscle weakness
Myasthenia gravis
questions.rationale: Benztropine should be used with caution in patients with myasthenia gravis. Anticholinergic agents can exacerbate myasthenia gravis symptoms.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: A patient who is intubated develops sinus bradycardia. Which medication will thenurse anticipate administering to treat this symptom?
options: Atropine sulfate (Atropine)
Benztropine (Cogentin)
Bethanechol chloride (Urecholine)
Metoclopramide (Reglan) www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Atropine is most commonly used to decrease salivation and respiratory secretions preoperatively and to treat sinus bradycardia by increasing theheart rate.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer tolterodine tartrate (Detrol LA) to a patient who has incontinence. Which symptom would warrant holding administration of thedrug?
options: Absent bowel sounds
Drooling
Gastric upset
Pain
questions.rationale: Absent bowel sounds could signal gastric paresis and/or thebeginning of paralytic ileus. Detrol is contraindicated in patients with gastric paresis.

questions.category: Chapter 16: Cholinergic Agonists and Antagonists
questions.stem: Cholinergic drugs have specific effects on thebody. Which of thefollowing are actions of cholinergic medications? (Select all that apply.)
options: Dilate pupils
Decrease heart rate
Stimulate gastric muscle
Dilate blood vessels e. Dilate bronchioles f. Increase salivation g. Constrict pupils
questions.rationale: , C, D, F, G Decreasing heart rate, stimulating gastric muscles, dilating blood vessels, increasing salivation, and constricting pupils are actions of thecholinergic drugs.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: The nurse is performing a medication history on a patient who plans to begin using phentermine HCl. thenurse knows which of thefollowing to be true about use of phentermine?
options: It is used short-term for thetreatment of obesity.
Use of phentermine can result in tachycardia.
Phentermine is a controlled substance.
All of theabove.
questions.rationale: Phentermine is indicated for short-term use to treat obesity. Phentermine is a controlled substance (schedule IV), and patients can experience tachycardia with use.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a 7-year-old child who has difficulty concentrating and completing tasks and who cannot seem to sit still. Which diagnostic test may be ordered to assist with a diagnosis of attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) in this child?
options: Computerized tomography (CT) of thehead
Electrocardiogram (ECG)
Electroencephalogram (EEG)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of thebrain
questions.rationale: A child with ADHD may have abnormal EEG findings. CT, MRI, and ECG tests are not diagnostic for ADHD.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: A patient has been using methylphenidate to treat ADHD for several weeks. thepatient is having difficulty sleeping and takes themedication twice daily before breakfast and dinner. thenurse will explain to thepatient that methylphenidate
options: can cause insomnia and recommend taking themedication before breakfast and lunch.
does not often cause insomnia.
can cause insomnia and recommend a medication to help with sleep.
usually causes drowsiness.
questions.rationale: Amphetamines such as methylphenidate are CNS stimulants and can contribute to insomnia. For patients taking methylphenidate twice daily, it is recommended to take themedication 30-45 minutes before breakfast and lunch. Recommending a shift in administration time would be thebest first option before staring a medication for insomnia.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a child and a parent about taking methylphenidate to treat attention- deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Which statement by theparent indicates understanding of theteaching?
options: “I should give this drug to my child at bedtime.”
“My child should avoid products containing caffeine.”
“The drug should be stopped immediately if my child develops aggression.”
“We should monitor my child's weight since weight gain is common.”
questions.rationale: Methylphenidate is a stimulant, so other stimulants such as caffeine should be avoided. themedication should be taken in themorning. Patients should be taught not to stop thedrug abruptly to avoid withdrawal symptoms. Weight loss is common.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: The parent of a child who is taking amphetamine to treat attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) asks theprovider to recommend an over-the-counter medication to treat a cold. What will thenurse tell theparent?
options: “Avoid any products containing pseudoephedrine or caffeine.”
“Never give over-the-counter medications with amphetamine.”
“Sudafed (pseudoephedrine) is a safe and effective decongestant for my child.”
“Use any over-the-counter medication from thelocal pharmacy.”
questions.rationale: Amphetamine is a stimulant, so other stimulants, such as caffeine and pseudoephedrine, should be avoided to avoid additive stimulation.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: The nurse is checking an 8-year-old child who has attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) into a clinic for an annual well-child visit. thechild takes methylphenidate HCl. Which assessments are especially important for this child?
options: Respiratory rate and oxygen saturation
Height, weight, and blood pressure
Measures of fine- and gross-motor development
Blood glucose
questions.rationale: Methylphenidate may cause growth suppression, so thechild's height and weight should be assessed. Methylphenidate may also increase blood pressure, so thenurse should pay careful attention to changes in blood pressure.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: The parent of an adolescent who has taken methylphenidate 20 mg/day for 6 months for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) brings thechild to clinic for evaluation of a recent onset of nausea, vomiting, and headaches. theparent expresses concern that thechild seems less focused and more hyperactive than before. What will thenurse do next?
options: Ask thechild whether thedrug is being taken as prescribed.
Contact theprovider to discuss increasing thedose to 30 mg/day.
Recommend taking thedrug with meals to reduce gastrointestinal side effects.
Report signs of drug toxicity to thepatient's provider.
questions.rationale: Nausea, vomiting, and headaches can occur with drug withdrawal, along with a recurrence of symptoms. thenurse should ask thechild about how they are taking themedication. Methylphenidate should be taken 30 to 45 minutes before meals, not with meals.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a parent about methylphenidate to treat attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD). Which statement by theparent indicates understanding of theteaching?
options: “I should consult a pharmacist when giving my child OTC medications.”
“I will only give my child diet soft drinks while administering this medication.”
“Medication therapy means that behavioral therapy will not be necessary.”
“Weight gain is a common side effect of this medication.”
questions.rationale: Since many OTC medications contain stimulants, parents should consult a pharmacist or theprovider before giving them in combination with methylphenidate. Diet soft drinks often contain caffeine, a stimulant, and should be avoided with methylphenidate use. Behavioral therapy remains an essential part of thetreatment for ADHD. Weight loss is common.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: The parent of an obese 10-year-old child asks thenurse about medications to aid in weight loss. Which response by thenurse is correct?
options: “Anorexiants are often used to ‘jump start' a weight loss regimen in children.”
“Children are able to use over-the-counter anorexiants on a long-term basis.”
“Children under 12 years of age should not use weight loss drugs.”
“Side effects of anorexiants occur less often in children.”
questions.rationale: Anorexiants should not be given to children under age 12 years.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: The nurse is working in a neonatal intensive care unit and is caring for an infant who is experiencing multiple periods of apnea and bradycardia. Which of thefollowing drugs could be used to treat neonatal apnea?
options: Albuterol
Caffeine citrate
Doxapram
Methylphenidate
questions.rationale: Caffeine citrate is indicated for use in newborns with respiratory distress. theother drugs listed are not used for this purpose.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: A college-age student is brought to theemergency department by friends after consuming caffeine tablets along with several cups of coffee and a few energy drinks. thepatient is complaining of nausea and diarrhea and appears restless. thenurse understands that
options: arrhythmias and convulsions may occur.
psychological dependence to caffeine does not occur.
effects of thecaffeine will wear off shortly due to its 1-hour half-life.
severe adverse effects do not occur.
questions.rationale: Caffeine and other stimulants can cause cardiac arrhythmias and seizures. Psychological dependence to caffeine may occur. thehalf-life of caffeine is approximately 4 hours.

questions.category: Chapter 17: Stimulants
questions.stem: A patient reports difficulty staying awake during thedaytime despite getting adequate sleep every night and is diagnosed with narcolepsy. Which medication will thenurse expect theprovider to order for this patient?
options: Caffeine
Albuterol
Modafinil
Theophylline
questions.rationale: Modafinil is given to treat narcolepsy.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: A patient describes having vivid dreams to thenurse. thenurse understands that these occur during which stage of sleep?
options: Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep
Stage 2 non rapid eye movement sleep
Stage 3 non rapid eye movement sleep
Stage 4 non rapid eye movement sleep
questions.rationale: Vivid dreams occur during REM sleep.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: Children who experience nightmares have these during which stage of sleep?
options: Early morning sleep
Non rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep
Rapid eye movement (REM) sleep
Sleep induction
questions.rationale: Nightmares that occur in children take place during NREM sleep.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: A patient reports difficulty falling asleep most nights and is constantly fatigued. thepatient does not want to take medications to help with sleep. What non-pharmacologic measure will thenurse recommend?
options: “Exercise in theevening to promote bedtime fatigue.”
“Get out of bed at thesame time each morning.”
“Have a glass of wine at bedtime to help you relax.”
“Take daytime naps to minimize daytime fatigue.”
questions.rationale: To promote sleep, patients should be advised to arise at a specific time each morning to establish a routine. Patients should avoid strenuous exercise before bedtime. Patients should not consume alcohol 6 hours before bedtime. Patients should avoid taking daytime naps.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who reports being able to fall asleep but has difficulty staying asleep. theprovider has written for a barbiturate to help with her sleep. thenurse knows that which of thefollowing agents is an intermediate-acting barbiturate that would be most useful for sustaining sleep? www.NursingExamBank.com
options: Butabarbital
Pentobarbital
Secobarbital
Temazepam
questions.rationale: Butabarbital is an intermediate-acting barbiturate and may be useful in some situations as a sleep sustainer to maintain long periods of sleep. It has an onset of 1 hour, so it is not useful for those who have trouble falling asleep. Pentobarbital and secobarbital are used for preoperative sedation. Temazepam is a benzodiazepine.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who will begin taking alprazolam. What information will thenurse include when teaching this patient?
options: “Avoid alcohol while taking this drug.”
“You don't have to worry about drug interactions with this medication.”
“Unlike other anxiety medications this medication is not a scheduled substance.”
“Consuming grapefruit juice decreases alprazolam levels.”
questions.rationale: Patients who are taking benzodiazepines should avoid alcohol. Alprazolam can interact with many medications and so drug interaction screening should be performed. Alprazolam is a controlled substance (CSS: IV), and consumption of grapefruit juice can increase alprazolam levels.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for an older adult patient who is receiving a first dose of flurazepam as a sedative-hypnotic medication. What intervention will be included in thenurse's plan of care for this patient?
options: Instituting a bed alarm system to prevent falls
Reassuring thepatient that nightmares are not a usual effect
Reporting a urine output greater than 1500 mL/day
Teaching thepatient that this drug may be used for 6 to 8 weeks
questions.rationale: The nurse should use a bed alarm for older patients and younger patients receiving a hypnotic for thefirst time. Patients may experience vivid dreams and nightmares. Urine output should be greater than 1500 mL/day, so this does not warrant reporting. This drug should be used short term.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: An older adult has difficulty falling asleep. thenurse understands that which sedative hypnotic is most appropriate for this patient?
options: Butabarbital
Flurazepam
Secobarbital
Temazepam
questions.rationale: Short- to intermediate-acting benzodiazepines such as temazepam are recommended for older adults and are considered safer than barbiturates and long-acting benzodiazepines.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: A patient asks thenurse about taking over-the-counter sleeping aids. thenurse will tell thepatient that theactive ingredient in these products is often a(n)
options: antiemetic.
antihistamine.
barbiturate.
benzodiazepine.
questions.rationale: The primary ingredient in OTC sleep aids is typically an antihistamine such as diphenhydramine, not barbiturates or benzodiazepines. Melatonin can also be purchased as an over-the-counter product.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: Which of thefollowing agents is classified as a melatonin receptor agonist?
options: Temazepam
Zolpidem
Butabarbital
Ramelteon
questions.rationale: Ramelteon is a sedative-hypnotic agent and is classified as a melatonin agonist. This is thefirst prescription hypnotic agent approved by theFDA that is not classified as a controlled substance.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: A patient who has been taking zolpidem (Ambien) for several weeks reports being drowsy and having difficulty performing tasks at work most mornings. thenurse suspects that which drug effects have occurred? www.NursingExamBank.com
options: Substance use disorder
Hangover
Tolerance
Withdrawal
questions.rationale: While less common than with barbiturates or benzodiazepines, nonbenzodiazepine hypnotics like zolpidem can also contribute to hangover (residual sedation) effects. Excess sedation would not be an indication of substance use disorder with zolpidem. Tolerance refers to a reduced drug effect requiring larger amounts of drug to get thedesired effect. Withdrawal occurs when stopping thedrug causes symptoms that can only be alleviated by taking thedrug.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: The nurse is providing teaching for a patient who will begin taking zolpidem tartrate (Ambien) 10 mg at bedtime as a sleep aid. Which statement by thepatient indicates understanding of theteaching?
options: “I should take this medication with food to avoid stomach upset.”
“I will take this medication at bedtime.”
“If this medication is not effective, I may increase thedose to 15 mg.”
“Tolerance and physical dependence do not occur with this medication.”
questions.rationale: Zolpidem is a non-benzodiazepine sleep aid. It should be taken 30 minutes before desired sleep. Food decreases theabsorption, so it should be taken on an empty stomach. themaximum recommended dose is 10 mg. Tolerance and physical dependence may occur.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: A patient who has been taking a benzodiazepine as a sleep aid for several months wishes to stop taking themedication. thenurse will suggest that thepatient taper thedose gradually to avoid which effect?
options: Depression
Hangover
Hypnotic rebound
Withdrawal
questions.rationale: Tolerance to benzodiazepines can occur, which means that abrupt cessation can result in withdrawal symptoms such as tremors and muscle twitching. A hangover is residual drowsiness that occurs theday after taking a hypnotic.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing a patient for surgery. thepatient received a hypnotic medication thenight prior and thenurse is administering midazolam and atropine. thepatient asks why all of these medications are necessary. thenurse will tell thepatient that they are given for which reason?
options: To decrease theamount of general anesthesia needed
To prevent theneed for post-surgical pain medications
To prolong theanesthetized state
To speed up anesthesia induction
questions.rationale: Balanced anesthesia may include giving a hypnotic thenight prior to surgery, premedication with an opioid analgesic or benzodiazepine plus an anticholinergic, and then a short-acting nonbarbiturate such as propofol, an inhaled gas, and a muscle relaxant as needed. One desired effect of this approach is to decrease theamount of general anesthetic needed. It may reduce postoperative nausea and vomiting, but it does not necessarily decrease drowsiness or theneed for post-operative pain medications. It does not affect theduration of anesthesia, which is dependent on thelength of time theinhaled gas is given, or therate of induction.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: During balanced anesthesia, which type of medication is given while thesurgery is performed?
options: Anticholinergics
Benzodiazepines
Hypnotics
Inhaled anesthetic
questions.rationale: An inhaled anesthetic is given to induce anesthesia and is maintained throughout thesurgical procedure. theother medications are given prior to anesthesia induction.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: The nurse performs a preoperative assessment on a patient and asks about drug and alcohol use. thepatient asks why this information is important. thenurse will explain that patients who consume increased amounts of alcohol
options: may have a prolonged postoperative recovery time.
may not be eligible for surgery.
may not receive inhaled gases for anesthesia.
may require changes in thetype and dose of anesthesia required.
questions.rationale: The type and amount of anesthetics may need to be adjusted if patients consume large amounts of alcohol, uses illicit drugs, as well as for those who smoke or who are pregnant. These questions are asked prior to surgery so providers can plan for this.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient in thepost-anesthesia care unit and notes that thepatient received isoflurane to induce anesthesia. When will thenurse expect thepatient to recover consciousness?
options: Immediately
In 15 to 30 minutes
In 1 hour
In several hours
questions.rationale: Upon discontinuation of isoflurane, recovery of consciousness usually occurs in approximately 1 hour.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient in thepost-anesthesia care unit who has received a spinal anesthetic. Which action will thenurse perform?
options: Ambulate thepatient as soon as consciousness returns.
Elevate thehead of thebed to a semi-Fowler's position.
Have thepatient lay flat for 6 to 8 hours after thesurgery.
Turn thepatient from side to side every 15 minutes.
questions.rationale: Patients who have had spinal anesthesia should remain flat for 6 to 8 hours to decrease thelikelihood of losing spinal fluid, causing a headache.

questions.category: Chapter 18: Depressants
questions.stem: The preoperative nurse is caring for a patient who is to receive a peripheral nerve block using bupivacaine. thenurse will explain that thepatient receiving this local anesthetic
options: may need to lie flat 6 to 8 hours after surgery.
may require less narcotic medication.
may have a prolonged hospital stay to monitor for respiratory distress.
may be at great risk for allergic reaction.
questions.rationale: Patients who have had a peripheral nerve block with bupivacaine are likely to require less narcotic medication. They are allowed increased mobility as compared to theclient with general anesthesia. thelocal anesthetic carries little risk of respiratory distress and theamide structure lends to less risk of allergic reaction.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A patient is diagnosed with epilepsy and asks thenurse what may have caused this condition. thenurse explains that epilepsy is most often
options: caused by head trauma.
of unknown origin.
linked to a stroke.
related to brain anoxia.
questions.rationale: Of all seizure cases, 75% are considered to be primary, or idiopathic, with no known cause. theremaining are secondary and may be related to head trauma, stroke, or anoxia.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who has epilepsy will begin an anticonvulsant medication. thepatient asks thenurse how long themedication will be necessary. How will thenurse respond?
options: “The medication may be necessary for a lifetime.”
“The medication will be given until you are seizure free.”
“You will need to take themedication for 3 to 5 years.”
“You will take themedication as needed for seizure activity.”
questions.rationale: Anticonvulsants are given to prevent seizures and are usually taken throughout thepatient's lifetime. Stopping themedication can lead to recurrence of seizures in many patients. Some patients may attempt to stop taking themedications after 3 to 5 years of no seizure activity. Anticonvulsants are not given as needed.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is providing teaching to theparents of a 5-year-old child who will begin taking phenytoin (Dilantin). What information will thenurse include when teaching these parents about their child's medication?
options: “Drug interactions are uncommon with phenytoin.”
“There are very few side effects associated with this drug.”
“The therapeutic range of phenytoin is between 15 and 45 mcg/mL.”
“Your child may need a higher dose than is usually used in adults.”
questions.rationale: Drug dosage for phenytoin is age related, and children, who have a rapid metabolism, may need higher doses than those used for newborns and adults. Phenytoin has many drug interactions and many side effects. thetherapeutic range is 10 to 20 mcg/mL. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has a seizure disorder being treated with phenytoin. thenurse notes that thepatient has reddened gums that bleed when brushing. thenurse recognizes this finding as
options: an adverse effect of thephenytoin.
likely due to a drug interaction with aspirin.
a symptom of hepatotoxicity.
a sign of poor self-care.
questions.rationale: Phenytoin commonly causes gingival hyperplasia, which causes overgrowth of reddened gum tissue that bleeds easily. It is not a sign of a drug interaction or a symptom of hepatotoxicity. It does not indicate a lack of self-care.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer phenytoin (Dilantin) to a patient who has a seizure disorder. thenurse notes that thelast random serum drug level was 18 mcg/mL. What action will thenurse take?
options: Administer thedose since thepatient's labs do not indicate toxic phenytoin levels.
Contact theprovider to discuss decreasing thephenytoin dose.
Contact theprovider and discuss increasing thephenytoin dose.
Report drug toxicity to theproviders.
questions.rationale: The patient's drug level is considered within thedesired therapeutic range of 10 to 20 mcg/mL. thenurse should administer thedose as written. It is not necessary to decrease thedose or increase thedose based on this serum level.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer phenytoin to an 80-year-old patient and notes thefollowing order: IVP phenytoin 50 mg. thenurse will perform which action?
options: Administer through a PICC over 2 minutes.
Contact theprovider to question theroute and thedose.
Dilute thedrug in dextrose solution and infuse over 15 to 20 minutes.
Request an order to administer thedrug intramuscularly.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com It is recommended that phenytoin be administered by direct injection into a large vein via a central line or PICC. In older patients it should be infused at a rate of 25 mcg/min. thedose and theroute are appropriate. Phenytoin will precipitate in dextrose solution. Intramuscular injection is very irritating to tissues and is not used.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to assist with blood collection on a newly admitted patient who has been taking phenytoin for several years. theprovider has ordered a complete blood count and liver function tests. Which other blood test will thenurse discuss with theprovider?
options: Blood glucose
Coagulation studies
Renal function tests
Serum electrolytes
questions.rationale: Patients who have taken hydantoins for long periods might have an elevated blood sugar that results from thedrug inhibiting therelease of inulin. thenurse should discuss this test with theprovider.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who takes phenytoin reports recently starting to take antacids for new-onset dyspepsia. thepatient previously had a phenytoin level in thenormal therapeutic range. thenurse might expect a serum phenytoin level in this patient to be in which range?
options: 5 to 10 mcg/mL
10 to 20 mcg/mL
20 to 30 mcg/mL
30 to 50 mcg/mL
questions.rationale: Antacids can decrease theeffects of phenytoin by inhibiting its absorption, which would decrease serum drug levels. thetherapeutic range is 10 to 20 mcg/mL, so a level lower than this may be expected in a patient who started antacids while on phenytoin.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A patient has recently begun taking phenytoin (Dilantin) for a seizure disorder. thenurse notes a reddish-brown color to thepatient's urine. Which action will thenurse take?
options: Ask theprovider to order a serum drug level.
Reassure thepatient that this is a harmless side effect.
Report possible thrombocytopenia to theprovider.
Request an order for a urinalysis and creatinine clearance. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Reddish-brown urine is a harmless side effect of phenytoin. thenurse should reassure thepatient. It is not necessary to order a serum drug level or renal function studies. It is not a symptom of thrombocytopenia.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A female patient who takes phenytoin for epilepsy becomes pregnant. thenurse will notify thepatient's provider and will anticipate that theprovider will take which action?
options: Add valproic acid (Depakote) for improved seizure control.
Discontinue thephenytoin and discuss alternative options to manage her epilepsy.
Closely monitor this patient's serum phenytoin levels.
Discontinue all anticonvulsant medications.
questions.rationale: Phenytoin has serious teratogenic effects, so women who are pregnant should not take it. Valproic acid is known to cause major congenital malformations in infants in 4% to 8% of women who take thedrug; it should be avoided also. Teratogenicity increases with multiple anticonvulsants.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has been diagnosed with absence seizures. thenurse will anticipate teaching this patient about which antiepileptic medication?
options: Carbamazepine (Tegretol)
Ethosuximide (Zarontin)
Phenobarbital (Luminal)
Phenytoin (Dilantin)
questions.rationale: Ethosuximide, which belongs to thesuccinimide drug group, is used to treat absence seizures. theother drugs are not used to treat absence seizures.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: An intubated child is brought to theemergency department while having a seizure that has been progressing for 20 minutes. Which drug will thenurse anticipate administering to this patient first?
options: Diazepam (Valium)
Phenobarbital (Luminal)
Phenytoin (Dilantin)
Valproic acid (Depakote)
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Diazepam is given to patients in status epilepticus and is administered IV. thedrug has a short- term effect; other antiseizure drugs, such as phenytoin or phenobarbital, must be given during or immediately after administration of diazepam. theother anticonvulsant medications do not have a rapid onset and are not used for emergencies.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A patient will begin taking theantiepileptic drug ethosuximide (Zarontin). Ethosuximide works by which of thefollowing mechanisms?
options: Suppressing sodium influx
Increasing GABA activity
Decreasing GABA activity
Suppressing calcium influx
questions.rationale: Ethosuximide works by suppressing calcium influx. Other seizure medications work by suppressing sodium influx and increasing GABA activity. Decreasing GABA activity would increase seizure activity.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A patient has recently begun taking carbamazepine (Tegretol) as an adjunct medication to treat refractory seizures. thepatient has a serum carbamazepine level of 18 mcg/mL. Which of thefollowing would be themost appropriate next step?
options: Ask thepatient about usual dietary preferences.
Reassure thepatient that this is a therapeutic drug level.
Report a subtherapeutic drug dose to theprovider.
Discontinue thecarbamazepine.
questions.rationale: This patient's carbamazepine level is high. When taken with grapefruit juice, an interaction may occur that results in toxic levels of carbamazepine. thenurse should question thepatient about food and fluid preferences. thetherapeutic level is 4 to 12 mcg/mL. This is a toxic level, not subtherapeutic. It would not be appropriate to discontinue therapy at this time.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is performing a health history on a patient who is ordered to begin therapy with valproic acid (Depakote) to treat epilepsy. Which aspect of thepatient's medical history will cause thenurse to be concerned?
options: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
Gastrointestinal disease
Liver disease www.NursingExamBank.com
Renal disease
questions.rationale: Valproic acid can elevate liver enzymes and contribute to hepatotoxicity. Patients with a history of liver disease should use valproic acid with caution and receive appropriate liver monitoring.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A woman who is pregnant is taking an anticonvulsant medication to treat a seizure disorder. thenurse will ensure that thepatient takes which dietary supplement toward theend of her pregnancy?
options: Vitamin D
Iron
Vitamin C
Vitamin K
questions.rationale: Anticonvulsants act as inhibitors of vitamin K and can contribute to hemorrhage in infants shortly after birth. Women taking these drugs should receive vitamin K within thelast week to 10 days of their pregnancies.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A parent expresses concern that a 5-year-old child may develop epilepsy because thechild experienced a febrile seizure at age 18 months. What will thenurse tell this parent?
options: “A child who has had a febrile seizure is considered to have epilepsy.”
“A small percentage of children who have febrile seizures develop epilepsy.”
“I recommend discussing prophylactic anticonvulsant drugs with theprovider.”
“Treat fevers aggressively with aspirin and NSAIDs to prevent seizures.”
questions.rationale: Epilepsy develops in approximately 2.5% of children who have one or more febrile seizures. One febrile seizure does not always result in epilepsy. Prophylactic anticonvulsants are given to high- risk patients. Children should not receive aspirin for fever because of therisk of Reye's syndrome.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A 25-year-old female patient will begin taking phenytoin for epilepsy. thepatient tells thenurse she is taking oral contraceptives (OCPs). Which response will thenurse give?
options: “Continue taking OCPs because phenytoin is not safe during pregnancy.”
“You should use a backup method of contraception along with OCPs.”
“You should stop taking OCPs because of drug-drug interactions with phenytoin.”
“You should take low-dose aspirin while taking these medications to reduce your www.NursingExamBank.com risk of stroke.”
questions.rationale: Female patients who take oral contraceptives and anticonvulsants should be advised to use a backup method of contraception because of reduced effectiveness of OCPs. Patients should be cautioned to consult with a provider if considering pregnancy because of the teratogenic effects of anticonvulsants. Patients should not stop taking OCPs and do not need to take precautions against stroke in the absence of other risk factors.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse provides teaching for a patient who will begin taking phenytoin. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “If I develop a rash, I should take diphenhydramine to control the itching.”
“If I experience bleeding gums, I should stop taking the medication immediately.”
“Most people develop diabetes while taking this medication.”
“I should not be alarmed if my urine turns reddish-brown.”
questions.rationale: Phenytoin can cause reddish-brown colored urine. Patients should be counseled to report a rash to the provider because it could be a serious adverse reaction. Bleeding gums are common, but patients should never stop taking anticonvulsants abruptly, or they may develop seizures. Changes in blood glucose may occur but do not necessarily result in diabetes.

questions.category: Chapter 19: Antiseizure Drugs
questions.stem: A parent of a child who has been taking valproic acid (Depakote) for several years calls the clinic to report a recent recurrence of seizures and states that the child is having three or four seizures per week, but is not currently seizing. The nurse will perform which action first?
options: Ask the parent to describe the child's drug regimen.
Request an order for a serum valproic acid level.
Suggest that the parent take the child to the emergency department.
Tell the parent that the provider will increase the child's dose of Depakote.
questions.rationale: Questions pertaining to medication adherence are a no-cost, non-invasive way of troubleshooting cause of decreased drug effect. The serum drug level will be assessed next. Children may need changes in doses as they grow. The child is not in status epilepticus so does not need to go to the emergency department. The dose will not be increased until the serum drug level is known.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: An older patient exhibits a shuffling gait, lack of facial expression, and tremors at rest. The nurse will expect the provider to order which medication for this patient?
options: Carbidopa-levodopa
Donepezil
Rivastigmine
Memantine
questions.rationale: This patient is exhibiting signs of Parkinson disease and should be treated with a medication indicated to treat Parkinson disease, such as carbidopa-levodopa. The other drugs are indicated to treat Alzheimer disease.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: A nursing student asks the nurse to differentiate the pathology of Alzheimer disease from that of Parkinson disease. Which description is correct?
options: Alzheimer disease involves a possible excess of acetylcholine and neuritic plaques.
Alzheimer disease is caused by decreased amounts of dopamine and degeneration of cholinergic neurons.
Parkinson disease is characterized by an imbalance of dopamine and acetylcholine.
Parkinson disease involves increased dopamine production and decreased acetylcholine.
questions.rationale: Parkinson disease (PD) is characterized by an imbalance of dopamine (DA) and acetylcholine (ACh) caused by an unexplained degeneration of the dopaminergic neurons, allowing the excitatory response of acetylcholine to exceed the inhibitory response of dopamine. Alzheimer disease (AD) may result from decreased ACh, degeneration of cholinergic neurons, and formation of neuritic plaques. Dopamine does not appear to play a role in Alzheimer disease.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: The spouse of a patient newly diagnosed with mild, unilateral symptoms of Parkinson disease (PD) asks the nurse what, besides medication, can be done to manage the disease. The nurse will do which of the following?
options: Counsel the spouse that parkinsonism is a normal part of the aging process in some people.
Recommend exercise, nutritional counseling, and group support to help manage the disease.
Tell the spouse that the disease will not progress if mild symptoms are treated early.
Tell the spouse that medication therapy can be curative if drugs are started in time. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: PD is a progressive disorder. Non-pharmacologic measures including exercise, nutritional counseling, and group support can lessen symptoms and help patients and families cope with the disorder. Although the aging process may contribute to the development of PD, it is not necessarily a normal part of aging. Treatment may slow the progression but does not arrest or cure the disease.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: A patient who has Parkinson disease is being treated with the anticholinergic medication benztropine (Cogentin). The nurse will tell the patient that this drug will have which effect?
options: Helping the patient to walk faster
Improving mental function
Minimizing symptoms of bradykinesia
Improve tremors
questions.rationale: Benztropine, an anticholinergic medication, is given to reduce rigidity and improve symptoms of tremor. It does not improve gait, reduce bradykinesia, or improve mental function.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a first dose of benztropine (Cogentin) to a patient diagnosed with parkinsonism. The nurse would notify the patient's provider if the patient had a history of which condition?
options: Asthma
Glaucoma
Hypertension
Irritable bowel disease
questions.rationale: Patients with a history of glaucoma should not take anticholinergic medications, as the drug can increase the intraocular pressure. Anticholinergics are not contraindicated in patients who have asthma, hypertension, or irritable bowel disease.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving istradefylline for their Parkinson disease. The patient asks the nurse why this medication was added. The nurse understands that this medication was added to
options: help decrease dyskinesias.
to prevent the peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine.
to help with tremor. www.NursingExamBank.com
to reduce “off” periods resulting from long-term treatment with levodopa.
questions.rationale: Istradefylline is an adenosine receptor antagonist used in people with Parkinson disease to reduce “off” periods in people who have been on long-term carbidopa/levodopa therapy.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: A nursing student asks the nurse why patients who have parkinsonism receive a combination of carbidopa and levodopa. The nurse will explain that the combination product
options: allows larger doses of levodopa to be given without causing increased adverse reactions.
causes more levodopa to be converted to dopamine before crossing the blood-brain barrier.
eliminates almost all drug side effects of both levodopa and carbidopa.
reduces peripheral conversion of levodopa to dopamine allowing for more dopamine to reach the basal ganglia with smaller doses of levodopa.
questions.rationale: Without carbidopa, the majority of levodopa is converted to dopamine before crossing the blood- brain barrier, causing peripheral adverse effects. When carbidopa is added, the enzyme dopa decarboxylase is inhibited, allowing more levodopa to cross into the brain before being converted to the active metabolite dopamine. The result is less levodopa required to achieve the desired effect. The drug still has many side effects, but the peripheral side effects are decreased.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: Which antiviral medication improves symptoms of Parkinson disease in some patients?
options: Acyclovir
Amantadine
Interferon
Zanamivir
questions.rationale: Amantadine is an antiviral drug that acts on dopamine receptors and is sometimes used to treat Parkinson disease (PD). The other drugs listed do not work to improve the symptoms of PD.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: A patient who has parkinsonism has been taking carbidopa-levodopa and has shown improvement in symptoms but develops dystonic movements, nausea, and vomiting. Which medication might the provider order for this patient to replace carbidopa-levodopa?
options: Amantadine
Benztropine
Bromocriptine mesylate www.NursingExamBank.com
Entacapone
questions.rationale: Bromocriptine is sometimes used for patients who do not tolerate carbidopa-levodopa. Amantadine is useful for treating Parkinson disease but is not as potent as carbidopa-levodopa. Benztropine is given to reduce muscle rigidity and some tremors. Entacapone is a COMT inhibitor that is used as add-on to carbidopa-levodopa therapy.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: A patient who has parkinsonism will begin taking selegiline. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient about this drug?
options: “Limit foods that are high in tyramine.”
“This drug will prevent the need to take levodopa.”
“You may have red wine with dinner.”
“You will not have serious drug interactions with this drug.”
questions.rationale: Selegiline inhibits monoamine oxidase-B, and it has similar adverse reactions to other monoamine oxidase inhibitors. Patients should be cautioned against excessive consumption of foods containing high amounts of tyramine because of the risk of hypertensive crisis. Red wine is high in tyramine. Use of this drug may delay, but will not prevent, the need for levodopa. Severe adverse drug interactions may occur between this drug and other drugs that work in the CNS.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: A patient who has parkinsonism will begin taking carbidopa-levodopa. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient about this medication?
options: “Call your health care provider immediately if your urine or perspiration turn a dark color.”
“Rise slowly from your bed or your chair to avoid dizziness and falls.”
“Take the drug with foods high in protein to improve drug delivery.”
“Discontinue the drug if you experience insomnia.”
questions.rationale: Carbidopa-levodopa can cause orthostatic hypotension, so patients should be taught to take care when getting out of bed or a chair. Darkening of the urine and perspiration is a harmless side effect. Patients should take the drug with low-protein foods to improve drug transport to the CNS. Carbidopa-levodopa should not be discontinued abruptly because rebound parkinsonism may occur; insomnia is an expected adverse effect of the drug, and the patient should report this effect to his or her health care provider.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who has Parkinson disease about the side effects of carbidopa- levodopa. Which statement by the patient indicates a need for further teaching?
options: “I may experience nausea, vomiting, and dyskinesia.”
“I may feel dizzy at first, but this side effect should improve with time.”
“I should report nightmares and mental disturbances to my provider.”
“I should take the drug with protein to increase absorption.”
questions.rationale: Taking carbidopa-levodopa with high protein foods can decrease absorption of the drug, although gastrointestinal distress may decrease when the medication is taken with food. Gastrointestinal side effects are common, and dyskinesias can potentially occur. Orthostatic hypotension occurs early and will resolve over time. Nightmares and mental disturbances should be reported.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: A patient is taking entacapone along with carbidopa-levodopa to treat parkinsonism. The nurse notes that the patient's urine is orange in color. The nurse will
options: notify the provider of possible drug toxicity.
reassure the patent that this is a harmless side effect.
request an order for liver function tests.
request an order for a urinalysis.
questions.rationale: Entacapone can cause the urine to be dark yellow to orange. It does not indicate drug toxicity, liver effects, or changes in renal function.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for an 80-year-old patient who has Alzheimer disease who will begin taking oral rivastigmine. What will the nurse include in the plan of care for this patient?
options: Administer the drug once daily.
Assist the patient to stand and walk.
Give the drug with food to increase absorption.
Use nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) instead of acetaminophen for pain.
questions.rationale: Patients taking rivastigmine for Alzheimer disease are at risk for orthostatic hypotension, falls, and loss of balance. Caregivers should assist with standing and walking. The drug is taken twice daily, and it should be taken on an empty stomach. NSAIDs increase gastrointestinal side effects.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: The nurse is providing teaching for the family of a patient who has been newly diagnosed with Alzheimer disease (AD). Which statement by the family member indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “Alzheimer disease is a chronic, progressive condition.”
“Alzheimer disease affects memory but not personality.”
“Alzheimer disease is caused by a deficiency in dopamine.”
“With proper treatment, symptoms of this disease can be arrested.”
questions.rationale: AD is chronic and progressive, and there is no cure. It affects memory and personality. PD is associated with a deficiency in dopamine. Symptoms cannot be arrested but may be slowed with treatment.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a family member about an elderly parent's new prescription for memantine. The nurse includes which of the following in the teaching?
options: Memantine is used to treat Parkinson disease.
Memantine is taken as needed for confusion.
Memantine is rarely associated with the development of a serious rash, which should be communicated with the provider if it occurs.
Memantine is available in a patch form.
questions.rationale: Memantine can rarely cause serious rash, including Stevens-Johnson syndrome. If a rash develops this should be reported to the provider immediately. Memantine is used to treat Alzheimer disease, not Parkinson disease. Memantine is taken daily and is taken orally. Rivastigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor indicated for the treatment of Alzheimer disease that is available in patch form.

questions.category: Chapter 20: Drugs for Parkinsonism and Alzheimer Disease
questions.stem: The nurse is helping to develop a plan of care for a patient who has advanced Alzheimer disease. The patient will be taking a new medication. Which is a realistic goal for this patient?
options: Demonstrate improved cognitive function.
Exhibit improved ability to provide self-care.
Receive appropriate assistance for care needs.
Show improved memory for recent events.
questions.rationale: For the most part, drugs to treat AD do not result in improvement of symptoms but help slow the progression of the disease. The most realistic care plan for a patient with advanced AD is that they will receive appropriate assistance for care needs. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has myasthenia gravis. The nurse will be alert to symptoms affecting which body system which may indicate that the patient has transitioned to myasthenic crisis?
options: Cardiovascular system
Central nervous system (CNS), memory, and cognition
Gastrointestinal system (GI) and lower extremity muscles
Respiratory system
questions.rationale: Patients with myasthenia gravis can progress to severe, generalized muscle weakness involving the muscles of respiration, such as the diaphragm and intercostal muscles.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: A 40-year-old woman is diagnosed with myasthenia gravis, and her provider recommends removal of her thymus gland. She asks the nurse why this would be helpful. The nurse will explain that removal of the thymus gland may
options: increase binding of acetylcholine (ACh) molecules to ACh receptors.
increase the amount of ACh available at neuromuscular junction sites.
reduce the number of acetylcholine receptor sites.
reduce symptoms of myasthenia gravis following surgery.
questions.rationale: Thymic hyperplasia and tumors are common in patients with myasthenia gravis (MG). The thymus gland is involved in systemic immunity that is active during infancy and early childhood, but the gland normally shrinks during adulthood. Approximately 70% of MG patients have thymic hyperplasia. A thymectomy (removal of the thymus gland) is most beneficial because it can cause a reduction of symptoms following the surgery.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse assumes care of a patient who has myasthenia gravis and notes that a dose of neostigmine scheduled to be administered 1 hour prior was not given. The nurse will anticipate the patient to exhibit which symptoms?
options: Excessive salivation
Muscle spasms/twitching
Muscle weakness www.NursingExamBank.com
Abdominal cramping
questions.rationale: Neostigmine must be given on time to prevent myasthenic crisis, which is characterized by generalized, severe muscle weakness. The other symptoms are characteristic of cholinergic crisis, caused by too much medication.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has myasthenia gravis (MG) and takes pyridostigmine 60 mg every 4 hours. The patient's last dose was 45 minutes prior. The nurse notes respiratory distress, excess salivation, fasciculations of facial muscles, and pupil constriction. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Assess the patient for signs of ptosis.
Notify the provider to discuss an order for intravenous immune globulin (IVIG).
Obtain an order for atropine sulfate.
Request an order for an extra dose of pyridostigmine.
questions.rationale: Respiratory distress, excess salivation, fasciculations of facial muscles, and pupil constriction are the major signs of cholinergic crisis, caused by excess pyridostigmine. The antidote is atropine, so the nurse should obtain an order to give this. Ptosis is a sign of myasthenic crisis. IVIG is given to treat symptoms of MG and not used for cholinergic crisis. Giving extra pyridostigmine would increase the symptoms.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: Which of the following is FALSE regarding pyridostigmine?
options: It is poorly absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract.
Overdosing of pyridostigmine can result in cholinergic crisis.
Atropine is the antidote for pyridostigmine overdose.
Pyridostigmine is a muscarinic receptor antagonist.
questions.rationale: Pyridostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor and does not antagonize muscarinic receptors. The drug is poorly absorbed from the GI tract. Overdosing with pyridostigmine results in cholinergic crisis, and atropine is used as an antidote for pyridostigmine overdose.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: A patient reports weakness of the extremities and diplopia. The nurse knows that these symptoms are characteristic of which condition?
options: Cerebral palsy (CP) www.NursingExamBank.com
Multiple sclerosis (MS)
Myasthenia gravis (MG)
Parkinson disease (PD)
questions.rationale: Diplopia and weakness of the extremities are two symptoms of MS. CP is characterized by muscle spasticity. MG involves generalized weakness, especially of facial muscles and respiratory muscles. PD manifests as tremors and difficulty moving and walking.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: A patient has symptoms that are characteristic of multiple sclerosis (MS). Which diagnostic tests are likely to be ordered to aid in the diagnosis?
options: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI)
CSF proteins and an angiography
Serum albumin and a computed tomography (CT) scan
Serum anti-acetylcholine antibodies and x-rays
questions.rationale: Laboratory tests that may be used to confirm a diagnosis of MS include CSF analysis, evoked potential (EP) testing, and MRI.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: A patient with multiple sclerosis (MS) is to start treatment with interferon beta-1a. The presence of which of the following will prompt the nurse to check with the provider?
options: History of diabetes mellitus
History of hypertension
History of depression and suicidal ideation
History of osteoarthritis
questions.rationale: Interferons are associated with contributing to symptoms of depression and suicidal ideation. For patients with a positive history of depression and suicidal ideation consideration of alternative therapy is likely prudent. A history of diabetes, hypertension or osteoarthritis would not preclude the use of interferon therapy.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse provides teaching to a patient who will begin taking cyclobenzaprine to treat acute muscle spasms. Which statement by the patient indicates a need for further teaching?
options: “I may experience dizziness and drowsiness when I take this drug.”
“I should not consume alcohol while taking this medication.”
“I should be careful driving with this medication because it can cause drowsiness.”
“I will take this medication for 3 months and then stop taking it.” www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Most centrally acting muscle relaxants used for acute spasms are taken for no longer than 3 weeks and should be tapered over 1 week to avoid rebound spasms. Patients may experience dizziness and drowsiness. Alcohol will compound the central nervous system sedative effects. Patients should be cautioned about driving and operating machinery while using muscle relaxants.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse is performing an admission assessment on a patient who has been taking carisoprodol for 3 weeks to treat muscle spasms. The patient reports that the muscle spasms have resolved. The nurse will contact the provider to discuss
options: changing to cyclobenzaprine.
continuing the carisoprodol for 1 more week.
discontinuing the carisoprodol now.
ordering a taper of the carisoprodol.
questions.rationale: Muscle relaxants can result in drug dependence and should not be withdrawn abruptly. The nurse should discuss a drug taper. Changing to a different muscle relaxant (cyclobenzaprine) is not recommended since the patient is doing well.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a group of nursing students about multiple sclerosis (MS). Which statement by the nurse is correct?
options: “MS is characterized by depletion of dopamine in neurons and nerves in the brain and spinal cord.”
“MS is characterized by lesions or plaques on myelin sheaths of nerves.”
“MS is characterized by neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles in the CNS.”
“MS is characterized by weak muscles and decreased nerve impulses caused by decreased ACh.”
questions.rationale: MS is characterized by lesions or plaques on myelin sheaths of nerves.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has multiple sclerosis (MS). The patient is experiencing an acute attack and reports sudden onset of blindness in one eye. Which drug does the nurse anticipate the provider will order?
options: IV methylprednisolone www.NursingExamBank.com
Mitoxantrone
Glatiramer acetate
Interferon-B
questions.rationale: IV methylprednisolone (a corticosteroid) is given to treat an acute attack of MS. Glatiramer acetate, interferon products, and mitoxantrone are given chronically to prevent worsening of symptoms.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse is performing a health history on a patient who has multiple sclerosis (MS) who will be started on a new therapy. The patient asks about a medication he heard about on TV that can cause a life threatening viral infection in the CNS. The nurse recognizes that he is referring to which of the following medications?
options: Siponimod
Mitoxantrone
Glatiramer acetate
Natalizumab
questions.rationale: Natalizumab has a black box warning for risk of leukoencephalopathy.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to care for a patient who has multiple sclerosis (MS). The nurse learns that the patient receives fingolimod. The nurse knows that which of the following is FALSE about fingolimod?
options: It is used for treatment of relapsing remitting MS (RRMS).
It is administered IV.
Fingolimod treatment requires CBC, ECG and LFT monitoring.
Diarrhea and headache are common side effects.
questions.rationale: Fingolimod is orally administered. It is used to treat RRMS. Common side effects include diarrhea and headache, and treatment requires monitoring of CBC, ECG and LFTs.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: Which agent listed below is used in surgery to achieve neuromuscular blockade and paralysis?
options: Baclofen
Chlorzoxazone
Pancuronium bromide www.NursingExamBank.com
Methocarbamol
questions.rationale: Pancuronium bromide is used as a muscle relaxant as adjunct to anesthesia. Baclofen is used for muscle spasms caused by MS or spinal cord injury. Chlorzoxazone and methocarbamol are used for acute muscle spasms.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer chlorzoxazone to a patient who is experiencing acute muscle spasms. The nurse notes discoloration of the patient's urine. What will the nurse do?
options: Administer the next dose of chlorzoxazone since this is a harmless side effect.
Contact the provider to discuss changing to cyclobenzaprine.
Obtain an order for a complete blood count to evaluate blood loss.
Request an order for liver function tests since this indicates hepatotoxicity.
questions.rationale: Urine discoloration can occur in patients taking chlorzoxazone, and this is a harmless side effect. There is no need to change medications or order lab tests.

questions.category: Chapter 21: Drugs for Neuromuscular Disorders and Muscle Spasms
questions.stem: A client with myasthenia gravis is experiencing a cholinergic crisis. Which symptoms are associated with this condition? (Select all that apply.)
options: Bradycardia
Rash
Vomiting
Fever e. Drooling f. Weakness
questions.rationale: , C, E, F Bradycardia, vomiting, drooling, and weakness can all occur with cholinergic crisis.

questions.category: Chapter 22: Antipsychotics and Anxiolytics
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is taking chlorpromazine HCl 75 mg BID to treat schizophrenia. A family member tells the nurse that the patient's agitation, hallucinations, and delusions have improved with use of the drug, but the patient continues to withdraw from social interaction and won't bathe unless reminded to do so. The nurse will tell the family member that
options: all symptoms will eventually resolve over time with this medication.
the patient may need an increased dose of their current antipsychotic medication.
these results may indicate that the patient does not have schizophrenia.
they should consider discussing changing the chlorpromazine to an atypical antipsychotic.
questions.rationale: Chlorpromazine is a typical (first generation) antipsychotic medication; drugs in this class manage positive symptoms rather than the negative symptoms of withdrawal and poor self-care. It is not likely that the negative symptoms will improve over time with this medication. Atypical (second generation) antipsychotics can help with both positive and negative symptoms, so it would be worthwhile discussing a change in medication to see if the patient's negative symptoms could be improved. Increasing the dose will not improve control of negative symptoms. This patient exhibits signs of schizophrenia.

questions.category: Chapter 22: Antipsychotics and Anxiolytics
questions.stem: The nurse is assessing a young adult patient with schizophrenia who recently began taking fluphenazine. The patient is exhibiting spasms of facial muscles along with grimacing, and the nurse notes upward eye movements. The nurse suspects which side effect?
options: Acute dystonia
Akathisia
Pseudoparkinsonism
Tardive dyskinesia
questions.rationale: Acute dystonia can occur within days of taking typical antipsychotics, and facial muscle spasms, grimacing, and upward eye movements are characteristic of this side effect. Akathisia is characterized by restlessness, pacing, and difficulty standing still. Pseudoparkinsonism is characterized by stooped posture, pill-rolling, shuffling gait, and tremors at rest. Tardive dyskinesia manifests as protrusion and rolling of the tongue, smacking of the lips, and involuntary movement of the body and extremities.

questions.category: Chapter 22: Antipsychotics and Anxiolytics
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer loxapine 50 mg to a patient who has schizophrenia. The patient has been taking this medication twice daily for 15 months. The nurse notes smacking lip movements and involuntary movements of all extremities. Which initial action by the nurse would be most appropriate?
