questions.category: Chapter 28: Tetracyclines, Glycylcyclines, Aminoglycosides, and Fluoroquinolones
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer a maintenance dose of intravenous gentamicin to an infant through an intermittent needle. The nurse notes that the infant has not had a wet diaper for several hours. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Administer the medication and give the infant extra oral fluids.
Contact the provider to request adding intravenous fluids when giving the medication.
Give the medication and obtain a serum peak drug level 45 minutes after the dose.
Hold the dose and contact the provider to request a serum trough drug level.
questions.rationale: Gentamicin can cause nephrotoxicity. When changes in urine output occur, the provider should be notified, and serum trough levels should be obtained to make sure the drug is not at a toxic level. If the drug level is determined to be safe, giving extra fluids either orally or intravenously may be indicated. Serum peak levels give information about therapeutic levels but are not a substitution for avoiding nephrotoxicity in the face of possible oliguria.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Tetracyclines, Glycylcyclines, Aminoglycosides, and Fluoroquinolones
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a 70-kg patient who is receiving gentamicin 85 mg 4 times daily. The patient reports experiencing ringing in the ears. The nurse will contact the provider to discuss which of the following?
options: Decreasing the dose to 50 mg QID
Giving the dose 3 times daily
Obtaining a serum drug level www.NursingExamBank.com
Ordering a hearing test
questions.rationale: Aminoglycosides can cause ototoxicity. Any changes in hearing should be reported to the provider so that serum drug levels can be monitored. The dose is correct for this patient's weight (5 mg/kg/day in 4 divided doses). A hearing test is not indicated unless changes in hearing persist.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Tetracyclines, Glycylcyclines, Aminoglycosides, and Fluoroquinolones
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to begin a medication regimen for a patient who will receive intravenous ampicillin and gentamicin. Which is an important nursing action?
options: Administer each antibiotic to infuse over 15 to 20 minutes.
Order serum peak and trough levels of ampicillin.
Prepare the schedule so that the drugs are given at the same time.
Set up separate tubing sets for each drug labeled with the drug name and date.
questions.rationale: Intravenous aminoglycosides can be given with penicillins and cephalosporins but should not be mixed in the same container. The IV line should be flushed between antibiotics, or separate tubing sets may be set up. Gentamicin must be infused over 30 to 60 minutes. It is not necessary to measure ampicillin peak and trough levels. Giving the drugs at the same time increases the risk of mixing them together.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Tetracyclines, Glycylcyclines, Aminoglycosides, and Fluoroquinolones
questions.stem: The nurse is reviewing a patient's chart prior to administering gentamicin and notes that the last serum peak drug level was 9 mcg/mL and the last trough level was 2 mcg/mL. What action will the nurse take?
options: Administer the next dose as ordered.
Obtain repeat peak and trough levels before giving the next dose.
Report possible drug toxicity to the patient's provider.
Report a decreased drug therapeutic level to the patient's provider.
questions.rationale: Gentamicin peak values should be 5 to 8 mcg/mL, and trough levels should be <1 to 2 mcg/mL. Peak levels give information about whether or not a drug is reaching potentially toxic levels, while trough levels indicate whether a therapeutic level is maintained. This drug is at a toxic level, and the next dose should not be given.

questions.category: Chapter 28: Tetracyclines, Glycylcyclines, Aminoglycosides, and Fluoroquinolones
questions.stem: The nurse is providing discharge teaching for a patient who will receive oral levofloxacin to treat pneumonia. The patient takes an oral hypoglycemic medication and uses over-the-counter (OTC) antacids to treat occasional heartburn. The patient reports frequent arthritis pain and takes acetaminophen when needed. Which statement by the nurse is correct when teaching this patient?
options: “You may take antacids with levofloxacin to decrease gastrointestinal upset.”
“You may take nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory medications (NSAIDs) for arthritis pain.”
“You should monitor your serum glucose more closely while taking levofloxacin.”
“You should take levofloxacin on an empty stomach to improve absorption.”
questions.rationale: Levofloxacin may increase the effects of oral hypoglycemic medications, so patients taking these should be advised to monitor their glucose levels closely. Antacids decrease the absorption of levofloxacin and should be given 2 hours before or after the antibiotic. NSAIDs taken with levofloxacin can cause central nervous system reactions, including seizures. The drug can be taken with food.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: Which is a characteristic that distinguishes sulfonamides from other drugs used to treat bacterial infection?
options: Sulfonamides are bactericidal.
Sulfonamides are not derived from biologic substances.
Sulfonamides have antifungal and antiviral properties.
Sulfonamides increase bacterial synthesis of folic acid.
questions.rationale: Sulfonamides are not derived from biologic substances. They are bacteriostatic, not bactericidal. They are not antifungals or antivirals. They act by decreasing bacterial synthesis of folic acid.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: The nurse is counseling a patient who will begin taking a sulfonamide drug to treat a urinary tract infection. What information will the nurse include in teaching?
options: “Drink several quarts of water daily.”
“If stomach upset occurs, take an antacid.”
“This is a safe drug to take while pregnant.”
“Sore throat is a common, harmless side effect.”
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Patients should drink several quarts of water daily while taking sulfonamides to prevent crystalluria. Patients should not take antacids with sulfonamides. Sulfonamides should be avoided during pregnancy to avoid congenital malformations, neural tube defects, and kernicterus. Sore throat should be reported.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: A female patient who is taking trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMZ) to treat a urinary tract infection reports vaginal itching and discharge. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Ask the patient if she might be pregnant.
Reassure the patient that this is a normal side effect.
Report a possible superinfection to the provider.
Suspect that the patient is having a hematologic reaction.
questions.rationale: Superinfection can occur with a secondary infection. Vaginal itching and discharge is a sign of superinfection. This is not symptomatic of pregnancy. These are not common side effects and do not indicate a hematologic reaction.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: A patient who will begin taking trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX) asks the nurse why the combination drug is necessary. The nurse will explain that the combination is used to
options: broaden the antibacterial spectrum.
produce a synergistic effect.
improve the taste.
minimize toxic effects.
questions.rationale: The combination drug is used to produce a synergistic effect that increases the desired drug response. It does not broaden the spectrum, improve the taste, or decrease toxicity.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX) to a patient who is being treated for a urinary tract infection. The nurse learns that the patient has type 2 diabetes mellitus and takes a sulfonylurea oral antidiabetic drug. The nurse will monitor this patient closely for which effect?
options: Headaches
Hypertension
Hypoglycemia
Superinfection www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Taking oral antidiabetic agents (sulfonylurea) with sulfonamides increases the hypoglycemic effect. Sulfonylureas do not increase the incidence of headaches, hypertension, or superinfection when taken with sulfonamides. Examples of antidiabetic sulfonylurea medications are glipizide, glimepiride, glyburide, tolazamide, and tolbutamide.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to give a dose of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX) and learns that the patient takes warfarin. The nurse will request an order for
options: a decreased dose of TMP–SMX.
a different antibiotic.
an increased dose of warfarin.
coagulation studies.
questions.rationale: Sulfonamides can increase the anticoagulant effects of warfarin. The nurse should request INR levels. An increased dose of warfarin would likely lead to toxicity and to undesirable anticoagulation.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: A patient who is taking trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX) calls to report developing an all-over rash. The nurse will instruct the patient to perform which action?
options: Increase fluid intake.
Take diphenhydramine.
Stop taking TMP–SMX immediately.
Continue taking the medication.
questions.rationale: A rash can indicate a serious drug reaction. Patients should stop taking the drug immediately and notify the provider.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving sulfadiazine. The nurse knows that this patient's daily fluid intake should be at least which amount?
options: 1000 mL/day
1200 mL/day
2000 mL/day
2400 mL/day
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com To prevent crystalluria, patients should consume at least 2000 mL/day when taking sulfonamides.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: A patient taking trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX) to treat a urinary tract infection complains of a sore throat. The nurse will contact the provider to request an order for which laboratory test(s)?
options: Complete blood count with differential
Throat culture
Urinalysis
Coagulation studies
questions.rationale: A sore throat can indicate a life-threatening anemia, so a complete blood count with differential should be ordered.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is ordered to receive trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole 160/800 PO QID to treat a urinary tract infection caused by E. coli. The nurse will contact the provider to clarify the correct
options: dose.
drug.
frequency.
route.
questions.rationale: TMP–SMX is taken twice daily. This is the correct dose, drug, and route to treat this condition.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to give a second dose of trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX) to a patient and notes a petechial rash on the patient's extremities. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Hold the dose and notify the provider.
Request an order for a blood glucose level.
Request an order for a BUN and creatinine level.
Request an order for diphenhydramine (Benadryl).
questions.rationale: A petechial rash can indicate a severe adverse reaction and should be reported before administering the dose. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is taking trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX). The nurse learns that the patient takes an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor. To monitor for drug interactions, the nurse will request an order for which laboratory test(s)?
options: A complete blood count
BUN and creatinine
Electrolytes
Glucose
questions.rationale: TMP–SMX can result in hyperkalemia when taken with an ACE inhibitor. Monitoring of electrolytes and symptoms of hyperkalemia would be indicated.

questions.category: Chapter 29: Sulfonamides and Nitroimidazoles Antibiotics
questions.stem: A child who weighs 10 kg will begin taking oral trimethoprim–sulfamethoxazole (TMP–SMX). The liquid preparation contains 40 mg of TMP and 200 mg of SMX per 5 mL. The nurse determines that the child's dose should be 8 mg of TMP and 40 mg of SMX/kg/day divided into two doses. Which order for this child is correct?
options: 5 mL PO BID
5 mL PO daily
10 mL PO BID
10 mL PO daily
questions.rationale: This child should receive (10 kg × 8 mg) 80 mg of TMP and (10 kg × 40 mg) 400 mL of SMX per day. When divided into two doses, the correct dose is 40 mg TMP and 200 mg SMX, or 5 mL per dose.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: Which person should be treated with prophylactic antitubercular medication?
options: A child who attends the same school with a child who has tuberculosis
A nurse who is working in a hospital
An individual who is HIV-positive with a negative TB skin test
A patient with latent TB as evidence by a positive tuberculin skin test www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Prophylactic antituberculars are drugs to prevent TB disease in individuals with latent TB infection as evidenced by a clinically significant result on tuberculin skin testing. Attending the same school does not necessarily mean close contact occurs. Health care professionals do not need prophylactic treatment. HIV-positive individuals with negative TB skin tests do not need prophylaxis.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient who has chronic liver disease reports contact with a person who has tuberculosis (TB). The nurse will counsel this patient to contact the provider to discuss which of the following?
options: A chest x-ray
A TB skin test
Liver function tests (LFTs)
Prophylactic antitubercular drugs
questions.rationale: Patients who have exposure to TB should have a TB skin test. A chest x-ray is performed if the skin test is positive. LFTs do not need to be done simply because of TB exposure. This patient is not a candidate for antitubercular drug prophylaxis.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient who has tuberculosis asks the nurse why three drugs are used to treat this disease. The nurse will explain that multidrug therapy is used to reduce the likelihood of
options: disease relapse.
drug hypersensitivity reactions.
drug resistance.
drug adverse effects.
questions.rationale: Without multidrug therapy, patients easily develop resistance to antitubercular drugs. Using more than one antitubercular drug does not prevent relapse, hypersensitivity reactions, or adverse effects.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient is being treated with isoniazid (INH), rifampin, and pyrazinamide in the initial phase of treatment for tuberculosis. The organism develops resistance to isoniazid. Which drug will the nurse anticipate the provider will order to replace the isoniazid?
options: Ciprofloxacin
Ethambutol www.NursingExamBank.com
Kanamycin
Streptomycin sulfate
questions.rationale: If there is bacterial resistance to isoniazid, the first phase may be changed to ethambutol, rifampin, and pyrazinamide. Ciprofloxacin, kanamycin, and streptomycin are not generally first- line antitubercular drugs.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is diagnosed with active tuberculosis. The patient tells the nurse that the provider plans to order a prophylactic antitubercular drug for family members and asks which drug will be ordered. The nurse will expect the provider to order which drug?
options: Isoniazid
Pyrazinamide
Rifampin
Streptomycin
questions.rationale: INH is the drug of choice for prophylactic treatment of TB.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient is receiving antitubercular treatment for latent TB. The patient develops symptoms of peripheral neuropathy and is started on pyridoxine (vitamin B6). The nurse suspects this was caused by which of the following medications?
options: Ethambutol
Isoniazid
Rifampin
Kanamycin
questions.rationale: Peripheral neuropathy can be a problem in patients taking isoniazid, especially for those who are malnourished, have diabetes mellitus, or are alcoholics. This condition can be prevented if pyridoxine (vitamin B6) is administered.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient who is taking isoniazid (INH) as part of a two-drug tuberculosis treatment regimen reports tingling of the fingers and toes. The nurse will recommend discussing which treatment with the provider?
options: Adding pyrazinamide
Changing to ethambutol
Increasing oral fluid intake www.NursingExamBank.com
Taking pyridoxine (B6)
questions.rationale: Peripheral neuropathy is an adverse reaction to INH, so pyridoxine is usually given to prevent this. It is not necessary to change medications. Increasing fluids will not help with this.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient about rifampin. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “I should not wear soft contact lenses while taking rifampin.”
“I will report any changes in my hearing while taking this drug.”
“I will report orange urine to my provider immediately.”
“I understand that renal toxicity is a common adverse effect.”
questions.rationale: Patients taking rifampin should be warned that urine, feces, saliva, sputum, sweat, and tears may turn a harmless red-orange color. Patients should not wear soft contact lenses to avoid permanent staining. Streptomycin is associated with ototoxicity. Orange urine is a harmless side effect and does not need to be reported. Renal toxicity is not common with rifampin.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient who has completed the first phase of a three-drug regimen for tuberculosis has a positive sputum acid-bacilli test. The nurse will tell the patient that
options: drug resistance has probably occurred.
it may be another month before this test is negative.
the provider will change the pyrazinamide to ethambutol.
there may be a need to remain in the first phase of therapy for several weeks.
questions.rationale: The goal is for the patient's sputum test to be negative 2 to 3 months after the therapy. The positive test does not indicate drug resistance. The provider will not change the drugs or keep the patient in the first phase longer than planned.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a nursing student about the antifungal drug amphotericin B. Which statement by the student indicates a need for further teaching?
options: “Amphotericin B may be given intravenously or by mouth.”
“Patients who take this drug should have potassium and magnesium levels assessed.”
“Patients with severe renal disease should not take amphotericin B.”
“This drug is used for severe systemic infections.” www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Amphotericin B is not absorbed from the gastrointestinal tract, so is not given by mouth. It can cause nephrotoxicity and electrolyte imbalance. It is highly toxic and is reserved for severe, systemic infections.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient who has oral candidiasis will begin using nystatin suspension to treat the infection. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient?
options: “Coat the buccal mucosa with the drug and then rinse your mouth.”
“Put the pill under the tongue and let it dissolve.”
“Mix the suspension with 4 ounces of water and then drink it.”
“Swish the liquid in your mouth and then swallow after a few minutes.”
questions.rationale: Patients should be taught to swish the suspension in the mouth to coat the tongue and buccal mucosa and then either dispose of or swallow the medication. It should not be diluted with water or swallowed with water. Oral suspension is the preferred route for treating oral thrush.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient with HIV will begin taking micafungin to treat a candida infection. Which of the following statements by the patient indicates a further need for teaching?
options: “This medication will be given slowly over an hour so I don't have a reaction to the medication.”
“I will take this medication by mouth twice daily.”
“This medication works by preventing the growth of the fungus.”
“People who have HIV sometimes need a higher dose of this medication.”
questions.rationale: Micafungin is an echinocandin, which works by interfering with the growth and reproduction of the fungus. Echinocandins are given IV because they are not absorbed from the GI tract. Micafungin is infused slowly over 1 hour to prevent a histamine-medicated reaction. People with HIV co-infection sometimes need higher doses.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient is diagnosed with histoplasmosis and will begin taking oral ketoconazole. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient about this medication?
options: “Take the medicine twice daily.”
“Take the medication with food.”
“You may consume small amounts of alcohol.”
“You will not need lab tests while taking this drug.” www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Ketoconazole should be taken with food. It is administered once daily. Patients taking antifungals should not consume alcohol. Antifungals can cause liver and renal toxicity, so patients will need lab monitoring.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient who has AIDS is at risk to contract aspergillosis. The nurse will anticipate that which antifungal medication will be ordered prophylactically for this patient?
options: Metronidazole
Micafungin
Posaconazole
Voriconazole
questions.rationale: Posaconazole is given for prophylactic treatment of Aspergillus and Candida infections.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient is diagnosed with tinea capitis. The provider will order which systemic antifungal medication for this patient?
options: Anidulafungin
Fluconazole
Griseofulvin
Ketoconazole
questions.rationale: Griseofulvin is used to treat tinea capitis. Anidulafungin is used to treat esophageal candidiasis, candidemia, and other Candida infections. Fluconazole is used to treat Candida infections and cryptococcal meningitis. Ketoconazole is used to treat Candida infections, histoplasmosis, blastomycosis, and other infections.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient who takes an oral sulfonylurea medication will begin taking fluconazole. The nurse will expect to monitor which of the following in this patient?
options: Blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine
Electrolytes
Fluconazole levels
Glucose
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Fluconazole can increase the risk of hypoglycemia when taken with oral sulfonylureas. The patient's blood glucose should be monitored during treatment.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient calls the clinic in November to report a temperature of 103 F, headache, a nonproductive cough, and muscle aches. The patient reports feeling well earlier that day. The nurse will schedule the patient to see the provider and will expect the provider to order which medication?
options: Amantadine
Influenza vaccine
Oseltamivir phosphate
An over-the-counter drug for symptomatic treatment
questions.rationale: Current recommendations for the treatment of influenza types A and B are oseltamivir or zanamivir. Amantadine and rimantadine were formally used for prophylaxis and treatment against influenza A virus; but because of resistance in circulating influenza A, amantadines are not recommended. Influenza A is sensitive to oseltamivir and zanamivir. The influenza vaccine may be given later to protect against other strains. Over-the-counter medications may be used as adjunct treatment.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient is diagnosed with influenza and will begin taking a neuraminidase inhibitor. The nurse knows that this drug is effective when taken within how many hours of onset of flu symptoms?
options: 12 hours
24 hours
48 hours
72 hours
questions.rationale: Neuraminidase inhibitors, such as zanamivir and oseltamivir, should be taken within 48 hours of onset of symptoms for best effect.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: The nurse receives an order to administer a purine nucleoside antiviral medication. The nurse understands that this medication treats which type of virus?
options: Hepatitis virus
Herpes virus
HIV
Influenza virus www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Purine nucleosides, such as acyclovir, are used to treat herpes simplex viruses (HSV-1, HSV-2) and varicella-zoster viruses (chickenpox and shingles).

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: The nurse receives the following order for an immunocompetent patient who is diagnosed with herpes zoster virus: PO acyclovir 400 mg TID for 7 to 10 days. The nurse will contact the provider to clarify which part of the order?
options: Dose and frequency
Frequency and duration
Drug and dose
Drug and duration
questions.rationale: Acyclovir is used for herpes zoster, but the dose should be 800 mg 5 times daily for 7 to 10 days. The nurse should clarify the dose and frequency.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who will receive acyclovir for a herpes virus infection. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient?
options: Herpes cannot be spread to your partner while taking this medication.
Dizziness and confusion are harmless side effects.
Increase fluid intake while taking this medication.
Side effects are rare with this medication.
questions.rationale: Patients taking acyclovir should increase fluid intake to maintain hydration. Patients should be instructed to avoid spreading the infection by practicing sexual abstinence or using condoms correctly and consistently. Dizziness and confusion should be reported to the provider. Antiviral medications have many side effects.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A patient is being treated for hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. The nurse knows that all of the following are approved to treat HBV, EXCEPT:
options: Lamivudine.
Oseltamivir.
Tenofovir.
Peginterferon alfa-2a.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Oseltamivir is used to treat influenza. Lamivudine, tenofovir, and peginterferon alfa-2a are indicated for the treatment of HBV infection.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: A client is being treated for tuberculosis. Which medications are used to treat this condition? (Select all that apply.)
options: Streptomycin sulfate
Amoxicillin
Ethambutol
Gentamicin e. Rifabutin f. Ethionamide g. Pyrazinamide
questions.rationale: , C, E, F, G Streptomycin sulfate, ethambutol, rifabutin, ethionamide, and pyrazinamide are used to treat tuberculosis. The other medications are not used for this indication.

questions.category: Chapter 30: Antituberculars, Antifungals, and Antivirals
questions.stem: Which diseases are caused by herpes viruses? (Select all that apply.)
options: Chicken pox
Hepatitis
Influenza
Mononucleosis e. Shingles
questions.rationale: , D, E Herpes viruses cause chicken pox, mononucleosis, and shingles.

questions.category: Chapter 31: Antimalarials, Anthelmintics, and Peptides
questions.stem: A patient who has traveled to an area with prevalent malaria has chills, fever, and diaphoresis. The nurse recognizes this as which phase of malarial infection? www.NursingExamBank.com
options: Erythrocytic phase
Incubation phase
Prodromal phase
Tissue phase
questions.rationale: The erythrocytic phase of malarial infection occurs when the parasite invades the red blood cells and is characterized by chills, fever, and sweating.

questions.category: Chapter 31: Antimalarials, Anthelmintics, and Peptides
questions.stem: A patient is preparing to travel to a country with prevalent malaria. To prevent contracting the disease, the provider has ordered chloroquine HCl. The nurse will instruct the patient to take this drug according to which schedule?
options: 500 mg weekly beginning 2 weeks prior to travel and continuing for 8 weeks after travel.
1000 mg weekly beginning 2 weeks prior to travel and continuing for 8 weeks after travel.
500 mg once followed by 500 mg per dose in 6 hours, 24 hours, and 48 hours.
1000 mg once daily for 2 days followed by 500 mg daily for 2 to 3 weeks.
questions.rationale: For malaria prophylaxis, chloroquine is started 2 weeks before entering an endemic area and then continued for 8 weeks after leaving the area. The dose is 500 mg weekly.

questions.category: Chapter 31: Antimalarials, Anthelmintics, and Peptides
questions.stem: A patient is taking chloroquine to treat acute malaria. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of this medication?
options: “I should abstain from alcohol while taking this medication because the combination will make me violently ill.”
“I will have to take this medication indefinitely to avoid recurrence of my infection.”
“I should report visual changes immediately.”
“I should take this drug on an empty stomach.”
questions.rationale: Patients taking chloroquine should report any visual changes or symptoms to the provider. One does not need to abstain from alcohol, but if the patient drinks large amounts of alcohol or has a liver disorder, the liver enzymes will require closer monitoring. Chloroquine is not associated with disulfiram-like reactions. The patient will likely need to be on therapy for 2-3 weeks, not indefinitely.

questions.category: Chapter 31: Antimalarials, Anthelmintics, and Peptides
questions.stem: A patient will take an anthelmintic medication and asks the nurse about common side effects. The nurse will tell the patient that anthelmintic drugs
options: can cause hepatic toxicity.
most commonly cause orthostatic hypotension.
most commonly result in gastrointestinal (GI) side effects.
have many serious adverse reactions.
questions.rationale: Anthelmintic drugs have many GI side effects, including anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and cramps. Adverse reactions do not occur frequently given the short treatment duration of 1-3 days.

questions.category: Chapter 31: Antimalarials, Anthelmintics, and Peptides
questions.stem: A child is being treated for pinworms, and the parent asks the nurse how to prevent spreading this to other family members. What will the nurse tell the parent?
options: “Give your child baths every day.”
“Obtain a daily stool specimen from your child.”
“Change sheets, bedclothes, towels and underwear weekly.”
“Your child should wash hands well before meals and after using the toilet.”
questions.rationale: To prevent the spread of pinworms, good hand washing after toileting is recommended. Patients should take showers, not baths. It is not necessary to get regular stool specimens. Sheets, bedclothes, towels and underwear should ideally be changed daily.

questions.category: Chapter 31: Antimalarials, Anthelmintics, and Peptides
questions.stem: A child is prescribed pyrantel pamoate. The nurse understands that this is most likely prescribed to treat which condition?
options: Candidiasis
Schistosomiasis
Pinworms
Liver flukes
questions.rationale: Pyrantel pamoate is used to treat pinworms. Schistosomiasis and liver flukes are better treated with other anthelmintic products indicated to treat these conditions. Candidiasis would be treated with an antifungal agent.

questions.category: Chapter 31: Antimalarials, Anthelmintics, and Peptides
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer an intravenous polymyxin antibiotic. The patient reports dizziness along with numbness and tingling of the hands and feet. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Administer the drug since these are harmless side effects.
Hold the drug and notify the provider of these adverse reactions.
Obtain an order for an oral form of this medication.
Request an order for serum electrolytes.
questions.rationale: Polymyxins can cause nephrotoxicity and neurotoxicity. This patient has signs of neurotoxicity, so the nurse should notify the provider. These effects are generally reversible when the drug is discontinued. It is not correct to administer the drug when these symptoms are present. Polymyxins are not absorbed orally. Serum electrolytes are not indicated.

questions.category: Chapter 31: Antimalarials, Anthelmintics, and Peptides
questions.stem: A young adult female is prescribed metronidazole to treat trichomoniasis. Which of the following is FALSE regarding metronidazole?
options: Metronidazole is not appropriate for this patient because it is only indicated for bacterial infections.
Alcohol use is contraindicated.
Metronidazole is available in multiple dosage forms, including oral, topical, intravaginal, and IV products.
Metronidazole can be used for both bacterial and protozoal infections.
questions.rationale: Metronidazole can be used to treat both bacterial and protozoal infections and would be an appropriate therapy for treating trichomoniasis.

questions.category: Chapter 31: Antimalarials, Anthelmintics, and Peptides
questions.stem: A patient is prescribed ivermectin to treat onchocerciasis. The patient is currently taking warfarin and atorvastatin. Which of the following will the nurse recommend monitoring for in this patient?
options: Increase in INR
Decrease in INR
Increase in LDL cholesterol
Decrease in LDL cholesterol
questions.rationale: Ivermectin can interact with warfarin resulting in an increase in INR. There are no major concerns with ivermectin and LDL levels.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a 55-year-old patient who has been HIV-infected for 15 years. The nurse understands that this patient
options: has an increased risk of transmitting the HIV infection.
is less likely to develop AIDS than younger persons with HIV infection.
is less likely to respond to antiretroviral agents.
may have comorbid illnesses that can complicate HIV.
questions.rationale: Older HIV-infected patients may have age-related comorbid illness that can complicate management of HIV infection, such as renal dysfunction.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who is newly diagnosed with HIV infection after a recent exposure calls to report fever, sore throat, myalgia, and night sweats. The nurse will notify the provider that this patient is most likely experiencing which of the following?
options: Acute retroviral syndrome
AIDS
An increased viral load
An opportunistic infection
questions.rationale: Acute retroviral syndrome often occurs 2 to 12 weeks after exposure and is caused by rapid viral replication. This patient is likely experiencing symptoms of this syndrome. AIDS is a diagnosis that indicates advanced disease. Opportunistic infection symptoms are related to the type of infection.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: A patient with HIV infection has been receiving antiretroviral therapy for 4 months. At the initiation of treatment, the patient had a viral load of 60 copies/mL. Today's lab results reveal a viral load below the limit of detection (<20 copies/mL). How will the nurse interpret the patient's results?
options: A drug-resistant strain is likely.
The patient has achieved a key goal of therapy.
The patient should be assessed for drug non-adherence.
Treatment failure has occurred.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com A key goal of therapy is to achieve and maintain a viral load below the limits of detection (<20 to 40 copies/mL, depending on the assay used). This goal should be achieved in 16 to 24 weeks. Since this patient has achieved this goal, treatment should continue. A drug-resistant strain is not likely to respond to therapy. Response to therapy would not lead the nurse to expect medication non-adherence.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: A pregnant patient is HIV-positive. Which of the following is true of antiretroviral therapy during pregnancy?
options: To avoid toxicity to the fetus, antiretroviral therapy is discontinued during pregnancy.
To minimize toxicity to the fetus, antiretroviral monotherapy is used.
Combination antiretroviral drug therapy is the standard of care during pregnancy.
Intravenous antiretroviral therapy is absolutely contraindicated.
questions.rationale: To prevent mother-to-child transmission of HIV, ART is recommended in all pregnant patients who test positive for HIV infection, regardless of virologic, immunologic, or clinical parameters. Combination drug therapy is considered the standard of care for both treatment of maternal HIV infection and prophylaxis to reduce the risk for perinatal HIV transmission. The goal of ART is to achieve maximal and sustained viral suppression during pregnancy to prevent perinatal transmission of HIV. If viral load is greater than or equal to 400 copies/mL, IV zidovudine is recommended regardless of current ART.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who is HIV-positive begins combination therapy inclusive of zidovudine twice daily. The patient is in the clinic for follow-up 1 week after initiation of therapy and reports having nausea. The patient's creatinine clearance is estimated at 40 mL/minute. Based on these findings, the nurse will perform which action?
options: Instruct the patient to take the medication 60 minutes prior to meals.
Notify the provider to discuss dose adjustments.
Request an order for once-daily dosing of this medication.
Suggest that the patient increase fluid intake.
questions.rationale: NRTIs require dosage adjustment in persons with renal insufficiency. The patient will need single-dose medications so that adjustments can be made.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who has HIV infection will begin treatment with efavirenz. The nurse knows that which of the following should be performed prior to drug initiation:
options: Perform resistance testing prior to starting therapy www.NursingExamBank.com
Ensure the patient has failed protease inhibitor therapy
Allergy testing
Spinal tap
questions.rationale: A major disadvantage of NNRTI therapy is the high prevalence of NNRTI-resistant viral strains. Resistance testing is recommended for treatment-naïve patients before starting therapy. NNRTIs are often used first to reserve protease inhibitor therapy for future use. Allergy testing and spinal taps are not required prior to drug initiation.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who is HIV-infected takes 800 mg of indinavir, a protease inhibitor medication. The provider has ordered adding ritonavir to the regimen. The nurse will teach the patient that the addition of ritonavir
options: allows decreasing the dosing from 3 times daily to twice daily.
can lead to increased cholesterol and triglycerides.
may worsen insulin resistance.
will require increased dietary restrictions.
questions.rationale: Ritonavir boosting is a mainstay of protease inhibitor therapy and can reduce dosing frequency and pill burden as well as overcome viral resistance. It does not increase the likelihood of elevated cholesterol and triglycerides or insulin resistance and does not lead to increased dietary restrictions.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: A patient will begin taking the protease inhibitor combination Kaletra (lopinavir/ritonavir). What information will the nurse include when teaching the patient about dietary changes?
options: Consume a low-cholesterol diet.
Consume more acidic foods.
Take the pill on an empty stomach.
Take the pill with fatty foods.
questions.rationale: Protease inhibitors generally cause elevations of cholesterol and triglycerides, so patients should be counseled to consume a low-fat diet.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who has recently begun antiretroviral therapy with a combination drug develops immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) with mild symptoms. What does the nurse expect that the provider will recommend next?
options: Administration of an immunosuppressant
Changing the regimen to a single antiretroviral drug
Temporarily discontinuing the antiretroviral therapy
Treating an underlying opportunistic infection
questions.rationale: IRIS is related to specific opportunistic infections that must be treated. Anti-inflammatory medications, such as corticosteroids, may be used if indicated. Changing or discontinuing the antiretroviral therapy regimen is not indicated. Use of an immunosuppressant agent would not be appropriate.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who will begin antiretroviral therapy reports having trouble sticking with drug regimens in the past. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Ask the patient's family members to administer the medications.
Avoid discussing adverse effects to prevent focus on negative aspects of ART.
Give a detailed list of medications and stress the need to adhere to the schedule.
Offer written and verbal information about each drug's purpose.
questions.rationale: Patients often are more motivated to adhere to a drug regimen if they understand the purpose of the medications. Patients should be encouraged to take responsibility for their medications. Side effects need to be discussed so patients can plan ways to manage these before they occur.

questions.category: Chapter 32: HIV- and AIDS-Related Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is HIV-positive and has been receiving antiretroviral therapy for several months. The nurse experiences a needlestick injury resulting in exposure to the patient's blood. The nurse asks the Occupational Health nurse if treatment is necessary. How will the Occupational Health nurse respond?
options: “No treatment is necessary since the patient is receiving antiretroviral therapy.”
“We will treat you if the patient's viral load is greater than 20 copies/mL.”
“You will require 4 weeks of antiretroviral therapy.”
“You will undergo HIV testing and will be treated if you are positive.”
questions.rationale: Persons exposed to the blood of HIV-infected patients should receive 4 weeks of antiretroviral therapy.

questions.category: Chapter 33: Transplant Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who will begin taking basiliximab in conjunction with a kidney transplant. Which of the following would be appropriate to include when counseling the patient?
options: The drug is used to boost the immune system.
The drug is taken by mouth before and after the transplant surgery.
Nausea, vomiting, fever, and chills are common side effects.
Basiliximab is primarily used for patients receiving a heart transplant.
questions.rationale: Nausea, vomiting, fever, and chills are common side effects. Basiliximab provides intense immunosuppression to reduce the risk for acute rejection during the initial transplant period. The drug is administered intravenously. Basiliximab is approved for induction therapy in kidney transplant patients.

questions.category: Chapter 33: Transplant Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who has had an organ transplant is prescribed cyclosporine for maintenance therapy. Which statement by the patient indicates further teaching is needed?
options: “I will have to have blood tests drawn regularly while taking this medication.”
“I should avoid drinking grapefruit juice while on this medication.”
“I have to avoid receiving live vaccines.”
“Cyclosporine can cause my blood sugar to drop too low.”
questions.rationale: Cyclosporine, a calcineurin inhibitor, can cause hyperglycemia and place people at increased risk for developing diabetes. Therapeutic drug monitoring and safety labs are required. Grapefruit juice can affect the metabolism of cyclosporine and should be avoided. Patients should not receive live vaccines while taking cyclosporine.

questions.category: Chapter 33: Transplant Drugs
questions.stem: Your patient is taking belatacept and develops posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder (PTLD). PTLD primarily affects
options: the liver.
the heart.
the kidneys.
the central nervous system.
questions.rationale: PTLD primarily affects the central nervous system. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 33: Transplant Drugs
questions.stem: Combination of corticosteroids with certain antibiotics can result in which of the following?
options: Increased risk of QT prolongation and arrhythmias
Increased risk of hypokalemia
Increased risk of hyperglycemia
Increased risk of ophthalmic toxicity
questions.rationale: Chronic corticosteroid therapy with macrolide antibiotics increases the risk of ventricular arrhythmias. Combination of corticosteroids with diuretics can increase the risk of hypokalemia. Corticosteroid use in general is associated with risk of hyperglycemia and ophthalmic toxicity.

questions.category: Chapter 33: Transplant Drugs
questions.stem: The patient tells the nurse that he understands that transplant rejection may happen and asks what can be done to minimize risk of rejection and other negative outcomes. What will the nurse include in the teaching?
options: “An anti-T-cell antibody should be used in conjunction with corticosteroid therapy for best results.”
“ATG rabbit started immediately after transplant can help prevent rejection.”
“Transplant rejection drugs can be used and while they have unwanted side effects, none are deadly.”
“Caution needs to be taken when other immunosuppressant drugs are administered to avoid serious infections.”
questions.rationale: Caution needs to be taken when other immunosuppressant drugs are administered because of the increased risk of serious infection. Treatment of rejection with an anti-T-cell antibody is used when corticosteroids have failed to reverse rejection or for treatment of a recurrent rejection. ATG rabbit is indicated to manage transplant rejection, but would not be used prophylactically to prevent rejection immediately after transplant. These drugs have unwanted side effects, some of which are serious and potentially deadly.

questions.category: Chapter 33: Transplant Drugs
questions.stem: The patient on immunosuppressant medications is speaking to the nurse about appropriate activities. Which statement requires intervention? (Select all that apply.)
options: “I am going to the state fair with my friends.” www.NursingExamBank.com
“I enjoy working in my garden to relax.”
“I will brush my teeth after meals.”
“It's OK to eat fresh fruits and vegetables.” e. “I should get a new glass, if the one I am drinking from has been sitting out.” f. “I should bathe daily, using an antimicrobial soap.”
questions.rationale: , B, D Immunosuppressed patients should stay away from crowds and people who are sick. Fresh flowers, live plants, gardening, and standing water should be avoided. One should brush teeth at least twice a day with a soft toothbrush and bathe daily. In general, the patient should avoid activities that increase the risk of exposure to bacteria/germs.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: The nurse is discussing vaccines with the mother of a 4-year-old child who attends a day care center that requires the diphtheria, tetanus, acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccine. The mother, who is pregnant, tells the nurse that she does not want her child to receive the pertussis vaccine because she has heard that the disease is “not that serious” in older children. What information will the nurse include when discussing this with the mother?
options: If she gets the vaccine, both she and her 4-year-old child will be protected.
If the 4-year-old child contracts pertussis, it can be passed on to her newborn.
The vaccine will not be given to her child while she is pregnant.
Vaccinating the 4-year-old will provide passive immunity for her unborn child.
questions.rationale: Even though pertussis is not as serious in older children, it is important to vaccinate children to prevent the spread of the disease to infants and others who are not immunized and who are at risk for significant morbidity and mortality from this disease. Vaccinating the mother will not protect the 4-year-old from getting pertussis. The DTaP vaccine may be given to children whose mothers are pregnant. Vaccinating the child does not confer passive immunity to the unborn child.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: A 32-year-old woman who is pregnant tells the nurse she has not had any vaccines but wants to begin so that she can protect her unborn child. Which vaccine listed below would be most appropriate to administer to this patient?
options: Human papillomavirus (HPV) quadrivalent vaccine
Trivalent influenza vaccine www.NursingExamBank.com
Measles–mumps–rubella (MMR) vaccine
Varicella vaccine
questions.rationale: The influenza vaccine is recommended for everyone 6 months and older, including pregnant women. Pregnant women should not receive the live attenuated influenza vaccine, however. HPV quadrivalent vaccine is given to preteen boys and girls at age 11 or 12 so they are protected before virus exposure. HPV quadrivalent vaccine can be administered in women and men through age 26. The MMR is contraindicated because rubella can cause serious teratogenic effects. Varicella is contraindicated during pregnancy.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: A 4-year-old child is receiving amoxicillin to treat otitis media and is in the clinic for a well- child checkup on the last day of antibiotic therapy. The provider orders varicella; measles– mumps–rubella (MMR); inactivated polio (IPV); and diphtheria, tetanus, and acellular pertussis (DTaP) vaccines to be given. Which action by the nurse is correct?
options: Administer the vaccines as ordered.
Discuss giving the MMR vaccine in 4 weeks.
Hold all vaccines until 2 weeks after antibiotic therapy.
Recommend aspirin for fever and discomfort.
questions.rationale: Antibiotic therapy is not generally a contraindication to the use of vaccines. Vaccines may be given in cases of mild acute illness or during the convalescent phase of an illness. All four vaccines may be given. If the MMR or other live virus vaccine is not given the same day as the varicella vaccine, administration of the two vaccines should be separated by at least 4 weeks. Aspirin should not be given because of the increased risk of Reye syndrome.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: A patient is preparing to travel with a 4-year-old child to India in 15 days and is in the clinic to receive typhoid vaccines. Which vaccines will be given to the parent and the child?
options: Four capsules of live, oral vaccine to both patients.
Four capsules of live, oral vaccine for the parent and the intramuscular (IM) polysaccharide vaccine for the child.
Four capsules of live, oral vaccine for the child and the IM polysaccharide vaccine for the parent.
IM polysaccharide for both patients.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com While the live, oral vaccine may be given to patients older than 6 years, each capsule must be taken 48 hours apart with the last capsule given 1 week prior to travel. There would not be enough time to complete the regimen since the patients leave in 15 days. Children under age 6 cannot receive the oral vaccine. The IM polysaccharide vaccine should be administered at least 2 weeks before the expected exposure.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: A 48-month-old child is scheduled to receive the following vaccines: MMR, varicella vaccine, IPV, and DTaP. The child's parents want the child to receive two vaccines today and the other two in 1 week. To accommodate the parents' wishes, the nurse will administer
options: the DTaP and varicella vaccine today and the MMR and IPV in 1 week.
the IPV and MMR today and the varicella vaccine and DTaP in 1 week.
the MMR and DTaP today and the varicella vaccine and IPV in 1 week.
the MMR and varicella vaccine today and the DTaP and IPV in 1 week.
questions.rationale: If the MMR or other live virus vaccine is not given the same day as the varicella vaccine, administration of the two vaccines should be separated by at least 4 weeks. In the incorrect answers, the two live virus vaccines are given only 1 week apart.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: A young adult patient is in the clinic to receive a tetanus vaccine after sustaining a laceration injury. The nurse learns that the patient, who works in a day care center, has not had any vaccines for more than 10 years. Which vaccine will the nurse expect to administer?
options: DT
DTaP
Td
Tdap
questions.rationale: Persons who work with children should receive acellular pertussis vaccine. The Tdap is given to adults. The DTaP is given to children up to age 6. The DT and Td do not contain pertussis.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer rotavirus vaccine to a 4-month-old infant. The nurse notes that the infant received RV1 vaccine at 2 months of age. The nurse will plan to administer which of the following?
options: RV1 today
RV1 today and again at age 6 months
RV5 today www.NursingExamBank.com
RV5 today and again at age 6 months
questions.rationale: Patients receiving RV1 receive 2 doses at age 2 and 4 months only.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: A provider has ordered recombinant HPV quadrivalent vaccine to be given to a prepubertal 11- year-old female. The parent asks the nurse if this vaccine can be postponed until the child is in high school. The nurse will tell the parent that the vaccine
options: is less effective in older adolescents.
is more effective if given before sexual activity begins.
is more effective if given prior to the hormonal changes of puberty.
is not effective if given after the onset of menses.
questions.rationale: The HPV quadrivalent vaccine is most effective when the client is not yet sexually active. Ideally, the vaccine is administered to preteen boys and girls at age 11 or 12, but can be given through age 26.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: Which is an example of acquired passive immunity?
options: Administration of IgG to an unimmunized person exposed to a disease
Administration of an antigen via an immunization
Inherent resistance to a disease antigen
Immune response to an attenuated virus
questions.rationale: Passive immunity occurs without stimulation of an immune response. Acquired immunity requires administration of immune globulin. Inherent resistance to a disease antigen describes the state of natural immunity, not acquired passive immunity. The other answers involve stimulation of an immune response.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: The parent of a 12-month-old child who has received the MMR, varicella, and hepatitis A vaccines calls the clinic to report redness and swelling at the vaccine injection sites and a temperature of 100.3 F. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Recommend aspirin or a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) for pain and fever.
Recommend acetaminophen and cold compresses.
Report these adverse effects to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS).
Schedule an appointment in clinic so the provider can evaluate the child. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: These are common, minor side effects of vaccines and can be treated with acetaminophen and cold compresses. Aspirin is contraindicated in children because of its association with Reye's syndrome. Since these are not serious adverse effects, they do not need to be reported to VAERS. It is not necessary to schedule a clinic visit, but the parent should be encouraged to re- contact the clinic if symptoms do not improve.

questions.category: Chapter 34: Vaccines
questions.stem: The provider orders the zoster vaccine for a 60-year-old patient. The patient reports having had chicken pox as a child. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Administer the vaccine as ordered.
Counsel the patient that the vaccine may cause a severe reaction because of previous exposure.
Hold the vaccine and notify the provider of the patient's history.
Request an order for a varicella booster instead of the zoster vaccine.
questions.rationale: The zoster vaccine is given to boost the immunity to varicella-zoster virus among recipients. It is not likely to cause severe reaction secondary to prior exposure, since the immune response in most recipients has declined.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who has cancer is about to begin chemotherapy. The patient asks the nurse why two chemotherapeutic agents are being used instead of just one. Which response by the nurse is correct?
options: “The drugs may be given in less toxic doses if two drugs are used.”
“Two agents used together can have synergistic effects.”
“Use of two drugs will increase tumoricidal activity in the G0 phase of the cell.”
“Using two agents will shorten the length of time chemotherapy is needed.”
questions.rationale: Using two or more chemotherapeutic agents can have a synergistic effect. Combination therapy typically uses two drugs with different dose-limiting toxicities, but the use of more than one drug does not allow for using less toxic doses. Combination therapy allows cell kill in all phases of the cell cycle. Combination therapy does not shorten the length of time chemotherapy is needed.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who is about to begin chemotherapy asks the nurse when the risk of infection is highest. The nurse will tell the patient that infection risk is greatest at which point?
options: A week to 10 days after each chemotherapy dose
During the week immediately after chemotherapy
Immediately prior to each dose of chemotherapy
When the patient's temperature is elevated by 1 F
questions.rationale: Following chemotherapy administration, the time at which the blood count, including white blood cells, is lowest is typically 7 to 10 days after treatment.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving a third dose of high-dose cyclophosphamide. The nurse notes hematuria. The nurse will notify the provider and will perform which action?
options: Ask whether the patient takes allopurinol.
Assess the patient's skin and fingernails for darkening.
Question the patient about fluid intake.
Reassure the patient that this is an expected side effect.
questions.rationale: Hemorrhagic cystitis is a common adverse effect of high-dose cyclophosphamide and can be mitigated by increasing fluid intake. Allopurinol is given to treat gout, which is characterized by uric acid crystalluria. Darkening of the fingernails and skin is a common adverse effect of cyclophosphamide but is unrelated to hemorrhagic cystitis.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient is prescribed raloxifene as a cancer prophylactic agent. Which type of cancer is this being used to prevent?
options: Prostate cancer
Colon cancer
Multiple myeloma
Breast cancer
questions.rationale: Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs) such as tamoxifen and raloxifene have both estrogenic and antiestrogenic effects on various tissues. Tamoxifen is primarily used for breast cancer in both men and women. Raloxifene produces estrogenic effects in bone and lipids and has an antiestrogenic property in mammary tissues. It is used as a prophylactic against breast cancer in high-risk postmenopausal women with osteoporosis. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who will take oral cyclophosphamide. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “I should follow a diet high in organ meats and beans while taking this drug.”
“I should brush my teeth and gums vigorously twice daily.”
“I should report any low-grade temperature elevation immediately.”
“I should take the drug at bedtime to minimize side effects.”
questions.rationale: Even a low-grade temperature should be reported because it can indicate significant infection in immunocompromised patients. Patients should eat a low-purine diet while taking this medication. Patients should brush teeth and gums with a soft bristle toothbrush. Patients should take the medication early in the day to avoid accumulation in the bladder.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient is receiving bleomycin as part of a chemotherapeutic regimen to treat leukemia. During IV administration of this drug, what will the nurse observe the patient closely for?
options: Hypotension and visual disturbances
Pain and blistering at the IV site
Pink to red urine
Shortness of breath and wheezing
questions.rationale: Bleomycin can cause anaphylaxis, so patients should be monitored for respiratory distress. Pain and blistering at theIV site is common to antitumor antibiotics, except for bleomycin. Urine color changes occur with doxorubicin. Vincristine causes hypotension and visual disturbances.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient is receiving theantitumor antibiotic doxorubicin to treat lung cancer. thepatient is experiencing shortness of breath and palpitations. thenurse is concerned that thepatient has developed which condition?
options: Anemia
Cardiotoxicity
Hypersensitivity
Pulmonary infection
questions.rationale: Cardiotoxicity is a known adverse effect of this drug and is manifested in shortness of breath, edema, and palpitations.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving vincristine, a plant alkaloid chemotherapeutic agent, to treat non-Hodgkin lymphoma. thenurse observes that thepatient has difficulty walking. What action will thenurse take?
options: Ask about numbness or tingling in thefingers and toes.
Assess heart rate and blood pressure to evaluate for orthostatic hypotension.
Assess thetemperature to evaluate for infection.
Request an order for a complete blood count and electrolytes.
questions.rationale: Peripheral neuropathy can occur with this drug and is manifested by difficulty in walking and numbness and tingling in thefingers and toes. Orthostatic hypotension is not a side effect. Infection is always a concern, and regular evaluation of complete blood count and electrolytes is performed but not related to signs of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: A woman who has advanced breast cancer will begin receiving androgen therapy. thenurse will explain to thepatient that androgen therapy is used to
options: enhance her own estrogen production.
give her a sense of well-being.
minimize hot flashes.
oppose theactivity of estrogen.
questions.rationale: Androgen is used to treat breast cancer to promote regression of tumors by opposing theactivity of estrogen. Exogenous androgen therapy is most effective for palliative treatment of breast cancer among postmenopausal women. Other hormonal therapies are used in other circumstances to promote well-being and treat hot flashes.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who is receiving vincristine about long-term management of thetreatment regimen. Which information will thenurse provide in teaching thepatient?
options: “If you experience numbness of your hands, it will eventually resolve.”
“If your IV starts to hurt, you should pull theIV out immediately.”
“You should ask for anti-nausea medication at thefirst sign of nausea.”
“You should report difficulty buttoning your clothes to your provider.”
questions.rationale: Difficulty buttoning clothing is a sign of peripheral neuropathy and should be reported. Numbness of hands may resolve after chemotherapy is stopped, but it may never resolve. If theIV infiltrates, theinfusion should be stopped and theneedle left in until attempts to aspirate residual vesicant are performed. Anti-nausea medication should be given prior to beginning theinfusion.

questions.category: Chapter 35: Anticancer Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving 5-fluorouracil (5-FU) to treat pancreatic cancer. Which interventions are included in thenurse's plan of care for this patient? (Select all that apply.)
options: Apply ice to theIV site if thepatient reports pain.
Administer antiemetics when thepatient reports nausea.
Counsel thepatient to use waxed dental floss.
Discourage visits with people who have respiratory infections. e. Offer ice chips frequently. f. Restrict to nothing by mouth during IV drug administration.
questions.rationale: , C, D, E If thepatient reports pain at theIV site, thenurse should apply ice and notify theprovider. Patients should use waxed dental floss to avoid bleeding of thegums. Advise patient not to visit anyone who has a respiratory infection. Ice chips help with oral pain. Antiemetics should be given prior to administration of thedrug. Patients do not need to be nothing per os (NPO) during theIV infusion.

questions.category: Chapter 36: Targeted Therapies to Treat Cancer
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who will begin receiving targeted therapy for cancer. thepatient asks how targeted therapy differs from other types of chemotherapies. thenurse will explain that targeted therapy
options: damages cancer cell DNA to prevent cell replication.
directly kills or damages cancerous cells.
interferes with specific molecules in cancer cells.
prevents metastasis of cancer cells.
questions.rationale: Targeted therapy differs from traditional cancer chemotherapy by taking advantage of biologic features particular to cancer cells and targeting specific mechanisms. They block thegrowth and spread of cancer by interfering with specific molecules within thecancer cells. Traditional chemotherapeutic agents damage cell DNA of cancer cells as well as normal cells. Targeted therapies do not directly kill or damage cancer cells or prevent metastasis.

questions.category: Chapter 36: Targeted Therapies to Treat Cancer
questions.stem: A patient who has metastatic colorectal cancer tells thenurse that a cousin who had colorectal cancer received bevacizumab and wonders how thedrug works. thenurse will explain that bevacizumab works by targeting which of thefollowing?
options: HER2 receptors
Epidermal growth factor receptor-tyrosine kinase
The BRCA1 suppressor gene
Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) proteins
questions.rationale: Bevacizumab acts by blocking VEGF (vascular endothelial growth factor); blocking VEGF may prevent thegrowth of new blood vessels, including those that may feed thetumor.

questions.category: Chapter 36: Targeted Therapies to Treat Cancer
questions.stem: The nurse is performing a history on a patient who will begin taking bevacizumab. Which aspect of thepatient's history should be reported to theoncologist treating this patient?
options: History of hepatitis
Hypertension
Recent treatment for a GI obstruction
Weight loss
questions.rationale: Bevacizumab carries a warning for gastrointestinal obstruction or perforation.

questions.category: Chapter 36: Targeted Therapies to Treat Cancer
questions.stem: The patient asks thenurse what apoptosis means. thenurse will explain that apoptosis refers to
options: alteration of cellular functions.
inhibition of cell division.
prevention of cell phase progression.
slow, planned cellular death.
questions.rationale: Apoptosis is programmed cell death, designed to ensure that tissues contain only healthy and optimally functional cells.

questions.category: Chapter 36: Targeted Therapies to Treat Cancer
questions.stem: Which of thefollowing agents is NOT an epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) inhibitor?
options: Alectinib
Erlotinib www.NursingExamBank.com
Gefitinib
Osimertinib
questions.rationale: Alectinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor. Erlotinib, gefitinib and osimertinib are all EGFR inhibitors.

questions.category: Chapter 36: Targeted Therapies to Treat Cancer
questions.stem: The nurse performs a medication history on a patient who will begin targeted therapy for cancer with gefitinib. thenurse learns that thepatient is taking carbamazepine, a histamine 2 blocker, and warfarin. thenurse will anticipate that theprovider will make which change to themedication regimen?
options: Decrease thegefitinib dose.
Decrease thewarfarin dose.
Increase thehistamine2 blocker dose.
Increase thecarbamazepine dose.
questions.rationale: When patients taking warfarin take gefitinib, theeffectiveness of thewarfarin is greatly increased, and bleeding risk increases. Carbamazepine and histamine2 blockers decrease theeffectiveness of gefitinib, so decreasing thegefitinib dose or decreasing thecarbamazepine or histamine2 blocker is not recommended.

questions.category: Chapter 36: Targeted Therapies to Treat Cancer
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer intravenous temsirolimus. To prevent a common adverse drug effect, thenurse will expect to administer which type of drug?
options: An antibiotic www.NursingExamBank.com
An anticoagulant
An antiemetic
An antihistamine
questions.rationale: Hypersensitivity reactions to temsirolimus are common, and pretreatment with antihistamines is recommended. Other drugs are given as needed but not prophylactically.

questions.category: Chapter 36: Targeted Therapies to Treat Cancer
questions.stem: A patient who is taking thetyrosine kinase inhibitor sunitinib calls to report red, painful, and swollen palms and soles of feet. thenurse will perform which action?
options: Notify thepatient's provider of this adverse reaction.
Reassure thepatient that these are common side effects.
Recommend taking acetaminophen for discomfort.
Suggest taking diphenhydramine to help with theswelling.
questions.rationale: The nurse should notify theprovider if thepatient reports these symptoms, since they may indicate erythrodysesthesia. Reassuring thepatient or recommending over-the-counter treatments is not indicated.

questions.category: Chapter 36: Targeted Therapies to Treat Cancer
questions.stem: What action is most important for thenurse to teach thepatient taking imatinib?
options: “The medication will cause thestool to be black; do not worry about that.”
“Acetaminophen can be used for headaches.”
“Limit your fluid intake to 1 liter each day.”
“Be diligent about using birth control while you are on this medication.”
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Women should avoid pregnancy throughout treatment and for up to 12 months after treatment is complete. Black stools should be reported immediately. Acetaminophen is metabolized in theliver and should be avoided while on this drug. Fluids are encouraged.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: A patient is receiving interferon alpha subcutaneously. thepatient experiences chills, fatigue, and malaise, and thenurse assesses a temperature of 102 F. thenurse will notify theprovider of thetemperature and will anticipate which order?
options: Administer acetaminophen.
Change to intravenous (IV) interferon alpha.
Give diphenhydramine.
Obtain a serum blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine level.
questions.rationale: The major side effects of interferon are flulike symptoms with chills, fever, fatigue, malaise, and myalgia. Acetaminophen is given to treat this initially. Changing to an IV form does not alter theside effects. Diphenhydramine is given to reduce histamine effects. It is not necessary to obtain laboratory work when these symptoms initially occur.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: Prior to administration of interferon alpha, thenurse will administer which medications?
options: Acetaminophen and diphenhydramine www.NursingExamBank.com
Heparin and meperidine
Lorazepam and furosemide
Narcotic analgesics and loratadine
questions.rationale: Patients receiving these drugs should be premedicated with acetaminophen to reduce chills and fever and with diphenhydramine to reduce histamine effects.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: Which of thefollowing is an indication for use of IFN-□?
options: Chronic granulomatous disease
Hairy cell leukemia
Multiple sclerosis
Kaposi sarcoma
questions.rationale: Interferon beta is indicated for treatment of relapsing-remitting forms of multiple sclerosis. Interferon gamma is used to treat chronic granulomatous disease. Interferon alfa-2b is indicated to treat hairy cell leukemia and Kaposi sarcoma.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: A patient who has cancer will begin treatment with a colony-stimulating factor. thepatient verbalizes understanding of why thedrug is being used with which statement?
options: “This drug permits use of higher doses of chemotherapy.”
“This drug has antitumor activity.”
“This drug has cytotoxic effects.”
“This drug has antiviral effects.” www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Colony-stimulating factors permit thedelivery of higher doses of drugs because they counter myelosuppression. They do not have antitumor activity, cytotoxic effects, or antiviral effects.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: A patient is receiving theerythropoietin-stimulating agent (ESA) epoetin alfa. Which assessment finding would cause thenurse to notify thepatient's provider?
options: Blood pressure of 90/65 mm Hg
Headache and nausea
Hemoglobin >11 g/dL
Infiltration of theIV
questions.rationale: There is an increased risk of serious cardiovascular events and death when hemoglobin is greater than 11 g/dL. There is no need to notify theprovider of theother findings.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: A patient who is receiving cancer chemotherapy has been ordered to receive epoetin alfa 150 units/kg 3 times weekly. thenurse reviews thepatient's chart and notes a hemoglobin level of 10.9 g/dL. thenurse will perform which action?
options: Administer themedication as ordered.
Hold thedose and notify theprovider.
Reduce thedose by 25%.
Request an order for an increased dose.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com For patients receiving cancer chemotherapy, ESAs should not be initiated at a hemoglobin level greater than or equal to 11 g/dL. Because thepatient has a hemoglobin of 10.9 g/dL it would be prudent to hold thedose and notify theprovider to determine next steps.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: A patient has been receiving an ESA for 8 weeks. thenurse reviews thepatient's chart and notes no increase in hemoglobin levels from 8 g/dL on week 3 of therapy. thenurse will request an order for which of thefollowing?
options: A complete blood count and serum iron levels
An increased dose of theESA
More frequent dosing of theESA
Packed red blood cell infusions
questions.rationale: If there is no response, ESAs should be discontinued after 8 weeks of therapy. If a patient does not respond, iron deficiency or underlying hematologic disease should be considered and evaluated.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: A patient is receiving bone marrow transplantation for cancer and receives filgrastim. thepatient reports severe abdominal pain in theleft upper quadrant. thenurse will perform which action?
options: Administer acetaminophen 650 mg.
Administer an antiemetic medication.
Report a potentially life-threatening event.
Request an order for cardiac enzyme levels.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Splenic rupture can occur with this drug and is manifested by pain in theleft upper quadrant. thenurse should report theabdominal pain to theprovider so thepatient can be evaluated for splenic rupture.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: A patient with cancer is receiving aldesleukin. thepatient reports black stools, which thenurse recognizes as
options: a sign of cancer metastasis.
an indication of gastrointestinal bleeding.
caused by inadequate hydration.
renal failure.
questions.rationale: Black stools suggest gastrointestinal bleeding, an absolute contraindication for aldesleukin. It is not a sign of cancer metastasis, inadequate hydration, or renal failure.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to give sargramostim to a patient who has acute myelogenous leukemia. thenurse assesses a heart rate of 78 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 120/70 mm Hg. thepatient reports shortness of breath and has a cough and bilateral crackles. What will thenurse do next?
options: Contact theprovider; discuss giving a lower dose.
Contact thepharmacist; request a bronchodilator.
Contact thepharmacist; request an order for furosemide.
Contact theprovider; suggest administration of antibiotics.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Patients receiving this drug can experience sequestration of granulocytes in thepulmonary circulation and may experience dyspnea. thesargramostim infusion should be reduced by half if this occurs. Bronchospasm, pulmonary edema, and infection are not common side effects. Calling thepharmacist to request medication is an incorrect nursing action; antibiotics are not warranted in this situation.

questions.category: Chapter 37: Biologic Response Modifiers
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer interleukin-2 (aldesleukin) to a patient who has cancer. thepatient reports shortness of breath. thenurse assesses clear breath sounds, a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, a heart rate of 80 beats per minute, an oxygen saturation of 88% on room air, and a blood pressure of 92/68 mm Hg. thenurse will perform which action?
options: Administer thedose as ordered.
