questions.rationale: Patients taking antihyperlipidemics should be advised to increase fluid intake. It is not necessary to take with food. Patients should never stop taking a statin without consulting the provider. Patients should continue a low-fat diet while taking statins.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Antihyperlipidemics and Drugs to Improve Peripheral Blood Flow
questions.stem: A patient has been prescribed cilostazol. Which statement by the client indicates the need for further teaching?
options: “I can take the medication with food if it causes nausea.”
“This medication is used to improve blood flow.”
“I can continue to take ginkgo biloba to improve my memory.”
“I should be cautious when standing.”
questions.rationale: Cilostazol should not be taken with ginkgo biloba because bleeding time can be prolonged. It can cause nausea so the nurse should recommend taking the medication with food. Cilostazol does cause vasodilation and improves blood flow which can also cause peripheral edema. Caution should be taken when standing for long periods.

questions.category: Chapter 44: Antihyperlipidemics and Drugs to Improve Peripheral Blood Flow
questions.stem: A patient with high cholesterol is ordered to take atorvastatin. What information will be included in the patient teaching? (Select all that apply.)
options: Dietary management is not a priority with this medication.
The medication should be taken on an empty stomach.
The medicine should be taken with a full glass of water.

The patient should watch for body aches or gastrointestinal upset as side effects. e. The patient should have renal function tests frequently. f. The patient should have periodic liver function testing.
questions.rationale: , D, F This medication is most effective with careful monitoring of diet. Atorvastatin does not affect renal function.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who experiences motion sickness when flying asks the nurse the best time to take over- the-counter antiemetic medications to prevent motion sickness for a 0900 flight. The nurse will instruct the patient to take the medication at which time?
options: As needed, at the first sign of nausea
At 0700, before leaving for the airport
At 0830, just prior to boarding the plane
When seated, just prior to takeoff
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Antiemetics have a general onset of action of 30 minutes. The patient should be instructed to take the medication a half hour prior to takeoff. These products are ideally used prior to the onset of motion sickness, not used as needed.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has unexplained, recurrent vomiting and who is unable to keep anything down. Until the cause of the vomiting is determined, the nurse will anticipate administering which medications?
options: Antibiotics and antiemetics
Intravenous fluids and electrolytes
Nonprescription antiemetics
Prescription antiemetics
questions.rationale: Antiemetics can mask the underlying cause of vomiting and should not be used until the cause is determined unless vomiting is so severe that dehydration and electrolyte imbalance occur. Nonpharmacologic measures, such as fluid and electrolyte replacement, should be used. Antibiotics are only used if an infectious cause is determined.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: The parent of an 18-month-old toddler calls the clinic to report that the child has vomited 5 times that day. The nurse determines that the child has had three wet diapers in the past 6 hours. What will the nurse recommend for this child?
options: Administering an OTC antiemetic medication such as diphenhydramine
Giving frequent, small amounts of Pedialyte
Keeping the child NPO until vomiting subsides
Taking the child to the emergency department for IV fluids www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: The child is not dehydrated as evidenced by adequate wet diapers, so nonpharmacologic measures, such as oral fluids, are recommended. OTC antiemetics are not recommended unless dehydration occurs. Intravenous fluids are given when dehydration is present.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who is about to take a long car trip about using dimenhydrinate to prevent motion sickness. What information is important to include when teaching this patient?
options: “Do not drive while taking this medication.”
“Dry mouth is a sign of toxicity with this medication.”
“Take the medication 1 to 2 hours prior to beginning the trip.”
“Take 100 mg up to 6 times daily for best effect.”
questions.rationale: Drowsiness is a common side effect of dimenhydrinate, so patients should be cautioned against driving while taking this drug. Dry mouth is a common side effect and not a sign of toxicity. The drug should be taken 30 minutes prior to travel. The maximum recommended dose is 400 mg per day.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has postoperative nausea and vomiting. The surgeon has ordered promethazine. Which aspect of this patient's health history would be of concern?
options: Asthma
Diabetes
GERD www.NursingExamBank.com
Glaucoma
questions.rationale: Promethazine is contraindicated in patients with glaucoma since it is an anticholinergic medication. It should be used with caution in patients with asthma. The other two conditions are not concerning with this medication.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a group of nursing students about the use of antipsychotic drugs for antiemetic purposes. The nurse will explain that, when given as antiemetics, these drugs are given
options: in smaller doses.
less frequently.
with anticholinergics.
with antihistamines.
questions.rationale: Antipsychotic medications are used in smaller doses when administered for antiemetic purposes.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who is receiving chemotherapy will be given dronabinol to prevent nausea and vomiting. The nurse will tell the patient that this drug will be given at which time?
options: Before and after the chemotherapy
During chemotherapy
Immediately prior to chemotherapy
24 hours prior to chemotherapy
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Cannabinoids are indicated for use prior to and after chemotherapy. Dronabinol is given 1-3 hours prior to chemotherapy and then every 2-4 hours after.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: A woman who is 2 months pregnant reports having morning sickness every day and asks if she can take any medications to treat this problem. The nurse will recommend that the patient try which intervention first?
options: Discuss a possible need for intravenous fluids with her provider.
Contacting the provider to discuss prescribing a prescription antiemetic.
Use nonpharmacologic measures, such as eating crackers or dry toast.
Take over-the-counter antiemetics such as diphenhydramine.
questions.rationale: To minimize risk to the fetus, the nurse should first recommend nonpharmacologic measures such as drinking flat soda or weak tea or eating crackers or dry toast. If this is not effective, intravenous fluids may become necessary depending on the severity of vomiting and dehydration. Pregnant women should consult with their provider before taking prescription or over-the-counter antiemetics.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: The parent of a child who is receiving chemotherapy asks the nurse why metoclopramide is not being used to suppress vomiting. The nurse will explain that, in children, this drug is more likely to cause which adverse effect?
options: Excess sedation
Extrapyramidal symptoms
Paralytic ileus
Vertigo www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Metoclopramide can cause extrapyramidal symptoms, and these effects are more likely in children. Children are not more prone to sedative effects, paralytic ileus, or vertigo while taking this drug.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: A child has been prescribed activated charcoal. What is the likely reason this is being ordered?
options: Ingestion of a toxic substance
Severe vomiting
Nausea
Motion sickness
questions.rationale: Activated charcoal is given to prevent the absorption of ingested toxic substances. Activated charcoal does not have a role in the treatment of nausea, vomiting or motion sickness.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: A patient asks the nurse about using loperamide to treat infectious diarrhea. Which response will the nurse give?
options: “Loperamide results in many central nervous system (CNS) side effects.”
“Loperamide has no effect on infectious diarrhea.”
“Loperamide is taken once daily.”
“Loperamide can be used to treat diarrheal symptoms but may also slow the exit of the infectious organisms from the GI tract.”
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Patients with infectious diarrhea should be cautioned about using loperamide since slowing transit through the intestines may prolong the exposure to the infectious agent. Loperamide causes less CNS depression than other antidiarrheals. It is taken multiple times per day as needed.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: A child is brought to the emergency department after ingestion of a toxic substance. The child is alert and conscious and is reported to have ingested kerosene 20 minutes prior. The nurse will anticipate administering
options: activated charcoal.
an anticholinergic antiemetic.
an antihistamine.
syrup of ipecac.
questions.rationale: Activated charcoal is used when patients have ingested a caustic substance or a petroleum distillate in a patient who is alert and awake. Syrup of ipecac is not recommended. An anticholinergic or antihistamine would not be indicated.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who is taking diphenoxylate with atropine to treat diarrhea asks the nurse why it contains atropine. The nurse will explain that atropine is added, in part, to
options: decrease abdominal cramping.
increase intestinal motility.
minimize nausea and vomiting.
provide analgesia. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Atropine is added to decrease abdominal cramping and slow intestinal motility through its anticholinergic effects. It does not affect nausea and vomiting or pain.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for an older adult who is receiving diphenoxylate with atropine to treat severe diarrhea. The nurse will monitor this patient closely for which effect?
options: Bradycardia
Fluid retention
Urinary incontinence
Respiratory depression
questions.rationale: Diphenoxylate is an opioid agonist and can cause respiratory depression. Children and older adults are more susceptible to this effect. It contains atropine, so it will increase heart rate and potentially contribute to urinary retention. It does not contribute to fluid retention.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: A patient asks the nurse the best way to prevent traveler's diarrhea. The nurse will provide which recommendation to the patient?
options: “Ask your provider for prophylactic antibiotics.”
“Drink bottled water and eat only well-cooked meats.”
“Eat fresh, raw fruits and vegetables.”
“Take loperamide (Imodium) every day.”
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Patients traveling to areas with potential traveler's diarrhea should be counseled to drink bottled water and eat meats that are well cooked. Prophylactic antibiotics are not recommended. Patients should eat cooked, washed fruits and vegetables. Loperamide is not recommended for use as a prophylactic agent.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: An appropriate goal when teaching a patient who has diarrhea is that the patient
options: will have less frequent, more formed stools.
will not have a stool for 1 to 2 days.
will receive adequate intravenous fluids.
will receive appropriate antibiotic therapy.
questions.rationale: An appropriate goal is that patients will have formed, less frequent stools, not an absence of stools. Receiving adequate intravenous fluids or antibiotic therapy are interventions, not goals.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: A patient reports having three to four stools, which are sometimes hard, per week. The patient states that this represents less bowel movements than normal for her. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Recommend increased intake of fluids and dietary fiber.
Request an order for a stimulant laxative as needed.
Request an order for a stool softener.
Request an order for magnesium citrate.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com This patient is having stools that are within the normal range for frequency, but she does state that she generally has more frequent bowel movements. Nonpharmacologic measures, such as increased intake of fluids and dietary fiber, should be used first to help soften stools.

questions.category: Chapter 45: Gastrointestinal Tract Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is instructing a patient who will take psyllium to treat constipation. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient?
options: The importance of consuming adequate amounts of water
The need to monitor for systemic side effects
The onset of action of 30 to 60 minutes after administration
The need to use the dry form of psyllium to prevent cramping
questions.rationale: Insufficient fluid intake can cause the drug to solidify in the gastrointestinal tract and place the patient at risk for GI obstruction, thus counseling on ingestion of adequate amounts of water is important. Psyllium is not systemically absorbed, so it does not have systemic side effects. Onset of action for psyllium is between 10 and 24 hours. All forms of bulk forming laxatives can contribute to GI side effects such as cramping.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who has been instructed to use a liquid antacid medication to treat gastrointestinal upset asks the nurse about how to take this medication. What information will the nurse include when teaching this patient? www.NursingExamBank.com
options: All antacids can be taken safely with renal insufficiency.
Take 60 minutes after meals and at bedtime.
Take with at least 8 ounces of water to improve absorption.
Take with milk to improve effectiveness.
questions.rationale: Since maximum acid secretion occurs after eating and at bedtime, antacids should be taken 1 to 3 hours after eating and at bedtime. Taking antacids with meals slows gastric emptying time and causes increased gastrointestinal (GI) secretions. Aluminum salt antacids can accumulate in renal insufficiency and lead to toxicity. Patients should use 2 to 4 ounces of water when taking to ensure that the drug enters the stomach; more than that will increase gastric emptying time. If possible, antacids should not be taken with milk or foods high in vitamin D.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who has symptoms of peptic ulcer disease will undergo a test that requires drinking a liquid containing 13C urea and breathing into a container. The nurse will explain to the patient that this test is performed to
options: assess the level of hydrochloric acid.
detect H. pylori antibodies.
measure the pH of gastric secretions.
test for the presence of H. pylori.
questions.rationale: When H. pylori is suspected, a noninvasive test is performed by administering 13C urea, which, in the presence of H. pylori, will release 13CO2. The test does not measure the amount of HCl acid or the pH and does not detect H. pylori antibodies.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient is taking rabeprazole 20 mg per day to treat a duodenal ulcer. After 10 days of treatment, the patient reports that the pain has subsided. The nurse will counsel the patient to
options: continue the medication for up to 4-8 total weeks of treatment.
reduce the medication dose by half.
stop taking the medication.
take the medication every other day.
questions.rationale: With treatment, ulcer pain may subside earlier, but the healing process may take 1 to 2 months. Patients should be counseled to take the drug for the length of time prescribed. Reducing the dose or taking less frequently is not recommended.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient with a peptic ulcer has been diagnosed with H. pylori. The provider has ordered lansoprazole, clarithromycin, and metronidazole. The patient asks the nurse why two antibiotics are needed. The nurse will explain that two antibiotics
options: allow for less toxic dosing.
combat bacterial resistance.
have synergistic effects.
improve acid suppression.
questions.rationale: The use of two antibiotics when treating H. pylori peptic ulcer disease helps to combat bacterial resistance because H. pylori develops resistance rapidly. Giving two antibiotics, in this case, is not to reduce the dose or to cause synergistic effects. Antibiotics do not affect acid production.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who takes propantheline bromine and omeprazole for an ulcer will begin taking an antacid. The nurse will give which instruction to the patient regarding how to take the antacid?
options: Take the antacid 2 hours after taking the propantheline.
Take the antacid along with a meal.
Take the antacid with milk.
Take the antacid with the propantheline bromine.
questions.rationale: Antacids can slow the absorption of anticholinergics and should be taken 2 hours after anticholinergic administration. Antacids should be given 1 to 3 hours after a meal and should not be given with dairy products.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: Which antacid is most likely to cause acid rebound?
options: Aluminum hydroxide
Calcium carbonate
Magnesium hydroxide
Magnesium trisilicate
questions.rationale: While calcium carbonate is most effective among the listed antacids in neutralizing acid, a significant amount can be systemically absorbed and can cause acid rebound. The other antacids do not have significant systemic absorption.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: An elderly patient reports using magnesium hydroxide frequently to treat acid reflux. The nurse should notify the patient's provider to request an order for which laboratory tests? www.NursingExamBank.com
options: Liver enzymes and serum calcium
Liver enzymes and serum magnesium
Renal function tests and serum calcium
Renal function tests and serum magnesium
questions.rationale: Magnesium hydroxide carries a risk of hypermagnesemia, especially with decreased renal function. Older patients have an increased risk of poor renal function, so this patient should especially be evaluated for hypermagnesemia.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. Which medication order would the nurse question for this patient?
options: Cimetidine
Pantoprazole
Rabeprazole
Ranitidine
questions.rationale: Cimetidine is not effective for treating Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The other medications may be used to treat Zollinger-Ellison syndrome.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who is diagnosed with peptic ulcer disease has been started on a regimen that includes famotidine 40 mg daily at bedtime. The patient calls the clinic 2 days later to report no relief from discomfort. What action will the nurse take?
options: Contact the provider to discuss changing to cimetidine.
Notify the provider to discuss increasing the dose. www.NursingExamBank.com
Reassure the patient that it may take 1 to 2 weeks to notice an improvement in symptoms.
Suggest that the patient split the medication into twice daily dosing.
questions.rationale: Patients taking histamine2 blockers can expect abdominal pain to decrease after 1 to 2 weeks of drug therapy. Cimetidine is not as potent as ranitidine and interacts with many medications through the cytochrome P450 system. 40 mg at bedtime is the recommended dose.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A female patient with a peptic ulcer asks the nurse if misoprostol would be a good option for her because it works well for her mother. Upon review of her medication list it is noted that she takes a prenatal vitamin daily. What will the nurse do?
options: Recommend use of misoprostol since it works well for her mother.
Explain to the patient that misoprostol is contraindicated during pregnancy.
Tell the patient to purchase misoprostol over the counter.
Tell her that misoprostol is just another PPI and that she should just purchase a PPI that is available over the counter.
questions.rationale: Misoprostol is a synthetic prostaglandin analog that can be used to prevent and treat peptic ulcers, particularly in people using high doses of NSAIDs. As a prostaglandin analog, misoprostol is contraindicated during pregnancy. Misoprostol is available by prescription only.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who has been taking nizatidine continues to have pain associated with a peptic ulcer. A noninvasive breath test is negative. Which treatment does the nurse expect the provider to order for this patient? www.NursingExamBank.com
options: Adding an over-the-counter antacid to the patient's drug regimen
A dual drug therapy regimen
Amoxicillin, clarithromycin, and omeprazole
Lansoprazole instead of nizatidine
questions.rationale: This patient does not have H. pylori ulcer disease, so dual and triple drug therapy with antibiotics is not indicated. Patients who fail treatment with a histamine2 blocker should be changed to a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) such as lansoprazole. PPIs tend to inhibit gastric acid secretion up to 90% greater than the histamine antagonists.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient has been taking famotidine 20 mg bid to treat an ulcer but continues to have pain. The provider has ordered pantoprazole 40 mg per day. The patient asks why the new drug is necessary, since it is more expensive. The nurse will explain that pantoprazole
options: can be used for long-term therapy.
does not interact with other drugs.
has fewer medication side effects.
is more potent than famotidine.
questions.rationale: Famotidine is a histamine2 (H2) blocker. When patients fail therapy with these agents, proton pump inhibitors, which can inhibit gastric acid secretion up to 90% greater than the H2 blockers, are used. Pantoprazole is not for long-term treatment and has drug interactions and drug side effects, as do all other medications.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who will begin taking omeprazole 20 mg per day for 4 to 8 weeks to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease esophagitis. The nurse learns that the patient takes digoxin. The nurse will contact the provider for orders to
options: decrease the dose of omeprazole.
increase the dose of digoxin.
increase the omeprazole to 60 mg per day.
monitor for digoxin toxicity.
questions.rationale: Proton pump inhibitors can enhance the effects of digoxin, so patients should be monitored for digoxin toxicity. Changing the dose of either medication is not indicated prior to obtaining lab results that indicated elevated digoxin levels.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient reports experiencing flatulence and abdominal distension to the nurse. Which over-the- counter medication will the nurse recommend?
options: Famotidine
Magnesium hydroxide
Simethicone
Calcium carbonate
questions.rationale: Simethicone is an antigas agent. The other products do not help with gas relief.

questions.category: Chapter 46: Antiulcer Drugs
questions.stem: A patient who recently began having mild symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is reluctant to take medication. What non-pharmacological measures will the nurse recommend to minimize this patient's symptoms? (Select all that apply.)
options: Avoiding hot, spicy foods
Avoiding tobacco products
Drinking a glass of red wine with dinner
Eating a snack before bedtime e. Taking ibuprofen with food f. Using a small pillow for sleeping g. Wearing tight-fitted clothing
questions.rationale: , B, E Hot, spicy foods aggravate gastric upset, tobacco increases gastric secretions, and ibuprofen on an empty stomach increases gastric secretions, so patients should be taught to avoid these actions. Alcohol should be avoided since it increases gastric secretions. Eating at bedtime increases reflux, as does laying relatively flat to sleep, or wearing tight-fitted clothing.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has increased intraocular pressure. The provider has ordered levobunolol 0.5% ophthalmic solution. The nurse will perform a thorough health history to make sure the patient does not have a history of which condition?
options: Asthma
Diabetes
Hypertension www.NursingExamBank.com
Renal disease
questions.rationale: Levobunolol is a non-selective beta blocker that can be used to treat increased intraocular pressure. This agent is contraindicated in patients with asthma.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is performing a medication history on a patient who has glaucoma. The patient has a prescription for brimonidine (Alphagan P). The nurse knows that this drug belongs to which class of medications?
options: Alpha-adrenergic agonists
Beta-adrenergic blockers
Cholinergic agonists
Cholinesterase inhibitors
questions.rationale: Brimonidine is an alpha-adrenergic agonist.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse administers proparacaine HCl (Ophthaine) drops to a patient prior to an eye examination. What sign will the nurse look for to determine when the examination can begin?
options: Absence of the blink reflex
Blurred vision
Drying of the corneal epithelium
Photophobia
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Proparacaine is a topical anesthetic for the eye and causes temporary loss of the blink reflex. Drying of the corneal epithelium is a side effect but occurs later as a result of the loss of the blink reflex. Blurred vision and photophobia result from mydriasis and miosis.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is administering timolol (Timoptic) eye drops to a patient who has glaucoma. To prevent bradycardia, the nurse will perform which action?
options: Apply pressure to the lacrimal ducts.
Have the patient sit up after instilling the drops.
Prepare to administer an alpha-adrenergic agonist.
Wait 5 minutes between drops.
questions.rationale: Bradycardia is a potential systemic side effect of timolol. Applying pressure to the lacrimal ducts helps prevent the medication from being systemically absorbed and causing systemic side effects such as bradycardia.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: A patient has an infection of the eyelash follicles and in the gland on the eyelid margin. The nurse recognizes these symptoms as being consistent with which condition?
options: Blepharitis
Chalazion
Endophthalmitis
Hordeolum
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Hordeolum is a local infection of eyelash follicles and glands on the eyelid margin and is also known as a “stye.” Blepharitis is an infection of the margins of the eyelid. Chalazion is an infection of the glands of the eyelids that may produce cysts. Endophthalmitis is an infection of the structures of the inner eye.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer atropine sulfate drops as a mydriatic agent. Which of the following is considered a contraindication to therapy?
options: Tachycardia
Diarrhea
Bradycardia
Constipation
questions.rationale: Atropine sulfate is an anticholinergic medication that is contraindicated in patients with tachycardia and glaucoma. Anticholinergic effects could contribute to worsening constipation, but the presence of constipation would not be considered a contraindication.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer olopatadine (Patanol) eyedrops to a patient who has allergic conjunctivitis. The patient tells the nurse that the drops have caused burning and stinging. What action will the nurse take?
options: Administer the drops and reassure the patient that this is a normal side effect.
Offer an over-the-counter eye lubricant to minimize this adverse effect.
Request an order for antibiotic eyedrops.
Withhold the medication and notify the provider. www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Burning and stinging are the most common side effects of this class of drugs but do not warrant withholding the medication. An over-the-counter lubricant is not indicated. These symptoms are not an indication of infection.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is providing teaching for a patient who will begin using tobramycin ointment (Nebcin) 0.5 inches 3 times daily. The patient currently uses pilocarpine HCl (Isopto Carpine) drops to treat glaucoma. Which statement by the patient indicates a need for further teaching?
options: “I should apply the third dose of tobramycin at bedtime each day.”
“I should instill the drops in the conjunctival sac of the lower eyelid.”
“I should not stop the medications without consulting my provider.”
“I should put the ointment on first and then instill the eyedrops.”
questions.rationale: Patients using both eye drops and ointments should instill the drops prior to applying the ointment. Ointments should be applied at bedtime if possible. Drops should be instilled into the conjunctival sac of the lower lid. Patients should always consult with their provider before discontinuing any medication.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is counseling an adolescent patient who has recurrent otitis externa and who works as a lifeguard in the summer about preventing this condition. The nurse will teach this patient to do which of the following?
options: Avoid using ear plugs while swimming.
Request a prescription for prophylactic antibiotic eardrops.
Use a hair dryer to dry the ears after swimming. www.NursingExamBank.com
Wear a medical alert bracelet.
questions.rationale: To help prevent otitis externa, patients should be counseled to use a portable hair dryer to dry the ears after swimming. Ear plugs are recommended. Prophylactic antibiotic eardrops are not indicated. A medical alert bracelet is not necessary.

questions.category: Chapter 47: Eye and Ear Disorders
questions.stem: The parent of a toddler asks the nurse what can be done to prevent otitis media. What will the nurse recommend?
options: Administer diphenhydramine when the child has a runny nose.
Give phenylephrine (Neo-Synephrine Ophthalmic) to prevent congestion.
Keep the child's immunizations up to date.
Remove cerumen with carbamide peroxide (Auro Ear Drops).
questions.rationale: The pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) protects children against S. pneumoniae and should be administered to all children to prevent otitis media. Antihistamines and decongestants have been shown to be ineffective in preventing otitis media. Removing cerumen helps to prevent otitis externa.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is providing teaching for an adolescent who has acne vulgaris. In addition to teaching about correct administration of the prescribed medications, the nurse will instruct this patient to do which of the following?
options: Apply topical vitamin D3.
Cleanse the skin gently several times a day.
Cleanse the affected skin vigorously twice daily.
Take an oral vitamin D supplement.
questions.rationale: Gentle cleansing is one of the chief nonpharmacologic treatments of acne. Vigorous scrubbing should be avoided. Topical vitamin D is sometimes used to treat psoriasis.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: A patient reports using benzoyl peroxide 2.5% for acne but doesn't feel that it is working. The nurse notes papules and nodules on the patient's face, neck, and back, consistent with moderate acne vulgaris. The nurse will counsel this patient to ask the provider about which of the following?
options: Adding isotretinoin (Amnesteem) to the treatment regimen
Increasing the benzoyl peroxide to a 5% solution
Taking systemic antibiotics until symptoms improve
Using benzoyl peroxide 10% and a topical antibiotic
questions.rationale: Moderate acne may require a stronger concentration of benzoyl peroxide (such as 10%) and topical antibiotics. Isotretinoin is used for severe cystic acne. Systemic antibiotics are given for severe acne.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a female patient who will begin taking isotretinoin (Amnesteem) to treat severe cystic acne. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “I may get a 3-month supply of the medication with each refill.”
“I must abstain from intercourse while taking this drug.”
“I should avoid strenuous exercise when I am taking this medication.”
“I should take a vitamin A supplement while I am taking the medication.”
questions.rationale: Serious muscle damage may occur while taking this medication, so patients should avoid excessive vigorous activity which can compound this effect. Patients should be advised to stop taking the medication and contact the health care provider if they experience muscle weakness, which may be an indication of serious muscle damage. Patients must get monthly refills and should use two reliable forms of birth control while taking the medication, but abstinence is not required. Vitamin A can compound the adverse effects of this medication.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who has psoriasis is taking methoxsalen (Oxsoralen) to treat the condition along with receiving therapeutic UVA. The nurse notes burning and blistering of the patient's skin. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Ask the patient about any recent exposure to sunlight.
Explain to the patient that these signs mean the treatment is working.
Report spread of the psoriasis to the patient's provider.
Tell the patient to take the methoxsalen after the UVA treatment.
questions.rationale: Patients taking methoxsalen can develop burning and blistering with exposure to sunlight. These signs do not indicate efficacy of the treatment and do not mean the psoriasis is worsening. There is no indication for taking the drug after the UVA exposure. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who has psoriasis will begin taking etanercept (Enbrel). The nurse will ensure that which laboratory test is performed prior to initiating treatment with this drug?
options: Complete blood count (CBC) with differential
CD4 and T-cell count
Serum pregnancy test
Tuberculin skin test
questions.rationale: Etanercept can worsen infections by suppressing the immune system, and patients taking this drug must have a tuberculin skin test prior to initiation of treatment. CBC, CD4, and T-cell counts may be monitored during therapy. A serum pregnancy test is not specifically indicated prior to use.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse assists the provider to treat a patient who has warts with cantharidin (Cantharone). After the cantharidin is applied to the warts, the nurse will do which of the following?
options: Apply gauze dressings to the warts and secure them with tape.
Cover the warts with nonporous tape when the solution dries.
Prepare to assist the provider with cryotherapy to complete the procedure.
Treat the warts with Burrow's soaks and apply a wet-to-dry dressing.
questions.rationale: To prevent damage to the surrounding skin, the wart should be covered with nonporous tape after the application of cantharidin is allowed to dry. This procedure can be repeated in approximately 2 weeks. Gauze dressings are porous and would allow the solution to come in contact with intact skin. Cryotherapy is a separate procedure and not done after treatment with cantharidin. Burow's soaks are not indicated for the treatment of warts. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: A patient reports severe localized itching after contact with a new brand of laundry detergent. The nurse will suggest that the patient contact the provider to discuss treatment with which product initially?
options: Calamine lotion
Systemic glucocorticoid
Oral diphenhydramine
Topical corticosteroid
questions.rationale: This patient has contact dermatitis related to contact with a chemical. Topical corticosteroids may be used for the itching. Calamine lotion is used mainly for contact with plant irritants. Oral diphenhydramine is not recommended initially, but could be added if itching persists. Systemic steroids are used for more severe reactions.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who works outdoors has frequent contact dermatitis flares secondary to exposure to plant irritants. The patient asks the nurse how to minimize these episodes. The nurse will counsel this patient to perform which action?
options: Apply topical glucocorticoid medication prior to exposure.
Cleanse the skin immediately after any contact with plants.
Take oral diphenhydramine (Benadryl) after being outdoors.
Use calamine lotion prior to working outdoors.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Prevention is an important management strategy for contact dermatitis. Cleansing is one of the chief methods to decrease the irritation that has been caused by contact with the causative irritant or allergen.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: A female patient has begun using 2% minoxidil (Rogaine) to treat thinning of her hair. After several weeks of treatment, she reports minimal effectiveness but has noticed some improvement. The nurse will counsel her to perform which action?
options: Continue to use the 2% minoxidil.
Change to finasteride (Propecia).
Discontinue the minoxidil.
Increase to 5% minoxidil.
questions.rationale: The patient has shown some improvement, so she should keep using the product if she wants to maintain the results, since stopping treatment will result in hair loss in a few months. Finasteride and 5% minoxidil are not approved for women.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a group of adolescents about sun protection. What information will the nurse include when teaching this group?
options: Effective sunscreens absolutely prevent melanoma and basal cell carcinoma.
Sunscreen products are all chemical blockers.
SPF ratings less than 15 can denote reduced risk of skin cancer and early skin aging.
The American Academy of Dermatology recommends water resistant sunscreen www.NursingExamBank.com with an SPF 30 or higher.
questions.rationale: The American Academy of Dermatology recommends water resistant sunscreen with an SPF of 30 or higher. Sunscreen products can be either chemical blockers or physical blockers. Products with an SPF rating less than 15 cannot denote reduced risk of skin cancer and early skin aging. This is reserved for products with an SPF of 15 and above.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who has extensive second- and third-degree burns will use mafenide acetate (Sulfamylon) to treat the burns. Which of the following is true of mafenide acetate use for the treatment of burns?
options: It is dosed orally once daily.
It has multiple serious drug interactions associated with use.
Potential side effects include rash, urticaria and pruritus.
Mafenide is a synthetic aminoglycoside antibiotic.
questions.rationale: Common side effects associated with topical mafenide use include rash, urticaria, pruritus, swelling and erythema. Mafenide acetate is a synthetic sulfonamide antibiotic applied topically and has no significant drug interactions.

questions.category: Chapter 48: Dermatologic Disorders
questions.stem: A patient has second- and third-degree burns, and the nurse is applying silver sulfadiazine (Silvadene) to the burns with each dressing change. The patient reports a burning sensation. The nurse understands that this is
options: a hypersensitivity reaction to the medication. www.NursingExamBank.com
an expected adverse reaction to the medication.
a sign of localized tissue infection.
a sign of skin necrosis.
questions.rationale: A common adverse reaction to silver sulfadiazine is a burning sensation. It does not indicate a hypersensitivity reaction, localized tissue infection, or skin necrosis.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The parents of an 11-year-old boy ask about growth hormone therapy for their child, who is shorter than his 10-year-old sister. The nurse will tell the parents that growth hormone
options: does not affect other hormones when given.
is available as an oral tablet to be taken once daily.
is given after tests prove that it is necessary.
may be given until the child's desired height is reached.
questions.rationale: Growth hormone is given only when growth hormone deficiency is determined. It cannot be given orally. It antagonizes insulin secretion and thus can lead to the development of diabetes mellitus. It cannot be given after the epiphyses are fused.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving growth hormone. Which assessment will the nurse monitor daily?
options: Complete blood count
Height and weight
Renal function
Serum glucose
questions.rationale: Growth hormone antagonizes insulin secretion, so serum glucose should be monitored.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The parents of a 16-year-old boy who plays football want their child to receive growth hormone to improve muscle strength. What will the nurse tell the parents?
options: “Growth hormone may be used to improve strength in young athletes.”
“If the epiphyses are not fused, growth hormone may be an option.”
“Small doses of growth hormone may be used indefinitely for this purpose.”
“Using growth hormone to build muscle mass is not recommended.”
questions.rationale: Athletes should be advised not to take growth hormone to build muscle because of its effects on blood sugar and other side effects.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: Which would be a contraindication for hormone therapy with somatropin in a school-age child?
options: Asthma
Dwarfism
Enuresis www.NursingExamBank.com
Prader-Willi syndrome
questions.rationale: Fatalities associated with risks of taking growth hormone with Prader-Willi syndrome have been reported, so it is contraindicated in patients with this syndrome. It is not contraindicated in patients with asthma or enuresis. Dwarfism is an indication for hormone therapy.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A child exhibits acromegaly caused by a tumor that cannot be destroyed with radiation. Which medication would be appropriate to treat this child?
options: Bromocriptine mesylate
Conivaptan
Somapacitan
Somatropin
questions.rationale: Bromocriptine is used to inhibit release of growth hormone from the pituitary gland if the tumor cannot be destroyed by radiation. Conivaptan is used for symptomatic euvolemic hyponatremia associated with SIADH. Somatropin and somapacitan are used to treat growth hormone deficiency and would make acromegaly worse.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has hypothyroidism. To assist in differentiating between primary and secondary hypothyroidism, the nurse will expect the provider to order which drug?
options: Liothyronine sodium
Liotrix
Methimazole
Thyrotropin www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Thyrotropin is a purified extract of thyroid-stimulating hormone and is used as a diagnostic agent to differentiate between primary and secondary hypothyroidism. Liothyronine and liotrix are thyroid replacement drugs. Methimazole is used to decrease thyroid hormone secretion.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse administers intravenous corticotropin to a patient. A serum cortisol level drawn 60 minutes later shows no change in serum cortisol levels from prior to the dose. What is the nurse's first action?
options: Notify the provider to discuss a possible non-functioning adrenal gland.
Recognize the need for an increased dose to treat pituitary insufficiency.
Request an order for a second dose of corticotropin to treat cortisone deficiency.
Request an order to repeat the serum cortisol level in 1–2 h.
questions.rationale: Corticotropin is given to diagnose adrenal gland disorders as well as to treat adrenal gland insufficiency. When given intravenously, the serum cortisol level should increase within 30–60 min if the adrenal gland is functioning. The nurse should report adrenal gland dysfunction. The provider will determine how to treat. Since the levels should increase in 30–60 min, there is no need to repeat the test in 1–2 h.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse provides teaching for a patient who is receiving corticotropin. The nurse will instruct the patient to contact the provider if which condition occurs?
options: Bruising
Constipation
Myalgia www.NursingExamBank.com
Nausea
questions.rationale: Ecchymosis is an adverse reaction to corticotropin and should be reported. Constipation and nausea are known side effects but are not serious. Myalgia is not common.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who has experienced head trauma in a motor vehicle accident. The patient is having excessive output of dilute urine. The nurse will notify the provider and will anticipate administering which medication?
options: Calcifediol
Corticotropin
Prednisolone
Vasopressin
questions.rationale: The posterior pituitary gland secretes antidiuretic hormone (ADH) (vasopressin). When there is a deficiency of ADH, sometimes caused by head trauma, patients excrete large amounts of dilute urine. ADH replacement is necessary to prevent fluid imbalance. Calcifediol is used to treat parathyroid disorders. Corticotropin and prednisolone do not prevent diuresis.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer piperacillin to a patient to treat an infection caused by pseudomonas. The nurse learns that the patient is receiving corticotropin to treat an acute multiple sclerosis flare. The nurse will request an order for which of the following?
options: A different antibiotic
Blood glucose monitoring www.NursingExamBank.com
Cardiac monitoring
Serum electrolyte monitoring
questions.rationale: Corticotropin can interact with piperacillin to cause hypokalemia, so serum electrolytes should be monitored. It is not necessary to change the antibiotic. Blood glucose monitoring and cardiac monitoring are not indicated.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is receiving desmopressin acetate (DDAVP). Which assessments are important while caring for this patient?
options: Blood pressure and serum potassium
Heart rate and serum calcium
Lung sounds and serum magnesium
Urine output and serum sodium
questions.rationale: Desmopressin is an antidiuretic hormone. The nurse should monitor intake and output as well as serum sodium levels. Side effects and adverse reactions include hyponatremia, cephalgia, dyspepsia, diarrhea, nausea, and vomiting.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A 35-year-old woman reports lethargy, difficulty remembering things, facial edema, dry skin, and cessation of menses. The nurse notes a heart rate of 60 beats per minute and a weight increase of 5 pounds from a previous visit. The nurse suspects the patient will be diagnosed with which of the following?
options: Cretinism www.NursingExamBank.com
Early menopause
Hyperthyroidism
Myxedema
questions.rationale: Myxedema is severe hypothyroidism characterized by this woman's symptoms. Cretinism is congenital hypothyroidism. Early menopause is not characterized by memory loss, facial edema, dry skin, or bradycardia. Hyperthyroidism would include tachycardia and weight loss.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A patient is admitted to the hospital with myxedema and requires treatment for hypothyroidism. For rapid improvement in symptoms, the nurse will expect to administer which medication?
options: Levothyroxine sodium
Liothyronine
Liotrix
Dessicated thyroid
questions.rationale: Liothyronine has a short t1/2 and rapid onset of action and is not recommended for maintenance therapy but is used as initial therapy for severe myxedema. Levothyroxine is the drug of choice for replacement therapy. Liotrix is a second-line drug. Dessicated thyroid is used for hypothyroidism to reduce goiter size.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who takes warfarin and digoxin develops hypothyroidism and will begin taking levothyroxine. The nurse anticipates which potential adjustments in dosing for this patient?
options: Decreased digoxin and decreased warfarin
Decreased digoxin and increased warfarin
Increased digoxin and decreased warfarin www.NursingExamBank.com
Increased digoxin and increased warfarin
questions.rationale: Thyroid preparations increase the effect of oral anticoagulants, so the warfarin dose may need to be decreased. Levothyroxine can decrease the effectiveness of digoxin, so this dose may need to be increased.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who takes insulin to manage type 1 diabetes will begin taking levothyroxine. The nurse will advise this patient to monitor for
options: hyperglycemia.
hypoglycemia.
hyperkalemia.
hypokalemia.
questions.rationale: Insulin and oral antidiabetic drugs may need to be increased in patients taking levothyroxine. Patients should be taught to monitor for hyperglycemia, because of the reduced effects of these drugs.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a patient who is being treated for hypothyroidism. The patient reports insomnia, nervousness, and flushing of the skin. Before notifying the provider, the nurse will perform which action?
options: Assess serum glucose to evaluate possible hypoglycemia.
Check the patient's heart rate to assess for tachycardia.
Perform an assessment of hydration status. www.NursingExamBank.com
Take the patient's temperature to evaluate for infection.
questions.rationale: The patient has signs of a thyroid crisis, which can occur with excess ingestion of thyroid hormone. The nurse should evaluate heart rate before notifying the provider. These are not symptoms of hypoglycemia. The symptoms are not indicative of infection.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A patient with Graves' disease exhibits tachycardia, heat intolerance, and exophthalmos. Prior to surgery, which drug is used to alter thyroid hormone levels?
options: Liotrix
Propranolol
Propylthiouracil (PTU)
Dessicated thyroid
questions.rationale: Propylthiouracil is a potent antithyroid drug used in preparation for a subtotal thyroidectomy. Liotrix and thyroid are used as thyroid replacement. Propranolol is used to treat hypertension associated with hyperthyroidism.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A patient has hypocalcemia caused by parathyroid hormone deficiency. Which medication will the nurse anticipate giving to this patient?
options: Calcitonin
Calcitriol
Calcium
Vitamin D www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Calcitriol is given for management of hypocalcemia caused by parathyroid hormone deficiency. Calcitonin is used to treat hyperparathyroidism. Calcium and vitamin D are not useful in parathyroid deficiency.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A patient is receiving a glucocorticoid medication to treat an inflammatory condition, and the provider has ordered a slow taper to discontinue this medication. The nurse explains to the patient that this is done to prevent which condition?
options: Acromegaly
Adrenocortical insufficiency
Hypertensive crisis
Thyroid storm
questions.rationale: Patients receiving glucocorticoids stop making their own cortisol. These drugs should be tapered slowly to allow the body to resume making this hormone. Acromegaly is associated with growth hormone hypersecretion. Hypertensive crisis and thyroid storm are associated with thyroid replacement.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A patient is taking prednisolone and fludrocortisone. When teaching this patient about dietary intake, the nurse will instruct the patient to consume a diet that is
options: high in carbohydrates.
high in fat.
high in protein. www.NursingExamBank.com
low in potassium.
questions.rationale: Patients receiving fludrocortisone are at risk for negative nitrogen balance and should consume a high-protein diet.

questions.category: Chapter 49: Pituitary, Thyroid, Parathyroid, and Adrenal Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who takes high-dose aspirin to treat arthritis will need to take prednisone to treat an acute flare of symptoms. What action will the nurse perform?
options: Observe the patient for hypoglycemia.
Monitor closely for increased urine output.
Observe the patient for hypotension.
Request an order for enteric-coated aspirin.
questions.rationale: Glucocorticoids can increase gastric distress, so an enteric-coated aspirin product is indicated. Glucocorticoids increase the risk of hypoglycemia, fluid retention, and hypertension.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a group of nursing students about diabetes. The nurse explains that which type of diabetes is the most common?
options: Type 1 diabetes mellitus www.NursingExamBank.com
Type 2 diabetes mellitus
Diabetes insipidus
Secondary diabetes
questions.rationale: Type 2 diabetes mellitus is the most common type of diabetes.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A patient develops type 2 diabetes mellitus. The nurse will explain that this type of diabetes
options: is often triggered by viral infections.
is not as common as type 1 diabetes.
is often related to heredity and obesity.
will not require insulin therapy.
questions.rationale: Type 2 diabetes is often caused by obesity and hereditary factors. Viral infections triggering an autoimmune response is associated with the development of type 1 diabetes Type 2 diabetes is the most common type of diabetes. Patients with type 2 diabetes may eventually require treatment with insulin.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A patient who is overweight is being evaluated for diabetes. The patient has a random blood glucose level of 160 mg/dL and a hemoglobin A1c of 5.8%. The nurse understands that this patient has which condition?
options: Diabetes mellitus
Hypoglycemia
Normal blood levels
Prediabetes www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Patients with a hemoglobin A1c between 5.7% and 6.4% are considered to have prediabetes. A level of 6.5% or more indicates diabetes.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient who is newly diagnosed with type 1 diabetes mellitus about insulin administration. Which statement by the patient indicates a need for further teaching?
options: “I should rotate my injection sites.”
“I should give each injection a knuckle length away from a previous injection.”
“I will not be concerned about a raised knot under my skin from injecting insulin.”
“Insulin is absorbed better from subcutaneous sites on my abdomen.”
questions.rationale: Lipohypertrophy presents as a raised lump or knot on the skin surface caused by repeated injections into the same site, and this can interfere with insulin absorption. Patients are encouraged to rotate injection sites, giving each injection at least a knuckle length away from the previous injection. Insulin absorption is most predictable when given in abdominal areas.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a patient how to administer insulin. The patient is thin with very little body fat. The nurse will suggest injecting insulin
options: by pinching up the skin and injecting straight down.
in the abdomen only with the needle at a 90-degree angle.
subcutaneously with the needle at a 45- to 60-degree angle.
using the thigh and buttocks areas exclusively.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com In a thin person, with little fatty tissue, the needle is inserted at a 45- to 60-degree angle. In other patients, a 45- to 90-degree angle is acceptable. There is no recommendation for preferring one site over another.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: The nurse receives the following order for insulin: IV NPH (Humulin NPH) 10 units. The nurse will perform which action?
options: Administer the dose as ordered.
Clarify the insulin type and route.
Give the drug subcutaneously.
Question the insulin dose.
questions.rationale: NPH insulin is not indicated for intravenous administration. The nurse should clarify the order. The nurse should not administer the drug by a different route without first discussing the order with the provider.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: The nurse has been asked to provide medication education to a patient with type 2 diabetes starting a new oral medication. The patient can't remember the name of the medication but says that his physician called it a “DPP-4 inhibitor.” Which of the following medications is a DPP-4 inhibitor?
options: Dapagliflozin
Glyburide
Liraglutide
Saxagliptin www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Saxagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor. Dapagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor, liraglutide is a GLP-1 receptor agonist, and glyburide is a sulfonylurea.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A patient reports that they are taking a rapid-acting insulin with meals, but can't remember the name. Which of the following products is a rapid-acing insulin?
options: Regular insulin (Novolin R)
Insulin glargine (Lantus)
Insulin lispro (Humalog)
Insulin degludec (Tresiba)
questions.rationale: Insulin lispro (Humalog) is a rapid-acing insulin product. Regular insulin is considered a short- acting insulin. Insulin glargine and insulin degludec are long-acting insulins.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A patient is ordered to receive insulin lispro at mealtimes. The nurse will instruct this patient to ideally administer the medication at which time?
options: 10-15 min before eating
15 min after eating
30 min before eating
10 min after eating
questions.rationale: Lispro acts faster than regular insulin, and patients should be taught to give this medication 10- 15 minutes before eating. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: The parent of a junior high school child who has type 1 diabetes asks the nurse if the child can participate in sports. The nurse will tell the parent
options: that strenuous exercise is not recommended for children with diabetes.
that the child must be monitored for hyperglycemia while exercising.
to administer an extra dose of regular insulin prior to exercise.
to send a snack with the child to eat just prior to exercise.
questions.rationale: Patients generally need less insulin with increased exercise, so the child should consume a snack to prevent hypoglycemia. Exercise is an integral part of diabetes management. Hypoglycemia is more likely to occur, and extra insulin is not indicated.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A patient was administered regular insulin 45 minutes ago, but has not yet received a breakfast tray. The patient is experiencing nervousness and tremors. What is the nurse's first action?
options: Administer glucagon.
Give the patient orange juice.
Notify the kitchen to deliver the tray.
Perform bedside glucose testing.
questions.rationale: The patient is symptomatic and has hypoglycemia. The nurse should give orange juice. Glucagon is given for patients unable to ingest carbohydrates. The kitchen should be notified, and bedside glucose testing should be performed, but only after the patient is given carbohydrates. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A patient who has type 2 diabetes mellitus asks the nurse about using a combination insulin product such as Humalog 70/30. The nurse will tell the patient that use of this product
options: depends on individual insulin needs.
is useful for patients with severe insulin resistance.
means less rotation of injection sites.
requires refrigeration at all times.
questions.rationale: Combination products are convenient because the patient does not have to mix insulin, but the products depend on individual needs, since the doses are fixed. They are generally not used for patients with severe insulin resistance that require large insulin doses. Patients must continue to rotate injection sites. They do not require refrigeration after first use.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: The patient asks the nurse about storing insulin. Which response by the nurse is correct?
options: “All insulin vials must be refrigerated before and during use.”
“Insulin will last longer if kept in the freezer.”
“Opened vials of insulin must be discarded after first use.”
“Some insulin products do not require refrigeration during use.”
questions.rationale: Some insulin products do not require refrigeration during use. Storing insulin in the freezer is not recommended. Opened vials may either be kept at room temperature or refrigerated. Drug information for each product should be reviewed for drug-specific storage information.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A patient who has type 1 diabetes mellitus must take a glucocorticoid medication for osteoarthritis. When teaching this patient, the nurse will explain that there may be a need to
options: decrease the glucocorticoid dose.
decrease the insulin dose.
increase the glucocorticoid dose.
increase the insulin dose.
questions.rationale: Glucocorticoids can cause hyperglycemia, so the insulin dose may need to be increased. Changing the glucocorticoid dose is usually not recommended. Decreasing the insulin dose will only compound the hyperglycemic effects of the glucocorticoid.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: Which statement by a patient who will begin using an insulin pump indicates understanding of this device?
options: “I will have an increased risk for hypoglycemia.”
“I will leave this on when bathing or swimming.”
“I will not need to count carbohydrates anymore.”
“I will still need to monitor my glucose levels.”
questions.rationale: Patients using an insulin pump will still monitor glucose levels and count carbohydrates. The advantage of the pump is that it is programmed to deliver continuous rapid-acting insulin in varying amounts at different times throughout the day. Changes in food intake can alter the risk for hypoglycemia if the pump is not adjusted accordingly. Most devices must be removed when bathing or swimming. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A patient who is unconscious and has a pulse is brought to the emergency department. The patient is wearing a Medic-Alert bracelet indicating type 1 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following would be the most appropriate to administer to the patient at this time?
options: Cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR)
Glucagon
Insulin
Orange juice
questions.rationale: This patient is most likely hypoglycemic. Glucagon is given if patients are unable to ingest a carbohydrate, such as orange juice. CPR is not indicated. Insulin will compound the hypoglycemia.

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A patient who has type 2 diabetes mellitus asks the nurse why the provider has changed their oral antidiabetic agent from tolbutamide (Orinase) to glipizide (Glucotrol). The nurse will explain that glipizide
options: has a longer duration of action.
has fewer gastrointestinal side effects.
may be taken on an as-needed basis.
does not cause hypoglycemia.
questions.rationale: Glipizide is a second-generation sulfonylurea. It has a longer duration of action than the first- generation sulfonylurea tolbutamide. It has many gastrointestinal side effects. It is taken once daily, not as needed. All sulfonylureas can contribute to hypoglycemia. www.NursingExamBank.com

questions.category: Chapter 50: Antidiabetics
questions.stem: A 45-year-old patient who is overweight has had a diagnosis of type 2 diabetes for 2 years. The patient uses 20 units of long-acting insulin per day. The patient's fasting blood glucose (FBG) is 190 mg/dL. The patient asks the nurse about using an oral antidiabetic agent. The nurse understands that oral antidiabetic agents
options: cannot be used if the patient is overweight.
cannot be used once a patient requires insulin.
may be used in patients with type 2 diabetes in combination with insulin.
may not be used since this patient's fasting blood glucose is too high.
questions.rationale: Patients with type 2 diabetes often use long-acting insulin in combination with oral agents to manage blood glucose.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: A 25-year-old female patient reports urinary frequency with pain on urination, flank pain, fever, and chills. The nurse recognizes these symptoms as characteristic of which condition?
options: Cystitis
Dysuria
Pyelonephritis
Urethritis www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: These are symptoms of pyelonephritis, characterized by fever, dysuria, flank pain, and urinary frequency.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: A male patient reports urinary urgency and pain with burning on urination. The nurse understands that this patient will likely be treated for which condition?
options: Cystitis
Prostatitis
Pyelonephritis
Urethritis
questions.rationale: In a male patient, a lower urinary tract infection is most likely prostatitis with symptoms similar to cystitis, such as pain and burning on urination and urinary frequency and urgency.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a woman diagnosed with a urinary tract infection (UTI). The patient reports always having difficulty remembering to take medications. Which drug could the provider select when treating this patient to help with medication adherence due to its efficacy as a single-dose treatment?
options: Fosfomycin tromethamine (Monurol)
Ciprofloxacin (Cipro)
Nitrofurantoin (Macrodantin)
Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole (Bactrim)
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Fosfomycin is given as a one-time, single dose and is approved for the treatment of uncomplicated UTIs in women. Ciprofloxacin is given daily or twice a day. Nitrofurantoin is given four times daily. Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is given twice daily.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is caring for a hospitalized patient who has symptoms characteristic of pyelonephritis. Before administering the first dose of the intravenous antibiotic, the nurse will ensure that which action is performed?
options: An antipyretic is administered.
A dose of oral antibiotic is given.
A urinary analgesic is given.
A urine culture is obtained.
questions.rationale: A urinalysis, as well as a culture and sensitivity, is usually performed before initiating drug therapy. An antipyretic is indicated for fever but does not need to be timed before the antibiotic. An oral antibiotic is not indicated. A urinary analgesic is given as needed.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse provides teaching for a patient who will begin taking nitrofurantoin (Macrodantin) to treat a urinary tract infection. Which statement by the patient indicates understanding of the teaching?
options: “If I experience gastrointestinal upset, I may take an antacid.”
“I should notify my provider immediately if my urine is brown.”
“I should take the drug with food and increase my fluid intake.”
“There is no need to worry or contact my physician if I have sudden onset of chest pain.” www.NursingExamBank.com
questions.rationale: Patients taking nitrofurantoin should take the drug with food and increase fluid intake. The drug should not be taken with antacids. Brown urine is a harmless side effect. Patients should contact their health care provider if the experience sudden onset of dyspnea, chest pain, cough, fever, and chills.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer methenamine (Hiprex) to a patient who is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection. The nurse reviews the patient's chart and notes a urinary pH of 6.0. Which action will the nurse take?
options: Administer the drug as ordered.
Obtain an order for 8 ounces of cranberry juice three times daily.
Request an order for an increased dose.
Restrict fluids to concentrate the patient's urine.
questions.rationale: Methenamine produces a bactericidal effect when the urine pH is less than 5.5. Cranberry juice, ascorbic acid, or ammonium chloride can be administered to help to acidify the urine.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: Which side effect listed below is NOT associated with the urinary analgesic phenazopyridine?
options: Renal dysfunction
Altered blood glucose testing results
Reddish-orange urine
Hemolytic anemia
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Phenazopyridine can cause hemolytic anemia, renal and hepatic dysfunction, and a harmless discoloration of the urine to a reddish orange color. Phenazopyridine can alter urine glucose testing, but does not affect blood glucose test results.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: A patient who has pain with urination associated with cystitis will be discharged home with a prescription for phenazopyridine (Pyridium). What instruction will the nurse include when teaching the patient about this drug?
options: “Do not take this drug concurrently with an antibiotic.”
“Report reddish-brown urine to the provider immediately.”
“This drug has antiseptic and analgesic properties.”
“The drug provides symptomatic relief of pain.”
questions.rationale: Phenazopyridine is used to provide symptomatic pain relief. It may be taken with antibiotics. Reddish-brown urine is a harmless side effect. It does not have antiseptic properties.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer bethanechol chloride (Urecholine) to a patient. The nurse understands that this drug acts to
options: block parasympathetic nerve impulses.
increase the tone of the urinary detrusor muscle.
relax smooth muscles in the urinary tract.
relieve urinary pain and burning.
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Bethanechol is used to increase the tone of the detrusor muscle and increase the bladder tone to stimulate urination. It stimulates the parasympathetic nerves. It increases smooth muscle tone in the urinary tract. It does not alleviate dysuria.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: An older woman has urgent urinary incontinence related to an overactive bladder. Which medication does the nurse expect the provider to order?
options: Dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO)
Mirabegron (Myrbetriq)
Phenazopyridine HCl (Pyridium)
Tolterodine tartrate (Detrol)
questions.rationale: Detrol is used to treat overactive bladder. Dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) is a urinary analgesic. Mirabegron (Myrbetriq) is a urinary antispasmodic. Phenazopyridine HCl (Pyridium) is used to alleviate the pain and burning sensation during urination that is experienced with chronic cystitis.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse assumes care for a patient who is experiencing urinary tract spasms and is ordered to receive flavoxate HCl (Urispas). When reviewing this patient's history, which condition would cause the nurse to notify the provider?
options: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder
Diabetes
Glaucoma
Hypotension
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Flavoxate should not be used in a patient who has gastrointestinal or urinary tract obstruction or if the patient has glaucoma.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is preparing to administer methenamine (Hiprex) to a patient who has pyelonephritis. The nurse understands that methenamine use is associated with the potential side effect of crystalluria. Which of the following would increase the risk of crystalluria?
options: Restrict fluid intake
Darkening of the urine
Frequent ingestion of cranberry juice
Combination therapy with a sulfonamide
questions.rationale: Patients who take methenamine can develop crystalluria and should increase fluid intake to prevent this effect. A reddish-brown color is a harmless side effect. Patients should have acidic urine to increase effectiveness of the medication. Methenamine taken with sulfonamides increases the risk of crystalluria.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: The nurse is teaching a parent about administering nitrofurantoin suspension to a 5-year-old child. Which instruction will the nurse include in the patient teaching?
options: “Give the medication on an empty stomach.”
“Have the child rinse their mouth after taking the drug.”
“Limit the child's fluid intake to concentrate the urine.”
“Report brownish-colored urine to the child's provider.”
questions.rationale: www.NursingExamBank.com Nitrofurantoin suspension can stain the teeth, so patients should rinse their mouth after taking it. Nitrofurantoin should be taken with food, and patients should increase fluid intake. A reddish- brown discoloration of the urine is a harmless side effect.

questions.category: Chapter 51: Urinary Disorders
questions.stem: A patient will begin taking an antimuscarinic medication to treat overactive bladder. Which symptom should the patient report immediately?
options: Dry mouth
Fatigue
Increased heart rate
Urinary retention
questions.rationale: Urinary retention should be reported to the provider. Dry mouth, fatigue, and increased heart rate are potential side effects, but they do not necessarily warrant immediate notification of the provider. Urinary retention is more serious and warrants immediate attention should it occur.

questions.category: Chapter 52: Pregnancy and Preterm Labor
questions.stem: A pregnant woman asks the nurse about whether a medication is safe to take during pregnancy. The nurse notes that the drug has a low-molecular weight. Based on this drug characteristic, the nurse understands that this drug
options: can cause greater gastrointestinal distress and hyperemesis when compared to www.NursingExamBank.com high-molecular weight drugs.
has reduced renal elimination resulting in toxicity when compared to high- molecular weight drugs.
is more sensitive to metabolism by circulating maternal hormones when compared to high-molecular weight drugs.
will be more likely to cross the placenta and affect the fetus when compared to high-molecular weight drugs.
questions.rationale: Low-molecular-weight drugs are more likely to cross the placental barrier when compared to high-molecular weight drugs. This characteristic does not contribute to increased GI distress or toxicity because of reduced renal elimination. Drugs with low-molecular weight are not more sensitive to metabolism by maternal hormones.

questions.category: Chapter 52: Pregnancy and Preterm Labor
questions.stem: A woman who is 4 weeks pregnant is worried that a medication she took until 3 weeks ago may cause birth defects. The nurse will tell her that
options: drugs taken in the first week of pregnancy can cause CNS defects.
medications have increased teratogenicity during the first week of pregnancy.
she should have an ultrasound immediately.
teratogenic effects are rare in the first 2 weeks of pregnancy.
questions.rationale: During the first 2 weeks, the embryo is not susceptible to teratogenesis. There is no need for an ultrasound.

questions.category: Chapter 52: Pregnancy and Preterm Labor
questions.stem: Which statement by the nurse is accurate regarding iron supplementation during pregnancy? www.NursingExamBank.com
options: “Women should only take an iron supplement if they have a documented serum iron deficiency.”
“Iron supplements are given to supply the fetus.”
“Low-dose iron supplementation is recommended starting at the first prenatal appointment.”
“The greatest iron demand is in the first trimester of pregnancy.”
questions.rationale: Low-dose iron supplementation is recommended by the CDC starting at the first prenatal appointment. Iron supplements are given to prevent maternal iron deficiency, not to supply the fetus. The greatest demand occurs in the third trimester.

questions.category: Chapter 52: Pregnancy and Preterm Labor
questions.stem: A patient who has just delivered her baby asks the nurse if she needs to continue taking her iron supplement. What instruction will the nurse provide to the patient?
